												Disappointment. That's what I feel after playing this game. I wanted to like it so much and it has a lot of potential and appealing aspects, but looking beyond the amazing atmosphere of a black and white platformer and there's only disappointment.I expected a fun puzzle game that provided a good challenge, but instead it's a do-everything-at-the-perfect-time-or-you-fail-while-being-timed-already type of game where every task feels trivial and doesn't give you with a sense of achieving anything. The puzzles aren't even difficult, simply tedious, and after completing one and moving on to the next there's no feeling of excitement to overcome the challenge of the game but rather dread that the next puzzle is going to take even longer to get the timing right. And the one after that even longer. And the one after that even longer.I was hoping for some sense of a story, for some feeling that accompanied the atmosphere and haunting connection of being in LIMBO, but it's simply not there. And the lack of any sense of this makes everything you do in the game feel like you are mindlessly completing poorly designed puzzles. Not to mention the physics in the game can be a bit questionable and the controls have issues with response, and you're only getting more tedious things to deal with to make the challenge of the game.Unless you are passionate about this genre, I can't even suggest picking it up in a sale. It feels highly overhyped simply because of its atmosphere and potential.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												Limbo, the game, is special in that while it does not wholly depict that mysterious dimension as my mind did, it captures its essence. You are a boy who wakes up in a lonely world made up only of black, white, and shades of gray. Video game logic demands you walk from left to right, jumping over obstacles as they appear, a simple task that needs little attention in the initial moments. This is your chance to absorb your surroundings. The background provides an illusion of depth, but its branches and bridges are out of focus, as if you are dreaming them into existence. The pint-sized hero, his bright blinking eyes shining from his blackened silhouette, trots ahead with the charming gangliness of a six-year-old.You can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.Then comes death. Limbo is a hostile place, home to giant spiders that would feast upon you, and traps apparently scattered by the world's other denizens. You step onto a claw trap, and it closes on your neck. Your head falls to the ground and wobbles just for a moment before lying still. No tears are shed, no music plays--the game provides no grand gesture to honor your demise. It simply happens, and you revive at the most recent checkpoint to try the puzzle again. Some of these deaths aren't outright fair; stepping on a pressure plate could mean certain death, but so could jumping over it. Such inconsistencies aren't common, but your first time in Limbo requires some trial-and-error experimentation. Loading times are short, and checkpoints are frequent, however, so death is rarely a frustration, though often a horror.What does it all mean? People pondered that question when Limbo was first released on the Xbox 360 in 2010, and the PC version adds nothing new that would illuminate the mystery of this world, so there's little reason to splurge on another version if you've already played. Nevertheless, the ending offers important clues to the greater plot, if not to the details of the game's events and objects--the imposing neon hotel sign that you must cross, for instance, or the murderous children, seemingly escaped from Lord of the Flies, that aim their blowguns at you. Limbo means for its atmosphere to consume you in the moment, and in that sense, it succeeds. You drag a dead child's corpse to solve a puzzle, and perhaps wonder if anyone grieves this lost soul given the apathy of the realm. You glimpse a figure and regard her with tenderness, but the brief glimmer of hope is snuffed out in an instant.After life, before death.It isn't until the final third of its two- to three-hour runtime that Limbo's puzzles become challenging. The first half of the game is more concerned with building dread and ambiguity. Even after being vanquished, a colossal spider's remaining leg thrusts at you from its thorax, one final act of defiance that could leave two corpses for the crows to pick. When you pull the leg from the spider, the audible cracks and visible white splatters emphasize just how recently its life force was crushed. Elsewhere, you push boxes and pull levers, rushing to finish the puzzle before the rising water fills the room. Failure means watching the dear boy go as limp as a ragdoll as liquid fills his lungs.The second half leaves behind the horrors in favor of puzzles involving gravity and complex machinery. As memorable as it is to navigate tilting rooms with only a few hanging lamps to light the way, it is that spider that most embodies Limbo's somber spirit. The later puzzles are complex and clever, but they don't haunt the heart. The finale feels abrupt because it returns to the first hour's imagery, having abandoned it for long enough to have altered your personal connection with the game from an emotional one to an intellectual one. And yet the end offers insight into a backstory left otherwise untouched--enough of it to inspire another playthrough, this time ever so much wiser than you were before.THE GOOD Striking atmosphere that chills the heart Excellent, poignant moments that stay with you Cold, gruesome deaths are presented with memorable and horrific apathy Introduces more involved puzzles at a satisfying paceTHE BAD The most haunting imagery is limited to the first half Ending doesn't emerge organically from the hour leading to it8/10GREAT

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Limbo started off as an experience. Similar to what you'd expect when seeing the trailer for it: an intriguing and relaxing theme of soft mystery through a peaceful environment. Distinctly stylistic, mostly lush and natural, industrial bits sometimes in moderation. Light puzzles are sprinkled in here and there. Nothing complex enough to ruin the experience or slow the progression.Then the puzzles get complex. Water puzzles. Gravity puzzles. Magnet puzzles. Speed puzzles. Timing puzzles. The only good thing I can say about them is it'll start you right back in front of the puzzle you failed instead of make you do an entire segment over like most games.LIMBO loses it's magic as the difficulty increases. It became just another puzzle game by the end. The lush relaxing environments largely became plain beam platforms and simple straight angle rooms. The magical relaxing nature disappeared because of the difficulty spike. The world's mystery theme vanishes entirely as though the story was only early bait made specifically for the trailer. I honestly feel a little let down. This game had a magical feel for half of it. Then the second half dropped that. I wouldn't be surprised if two different people designed separate halves of the game.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Really good atmosphere and general artstyle could make this game rise above the others. Unfortunately, I feel that when compared to other puzzle \ platformer games, visuals and sounds are really the only thing that Limbo does well.There are a few puzzles that are very smart and challenging, but most of the times you'll find the solution right away and you'll have to push some block or run very slowly to the solution. It's boring and irritating to have to spend so much time to solve a puzzle that you could have solved right away... and it's even more irritating to die while solving it, because you jumped a tenth of a second too early ( timing is really the essential skill in here) Other times I felt deaths were a little cheap, with objects that are virtually unavoidable on your first try, since you can't \ won't really see them hanging out in the darkness.Also, the story. This is very much a personal opinion (as the rest of the review, btw)  and I know plenty of people like open ended stories or having to fill in the spots. Still, this is way too much if you ask me. There are so many websites arguing about what this game means, and that's because nothing is explained at all. You wake up in a forest, run away from a spider, then other things, at some point from other humans, then machines, then you find a girl. And I know lots of hints can be gathered by visual imagery, yet these are the only elements that one can know for sure about the plot.Overall, this game is very short, unexplained and with a gameplay that can be both frustrating and boring. Yes, there are things to be loved here, but I'd suggest thinking twice before buying it (basically if you want something short, visually appealing and interesting, this might actually be for you)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												9.5/10 - Why such a high score for a game this simple? Because there is little to find wrong with it. Seriously. Sure, it might be on the short side, clocking in at just a couple 2 or 3 hours. But that is about it. For what it is, it is wonderful. In Limbo, you play the role of a boy, who is for the purpose of this game, nameless. You will pretty much go from left to right the entire game, with very little need to backtrack, and when you do, not very far. You will run through a macabre-like setting, that changes atmosphere as you progress the various settings. You will see a few people, but not many. You will see very few enemies period. The game just seems like you are in some hopeless kind of setting. and that is the whole point of Limbo. The gameplay is a mix of platforming, and environmental puzzles, seamlessly mixed together, without need for an inclined difficulty as you progress. Instead, it chooses to go for a more relaxed increase, and keep you focused instead on the atmosphere, rather than difficult situations. However, when die, is it ever satisfying! As grim as that sounds, it is indeed. Limbo has some wonderfully sadistic and amusing deaths for our young nameless protagonist. The animations for each are wonderfully extecuted, as the young boy is well...executed, so to speak. Visuals are entirely black and white, on purpose. But you do get wonderful shades of everything with the lack of color, and a nice film grain to really set the tone for the eerie environments you will find yourself pushing through. The audio is mostly ambient, with really no traditional music to speak of. Instead, it goes for acoustamatic music to set the tone. Everything basically has a purpose to pull you into the game. As for story, it is entirely left up to interpretation. But once you get to the ending, you will find yourself either scratching your head, or thinking up one of many possible explanations on what really happened. Either way, Limbo will leave you satisfied. Simply put: BUY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: January 21
Product received for free
												I think you will like this game if:1) You're a big fan of puzzle platformers2) You're a hardcore speedrunner3) You're an extreme sucker for noir and atmospheric stuffI dabble in all three of the above, but not enough to truly like this game, which I got for free and am glad that I did. Obviously I'm in the minority here, and I won't deny that Limbo does some things well. The environments are interesting, especially in the forest levels, and I quite liked the parts that have you fighting against giant spiders and strange children that seem right out of Lord of the Flies. The whole concept of a brave little boy stuck in some kind of shadowy world is a good one, and I like white noise, so the game's quite pleasant to listen to.But I just got bored. Once you're out of the forest the puzzles devolve into block pushing/physics manipulation sections, which have to be some of my least favorite game mechanics. Everything just drags and drags until it all abruptly ends, and the game relies on style to stick out in your mind way more than interesting gameplay. I can see why a lot of people like this, and I think it may have played better in 2010 when it first came out. But even back then you already had great puzzle platformers like Prince of Persia, Flashback, Another World and Heart of Darkness on the market, and I'd rather play any of those than Limbo again.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24
												LIMBO is a game that I first played upon its release in 2011, though I played it on my Xbox 360. Just a handful of years ago, I remember being very creeped out by the game's premise and dark world.However, after replaying the game just now, I find that it was not that exciting. It seems that I look at LIMBO and other games differently than some years ago. I thought that the minimalist story of the game back then was some magic answer, as if it was free of criticism - especially with the ending of the game. But that is not quite right. While the set-up of the game is definitely eerie, this time around I seemed to have wanted more. LIMBO definitely could have had more to it.The early part of the game gives you that weird feeling because there are other creatures and seemingly human beings in this place with you. But in the later part of the game, all of that vanishes, and it becomes nothing but boxes and water and saws and gravity. The disappearance of other life could have been done as a means to make you feel even worse about the place you are in, but it did not have such an effect. If anything, it just seems like the developers did not know what else to do with other life.Environment-wise, the game's appearance and sound fit the overall idea. In fact, music does not exist at all, and you only hear your footsteps and random objects clashing around here and there. Fitting for the "dead" world that you are helplessly navigating. Darkness. Fog. Minimal light. The visuals also fit that bad realm of LIMBO.While I am not necessarily saying that the game is bad, I was just not as impressed as I was when I first played it. I feel like the game is a one-time-go, and then it's not really good to return. I also think that it is easy for you to overrate it (as I did myself years ago), because of things like the black and white shadow artwork. People seem to just look at the game and because of the visuals, it is already pulling them in and ready to say that it is good.As LIMBO is a game, the gameplay itself is actually not that amazing. The game is literally die-and-repeat-until-you-win. Most of the puzzles have hidden obstacles or traps which are not easy to tell until you run through the first time. It may seem funny at first, but is actually not that amazing once you find out that a lot of the challenge is simply that. You have to repeat until you understand how to get around something.For instance (slight spoilers if you care about single-pass obstacles), one of the sillier examples is early in the game. You are running through an area and you see two sets of mini-platforms that look like buttons, each of which are sitting on top of panels and underneath giant weights. If you run onto the first panel, then the weight comes down and crushes you. So you must jump onto the mini-platform button, and then jump across to the regular floor again. Now, as you'll probably know where it's going from my context, the next panel and button are swapped. If you jump onto the second button, you get crushed again. So this time you must use the panel and jump over the button, avoiding it.The developers did the above example as a means to simply trick you easily and add a little artificial time to the game, as you'll have to repeat getting around it - but you only do so once. And that is very common in this game, with you having to die here and there until you are able to know what is ahead of you, and what you need to use to stop yourself from dying. That is not necessarily a good design, in my opinion. It would be alright to happen a little bit, but not as often as it really does.And you also have the amount of gameplay there is, which is very little. Despite having already played the game years ago, I did not really remember much of the puzzles and still died quite a bit. Even so, I was able to complete the game in about 2 hours or a bit less. There is not a tremendous amount of content in the game; and quite a few of the puzzles are meticulous in a bad way, meaning a good chunk of the 2 hours was repeating attempts to get past the same obstacles over and over.Sadly, I did not have that much enjoyment, excitement, or feeling of accomplishment playing through LIMBO. While I still intend to try out Playdead's INSIDE game, I do not see myself returning to this one.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
Product received for free
												This game started of quite strong, but in the end fell short.It has a very beautiful style of using the contrast of black and white, and has some really interesting ideas.LIMBO was a game I really wanted a few years back as I saw a lot of great things said about the game. Well, then it became free for a while, and as I played it, well. I was disappointed.While I certanly didn't hate it and I would rather play this than many of the recent titles, I still did not manage to enjoy this to the fullest due to some simple things.The puzzles in this game are made to be simple, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, as a matter of fact the puzzles were quite enjoyable. Instead of making the puzzles complex they made them simple, but still a little to think about. The puzzles are heavily reliant on timing for the most part and object placement, which I found to be great, but unfortunately there were a few flaws which made me really have an unenjoyable experience:Learning from your mistakes as you die was clearly the focus of this game, but only effectively used this at the start of the game and midway trough, as in for example at the beginning they had put a hardly visible trap on the ground, which of course killed you, but also clearly was meant to aid you, and the game delivered this message to the player quite fast making you use the trap in a creative way. But as I said, half the time this was not the case, and you would often find yourself dying in unfair circumstances, and all you will learn from them is to avoid them. This felt like a waste of time for me, and possibly many others.The biggest problem with this game though was with the controls and movement:First you get thrown into the game with no introduction, you just need to run and then drag a box under a platform. There is the first problem: I needed to spam my keyboards every single button until I found out the correct button to grab objects with. They did not bind this control to anything obvious like E or Shift, but instead to CTRL. A button rarely, possibly never used in any video game to do similar tasks. For many people it is very hard to move pinky to such location, and even for a person like me who uses this button to crouch in every game, it felt very slow compared to buttons they could have used, such as E.-Another problem with this is the fact that the only way to change the key binds is to go trough the game files to find the correct file in which you'll be able to tamper with controls. The game should have had some keyboard customization options at least.After this the game progresses nicely, but you'll encounter various places where you will have troubles with how the movement works. The first problem being the CTRL bind for grabbing, as you will need to use it a lot while trying to go trough challenging areas where slightest error would cause a death, but the placement of the key makes it frustrating at times. Secondly after climbing on top of a box you will not be able to jump for a brief amount, so you might end up spamming the jump key in a tight situation, and jump at a 0,2 second latency, making you unprepared for the late jump which leads to your death.If you think you can get past these, then by all means have a go with this game.

I want to give it 11/10, 6/5, A+/A, 110%/100% - just kidding, there is no such thing as 110% :-D Anyway, this game has everything a good arcade has to have: puzzles, tough places, no-end (for some people is pointless, for some is not, I personally think, that it had a very huge point) and also monsters ! content:
Posted: February 3, 2012
												I love this game.You play as a little boy stuck in limbo, a side scrolling puzzle game that follows this boy on his adventures through limbo in a creepy, eerie setting with darkness all around him. This game really does make good use of contrast and silhouettes. It gives the game a really unique feel to it.The puzzles are different and creative; it starts off pretty simple and gets a lot harder as it goes along.The best part of this game for me though, is the ending and the little things you pick up between levels. There is no dialog in this game, and it definitely doesn’t spell anything out for you. A lot of it is open to interpretation and I really like that about this game. It’s a beautiful and unique indie game, one that I really did enjoy. Well worth a try.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												A good friend of mine finished this with 100% achievements and wanted to see how I fared.  It had been sitting in my backlog for nearly 2 years, so why not.  Boy was I in for a surprise.  The style is something I've seen copied in a few other titles already. Shadowy and spooky, but not frightening or stressful. And the gameplay is extremely clever.  However, I have to say there is also a good deal of hidden bits that will end up killing you repeatedly.  Towards the end especially, I got quite stuck until I realized some parts I thought were scenery were really part of the game.  Puzzles vary from hard to solve, hard to platform, hard to time well, and hard to sequence.  It never coddled me or left me too far in the dark, though.  It was tough when it needed to be and a definte challenge to see through to the end. You will die a hundred deaths and swear, but once you solve a level it is a very satisfying feeling. I still need to unlock the secret level, though.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Product received for free
												It's difficult to sum this up in one sentence but I will try: it attempts, and does a good job at, drawing your primal fears.Darkness.Big creepy crawlies.Unknown.Tight spaces.Death.LIMBO is a minimalistic, 2D puzzle platformer, in which you control a nameless boy through environments which are, to put it lightly, hazardous. There is no exposition, no dialogue and very little information; the story is left up to you to piece it together. The title of the game, oppressive atmosphere and the little girl at the end should give an idea of what you're going through.The art style is minimal, with absolutely no colour whatsoever. For the most part you can distinguish items you can interact with. Key word is "most".Even the sound design is minimal, yet impeccable. Headphones ABSOLUTELY RECOMMENDED.Controls are the bare essentials: jump and climb on ropes or ladders, move left and right, drop or descend from ropes or ladders, and a general interaction button with which you can push or pull items, or trigger mechanisms. It's physics based, so momentum and angle are taken into account when traversing terrain, as well as how fast or heavy things must be to kill you, and you will die a lot. No wonder the devs called it "trial and death".My playthrough, which was completing the main levels, took around 2 hours, but several achievements reward exploration in certain areas, and there might be a hidden level I've missed, so that's probably going to bring the playtime up a bit.The regular price tag makes it a bit difficult to justify the purchase, as although it is an experience, it doesn't offer enough longevity I feel. Grab it on sale, or for free until the special offer ends.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												This is a short, atmospheric game that takes 3-4 hours to beat. However, its unique, evil/melancholy feel makes it an absolutely worthwhile game. The dark atmosphere is haunting and cool, and the gameplay is well paced. It is not an especially challenging game but you will die a fair amount. For those interested, this game is all basic puzzle solving; the only controls are movement, jump, and an action/interact button. There is no combat.Pros:+Unique and awesome scary atmosphere+Simple but entertaining puzzles+Not hard, but not so easy it's boring. Good difficulty imo.Cons:-Game only lasts 3-4 hoursFor the squeamish, you do see a child die in gruesome ways; but since he is just a cartoony silhouette, it's not all that violent.This game is a no-brainer on sale, and it's probably worth the full $10 too. It's a memorable experience.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I downloaded the demo a few year's ago on the Xbox 360 and I remember loving the idea of being given no direction and having to figure everything out right from the beginning. So when I saw it on sale, I knew I had to buy it on Steam. What's neat about the game is that it progressively gets more elaborate and difficult. So while you start out by moving things to new places, without giving anything away, by the end of the game you have to be a master in timing.Be warned, this game is impossible to beat without dying 654894651684 times. Trust me I counted. But seriously, if you hate dying a million times trying to figure something out or are easily frustrated, you should probably stay away.In conclusion, if you like to figure things out without any hints or tips, then check this game out. I enjoyed it quite a bit and while I passed it in a relatively short period of time, I am looking forward to going back and getting some of the achievements and hopefully dying a lot less.-VR

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Short and sweet, but I like that about this game.  Limbo takes platforming into a dark, depressing and desperate world and does not lighten up one bit.The "story" was very emotional for me.  Enough questions are left unanswered to allow the player to come to his/her own conclusion, which can be tough to do but pays off well here.The controls are simple and balanced.  The game doesn't find its natch by sending volleys of flashy attacks and hordes of repetitive enemies at you like some plat-formers.  Instead, each encounter feels like a dream.  You do what you can to survive, but you are clearly not in control of your surroundings, and you feel as though your character truly doesn't belong in this place.The game also does not use an "awesome sound track!" to sell itself.  The game is quiet and eery -- dive into Limbo and see what feelings arise.Best bought on sale.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Short version: 71%Limbo has a catchy art design and an interesting, depressing atmosphere. Sadly those are the only real selling points of this otherwise quite generic puzzle platformer.Long version:Limbo is all about style: a noir-like, minimalist, but nonetheless unique art style. If you wouldn’t mind staring at what you see in the preview screenshots for 2-4 hours, then Limbo will definitely be your game. And it knows how important first expressions are, because the initial atmosphere is superb, the eerie forest sets a very memorable tone.Still, it is mostly just a façade. A façade that hides a fairly generic puzzle platformer set in the most overused and tired settings for such games, a boring factory. A façade that tries to hide the fact that the game has no story: all you do is walk right and try to get past various obstacles that prevent you from walking right.As for puzzle mechanics, there are a few clever ones, like a parasite that makes you unable to stop moving in one direction (usually towards a pit), or some gravity manipulation. They are too rare though in the endless sea of uninspired box and switch puzzles. And they aren’t even difficult puzzles; the difficulty comes from trying to implement the easy solutions with incredibly tight timing and jumps. You’re gonna die. A lot. (©LordKat)If puzzle platformers are your thing, by all means, get it. Despite my musings, it is one of the better ones to come out in these years. Just don’t have too high expectations for it.

content:
Posted: January 9
												LIMBO is a very atmospheric game that is both punishing and rewarding.LIMBO is not something you can just walk through without dying. You will die, and die, and die. You will die over and over again (unless you guide, then you cheater :P). However, you will learn from those death experiences and solve the different environmental puzzles and situations. LIMBO has a very nice saving system so that there is rarely ever a headbang rage moment. Some of the puzzles are actually quite difficult if you don't think outside the box and use all of the environment. The game is punishing if you are impatient and do not closely observe the environment. However, LIMBO truly has a good progression and none of the situations are hard beyond belief. The environment is also what makes the game so good, it is so well crafted and fits the atmosphere perfectly. The sounds and music also match the game very well.The only bad thing about LIMBO is that I hate the weak and short hops of this little boy. It's like he has never jumped before in his life and it is honestly the most insanely stupid short jump. Although this isn't really a big problem because that's the way the game is designed, it still annoyed me.Overall, very solid game that deserves to be played by all. There are very little if any cons to this game.Rating: 8.1/10Recommend Price: $6.49 or Lower

												A very mind-boggling puzzle game with amazingly setup puzzles, challenges, tricks, and more for you to explore. Each puzzle will leave you wondering how to solve it for a while, others will be simple and easy to solve halfway through, until you realize you've made a mistake somewhere along the line. Anything and everything could kill you, always leaving you hoping you solved the puzzle right. The save states are generous, but there are some very annoying timed puzzles near the end of the game. The visuals and art style are great, along with the level design, SFX, and music. I don't particularly like single player games, but this game is a must buy because of its cheap price, great design, and calming ambience.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												5/5A fantastic little, morbid adventure. Dark and gloomy. Vague and gorey. Clever and enraging. This is an artistic platform game that forces you to think outside the box--quite often, but every successful attempt is rewarding and leaves you feeling accomplished. This game touched me more than you might expect on an emotional level, too. I affectionately refer to the player as "Billy" because he doesn't really have a name. And he doesn't really talk. Or... anything, really. But that's part of the charm! It's a platform game with a delightful twist. It's kinda creepy and fun. Expect to die a lot but once you get that "Aha!" moment, it makes it all worth it. The checkpoints are also really handy and the game is merciless but not punishing, if that makes sense. A fun little adventure. 5/5 might seem like much but I'm rating it not based on what it is, but what it's trying to be. And it succeeds in its goal of being a clever, original platformer.

Product received for free
												Caveat:  Steam offered this program for free sometime during or around the last Steam Sale.  That's the only reason I have it.  It's a platformer, and, in general, I don't like platformers.  I don't like the time pressure the game puts on me at various locations.  I don't like the jump/miss/die/repeat activity to get through the puzzles.  I don't like the "discovery by death" methodology used in the puzzles.But, realizing that those are personal preferences, I've got to admit that from a technical perspective, it's a well done game.  The visuals, though basically a shadow-play, are all good, the controls (once you figure them out) are simple, and the checkpoints are close enough that the constant dying isn't too onerous.  At a technical level, my only real issue is that there's no explanation for why everything and everyone in the game is trying to kill the player.It took me 6.3 hours to play the game with all Achievements except for the final big one (play it through in one setting with 5 or fewer deaths).  Since I don't like platformers, I doubt I'll ever try to get that last Achievement.  So, at my dollar an hour metric, I'd say anything below $6 would be a great price (and since I got it for free, I can't complain).  So, I'm recommending it (with reservations).

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
-Quick Review-Limbo is what I would call a “Puzzle platform physics engine game”. The game has simple controls, but the puzzles do require some forethought. The game is priced normally at $9.99, I would personally recommend waiting until there was a sale on the game.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You play the story as a silhouette character that is always seemingly running to the right in an attempt to get someplace. Game Play: Great puzzles, sometimes tricky timed jumps, sometimes morbid, the best word to describe this game is “fascinating”.Achievements: Many of the achievements are easy to get, most of them require stepping on little white orbs found throughout the game, but there are a few very tough achievements such as “No point in dying”. (…Which I am still working on, as of 02/12/14)Price: I’ve put 6 hours into the game, in my opinion that isn’t enough time to be worth $9.99 the game was on a humble bundle sale when I purchased it, so I’ve been very satisfied with the quality of the game.Conclusion: If you’re in the market for a short little platformer adventure and have a few hours to burn, this is a great game for you to play, however the price is too high to purchase normally

content:
Posted: June 4, 2012
A Paladin's Review: Limbo. Dark and Moody Atmosphere in a Brutal World.Genre: 2D Puzzle Platformer.Developed & Published by: PlaydeadPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux, Consoles. Business Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Read the original review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsYou play as an unnamed, and apparently mute, boy searching through dark woods and city landscapes for something. According to the game description, you're looking for his sister. Oddly enough, there is no mention of this in the game though it's implied. There isn't much of a story in this game. You simply wake up in a forest, with no idea who you are or what's going on. In the background, you see trees and as you go along you start seeing buildings, plants and factories. It is almost as if your in a side world to the "real world" but the game never really explains this. The game has a distinct ending, but its a bit abrupt and isn't that satisfying to me. There isn't much to spoil about the ending of the game, but I won't spoil it so you'll have to play it to find out what happens.This story's character is no saint, to say the least. While one could make the claim that it was kill or be killed, he does some things that make me wonder. There are certain parts where the kid will kill the other kids via traps. There is also one point of the game where you have to pull a leg out of a spider that's been trying to kill you in order to progress further. Usually, you feel justified to an enemy, but ugh, doing that really made me queasy. PuzzlesSo what about the puzzles themselves? Well, they weren't too bad. They tended to range from jumping around, moving objects to the right place, using the physics engine and jumping at the right time, otherwise you were dead. It also includes some gravity puzzles as well as a part where an insect limits your movement. The overall difficulty curve is gentle and gradual for most of the time. None of the puzzles got to the point that required a ridiculous amount of precision in order to progress though. However, I did find some of the puzzles can be frustratingly opaque. I ran into a couple that required some help from guides. One other thing I should point out is that while the game auto-saves as you progress, there are a few puzzles that if you screw up, it sets you back a little bit more than I would like, which can lead to some frustration as you redo the steps over and over again until you get it right. PC Settings & Audio/VideoPC settings are fairly limited though you don't need many for 2D Games. You can change are controls and brightness levels. No V-Sync, AA, AF, resolution options or anything else. It's limited but to the game's credit, seems to scale well from my experience. I never had any lag or crashing or other issues crop up during gameplay. The game is very light on graphic settings, though your not going to really need to change them as long as you have a decent computer. It is controller compatible if you prefer controllers. The keybindings aren't changeable, but I found the default ones are smartly placed.The game's OST is very atmospheric. At first the music stays in the background, but as you progress along and get into the city-section, the music starts getting in your face, almost overwhelming you as you try and solve the puzzles all the way to the end of the game. The sounds itself sound very realistic, though sometimes muted. There is a flying insect in the game that slightly creeped me out thanks to the sound design. Final ThoughtsIn the end, I had more fun that I thought I would with this game. The unique visuals sets this game apart and makes it memorable, helped in no small part by how brutally dark this game is. It only clocks in at about three to fours hours for a run through it. But I was satisfied with the length of the game given how cheap it is and how well designed it is. There's a reason that a lot of games are based on the Limbo formula and why so many people played this title. It's worth giving a look for the moody atmosphere, the dark music and tight platforming.Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

content:
Posted: September 1, 2012
												LIMBO is a sidescrolling platformer with physics- and gravity-based puzzles and an unique visual art style.'Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO' is the only thing that the store page says about the game. This single line is basically the whole story of the game and your one and only reason to go on.The puzzles are decent but not extraordinary brilliant or innovative. After all, it's the visual art style of the game that raised the interest among players.With roughly 2 hours of playtime, the game is extremely short for a game of this genre. On the other hand, it doesn't try to stretch the playtime by repeating the same puzzles over and over again.LIMBO certainly isn't a bad game, but if you are expecting a brilliant platformer with loads of playtime and replayability, then you might want to look somewhere else as this game most likely isn't for you.I'm not sure I would recommed it at its full price, but at 75% off during the major sales, it's certainly worth it.

content:
Posted: April 15
												I have had Limbo in my gaming library for the longest of times, and I have always looked for the right time to bring it out of the darkness and into the light and start playing it through (analogy intended ;) . However I also wanted to wait and play Limbo the way I think this type of game was meant to be played, and that is with a controller on a big TV screen.I can't emphasise enough the importance of playing Limbo with a gaming controller. Now, not everyone has to agree with me on this, but if you are going to play this game, don't go at it on a "small" computer screen with a keyboard, its a little like playing FPS games with a ps/xbox controller, it just doesn't make the game proper justice. You have been warned.With that said, lets get on with the game L-I-M-B-O. And what a game it is. So well designed and directed, I am absolutley speechless. Limbo is not quite a platformer, and it's not quite a puzzle game, I could make it easy for myself and say it is a mix of both genres but... I would like to describe Limbo more as an immersive feeling, the game touches you without even a word being uttered throughout the whole game. Limbo takes you to places of lonelyness and war, a desolate place with trees and animals in a forest, there are gruesome deaths, machines and children, without any context and meaning, yet it all makes sense somehow.You, as a player, are totally commited to playing this through and through, and throughout the whole 4-5hours that I played, I never once got bored, only touched and amazed. The graphics and sounds mix seamleassly and completing one another in the most subtle ways and in what appears to be a minimalistic design, however such is not the case. Each section of the game has been carefully planned to the slightest detail, to mesh together seamlessly, hence the excellent minimalistic black and white design and the subtle sounds of the world of Limbo. Limbos art direction scales aways so much clutter and color and thus as a player your are solelyl left to focus only on the feeling- , exploring, and advancing the game.At this point you are probably wondering what the h**l is the game about, if you haven't heard or read about Limbo, I strongly suggest you youtube it and find some gameplay. Simply put, the game is the modern trendsetter for the puzzle/platformer games/genre, where its not about being able to jump over enemies and getting extra lives ala Super Mario Bros, but solving situations with the help your characters abilities, which is your brain, because the character, the little boy, himself, does not posses any abilities actually, outside of jumping and grabbing ledges. There is only one way to solve each problem, which is fine, and only once or twice did I have to youtube the solution to a problem. And for this review I would like to take the time to highlight one thing that probably most gamers never take into consideration, the game tester of Limbo that have done a tremendous job. This game is totally successfull because of game testers feedback has been right on point. Since in no part of the game do you really get stuck with a puzzle for too long, and this is 99% doing of the actual game testers. The testers have to understand what challenges each player faces and put their "new player" glasses on everytime they play the game. Don't get me wrong, the planning and direction and all that is the doing of the team, but where many puzzle games go wrong, is that you are at times lost of what to do next and how to do it, especially in this genre of games, but in Limbo, 99% of the time you know what to do intuitively or at least have a clue of what you are supposed to do, and what you can do to achieve the solution.  Final verdict: Get this game and start playing if you haven't dones so already, no questions asked, hands down (preferably on a controller ;) & Happy gaming!

content:
Posted: January 5
												Great indie puzzle platformer which moves at a very nice pace. You'll only spend roughly 2-4 hours playing this game, but it's definitely worth a go. The puzzles start very easy and become intuitive with slight increase in difficulty. The game requires a small amount of mechanical skill (jump timings, time coordinations, etc.) Progressing through the game rewards players with a nice sense of wit and accomplishment.The game can easily be played with a keyboard and includes a nice option to select different parts of your journey you can load in to. (This mechanic is nice for obtaining all the collectable achievments) There isn't much of a storyline. The game itself never mentions that the boy is searching for his sister (I only knew this due to the description). The game is dark, both figuratively and literally, giving a nice thematic to the title. Controls could be tighter, but really it's no big deal.8/10 :D

★★★★★A classic. Short, but perfect.It certainly got a lot of attention, including from other small-time developpers who try to bank on the same estetic style. In Limbo, it actually means something, as it conveys the horror that only comes across more effectively because of it.It also got the attention of my girlfriend, who normally dislikes games, but was blown away by Limbo and its predecessor INSIDE. The style, mystery and the gameplay just comes together in a perfect, harmonious, thought-out way.It might be somewhat expensive for some at a price of 10-15 bucks, but it's certainly worth 5 whole ones.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												9/10 - Simple, yet amazing.2/2 for GRAPHICS:The lool of this game proofs that superfancy highend graphic is not required to create a beautiful and atmospheric look.2/2 for SOUND:The soundambience just goes hand in hand with the look of the game, and together they create this beautiful dark atmosphere. Theres not really music playing, just background sounds - it fits they game perfectly.2/2 for GAMEPLAY:The gameplay of LIMBO consists solely of plattforming and puzzle solving. The difficulty raises as you progress, but doesn't get unfair. Also there are lots of mechanics which gives the puzzles a rich of variety. It's good for what it is, nothing more, nothing less.1,5/2 for STORY:The story of LIMBO is very simple and basic, although it leaves pretty much open and unanswered. The things that you know about the story can be explain in 5 seconds, it's not really complex. But still, it fits the game somehow.1,5/2 is my PERSONAL OPINION:I myself really enjoyed the game, especially since its pretty unique. There are not many games you could compare to LIMBO.I would recommened this game to pretty much everyone, since it doesn't cost that much. Especially plattformer fans and people who enjoy atmospheric games will have a good time playing this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Product received for free
												If you like ambiance, artistic and atmospheric games, and can handle puzzle platforming challenges, you'll almost certainly like this. I almost never care about stuff like that - other games that people enjoy because of their "atmosphere" don't end up appealing to me if they don't have gameplay that I'm really interested in, but this game pulls it off so well that I have to say the atmosphere is one of the main reasons I like it. The puzzle platformer aspect is perfectly fine as well. It's nothing very complex, but it manages to avoid being repetitive and is constantly introducing new mechanics for you to work with. It has highs and lows of intensity, with more action-oriented segments and other more sit-and-think type segments, and it ends up having a nice flow of stimulation because of that. I've played plenty of puzzle platformers in my time and all I can say about the puzzles in this game is that they are decent and don't detract from the atmosphere.All of that said, unless it looks really appealing to you, it's not 10 dollars worth of entertainment. I got this for free during a sale, and that's probably the only way I would've played this game. You're paying 10 dollars for about 2-3 hours of entertainment, probably. I'm not saying that every game is only as valuable as its cost per hours ratio; this game certainly packs a lot of aesthetic and gameplay entertainment into that short time, but I just could never justify spending 10 dollars on it. If you're really into artistic games, though, you may find it to be worth it. Other than that, I would just recommend waiting for a really heavy discount. Definitely consider giving this a try at some point, though. I've played lots of games and this one is certainly unique.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												A limbo is a state of mind wherein a person is unable to escape his dream. The game presents a young boy in a limbo who embarks on a journey to reunite with his sister. The atmosphere has been perfected to a dark and grim theme and it stands true to the predicament that the boy finds himself in.A simple 2D platformer is combined with a simple control system. The real challenge is in figuring out ways of advancing the stage with a keen eye toward the environment. Besides, there exists death traps and monsters that wreck the poor boy to pieces and its absolutely gruesome when limbs tear apart (no pun intended).Ofcourse, frustration arises when you repeatedly die and fail to realize the way out. The game however feels relaxing when you need a break from other titles.Rated 9.5/10

content:

Product received for free
												I've always heard of good things about Limbo, but it never piqued my interest enough to buy it until I got it from the HB Store. It's an atmospheric platformer with a minimalist approach to just about everything. When you start the game, you're just shown a little boy in the middle forest, and from there you take over. The main character can only move around, jump, and do certain actions if they're near certain objects such as pull a lever or press a button. There isn't much of a story and it's mostly left up to interpretation but I'm sure that was done on purpose. If there's one thing that I can truly appreciate about this game it's overall look of the game and the atmosphere it's able to give off. The devs did such a great job making you feel alone as you travel throughtout the game. They did a good job making me feel anxious and even scared as I went through some levels. HOWEVER this is game is far from a masterpiece, it isn't perfect. I was enjoying the game very much until the later half of the game when it changed its approach on level design. They start introducing new gimmicks such as gravity which really put a damper on the game for me personally. It wasn't difficult, but it didn't mesh well with what the game did so well in the first half.I got my enjoyment out of one playthrough which lasted me about 3.5 hours. I don't feel the need to go back for another playthrough unless I want to get the achievements or eventually forget how the scripted events go. I would recommend getting this on sale unless you are 100% positive that you will do multiple playthroughs for this game since the game is a bit on the short side for 10 dollars.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Limbo ReviewFrom Wikipedia: "In the theology of the Catholic Church, Limbo (Latin limbus, edge or boundary, referring to the "edge" of Hell) is a speculative idea about the afterlife condition of those who die in Original Sin without being assigned to the Hell of the Damned."Are video games an art form? Limbo is one of those games that can answer such questions. It combines gloomy black and white visuals, low volume ambient soundtrack and chilling sound effects to produce an unforgettable experience that stays with you, much longer than it lasts. You are a young boy who wakes up in a forest, without knowing anything about your identity, where you are, where you come from or where you are going. You walk alone in the shadows, facing creatures and meeting other children along the way. The road ahead is tough and you must solve many puzzles, with the use of your brain and reflexes to keep going. There are no dialogs or cut scenes in this game, yet the storytelling is much greater than many other games. But there is death.  So much death. You will die many times in order to figure how to solve some puzzles or just to see the animation in every case. The puzzles start simple and they get more complex as you approach the ending. Oh, the ending! What an unusual way to end a game and spur so much debate over the meaning! Let’s just say, abrupt beginnings lead to abrupt endings…

												I wanted to play this when it came out, but couldn't due to the fact that I don't have an Xbox360. Needless to say, I was thrilled when it finally came out on PC. For those that don't know, Limbo is a dark (literally and figuratively), eerie puzzle game masquerading as a platformer. You play as a boy who navigates through a series of creepy environments, trying to stay alive while solving lots of clever puzzles along the way. To say more would ruin the experience, so I'll just leave it at that. This is, simply put, one of those unbelievably unique games that MUST be played by anyone who believes that gaming can be an art form in addition to just being good old fashioned entertainment. The experience may last only a few hours, but it will stay with you a lifetime...

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
 Limbo  Child Death Simulator 2011-2016 What is it?  A dark and brutal 2D puzzle platforming game. Gameplay:  Puzzles are smart and rewarding but can be frustrating, they are very trial and error based. Often using physics very well. Story:  The story is not told via cutscenes or dialog, a lot of it is for you to figure out from the occurances and backgrounds of the game. Controls:  The controls can be rather annoying at times on the keyboard, but would probably play better with a controller. Aesthetic:  The style of this game is beautiful, the black and white colour palette is pleasing to look at and also adds to the dark, unknowing atmosphere of the game. Graphics:  The 2D art of this game still hold up today (in my eyes) and the background looks great too, making you feel even more alone. Running/Bugs:  The game is easy to run and i did not come across any glitches, framerate drops or really any broken parts of the game. Verdict:  If 2D trial and error puzzle platforming and child death is your thing, then you sould definitley pick up this indie release. The death scenes will definitley scare younger audiences. 7/10 For me it was too brutal but I still enjoyed the intellegent puzzles and aesthetic.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												I dunno, maybe this just isn't my type of game, but I'd heard it was a good game, so I gave it a shot.If I had to give it a genre, it would be puzzle platformer, but it isn't good at either.  I felt the controls were laggy, and unresponsive, and the puzzles were lacking.  There were three types of puzzles: 1.The type of puzzle where you need to die in order to figure out what you need to do  2.the type where you know where you need to get to, but you can't figure out how  3. the type where you know exactly how to solve the puzzle, but you just can't do it fast enoughNone of these three were interesting to me, and left me frustruated with the game.  Maybe I was expecting too much, but I was disappointed at the complete lack of story.  it gave me no incentive to keep playing, and I felt like quitting multiple times during the short 2 hour length.In my eyes, the only redeeming quality of the game is the art style if it's a type you like.  I'm personally not a fan, but I can see how some would like it.  The music was completely unmemorable.If you can get Limbo for really cheap or free, it might be worth a playthrough, but definitely not at full price.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
 Very atmospheric 2D platformer with smart but difficult puzzles  Limbo is a traditional popular dance contest that originated on the island of Trinidad. A horizontal bar, known as the limbo bar, is placed atop two vertical bars. All contestants must attempt to go under the bar with their backs facing the floor. Whoever knocks the bar off or falls is eliminated from the contest. After everyone has completed their turns, the bar is lowered slightly and the contest continues. The contest ends when only one person can successfully "limbo" under the bar. (SOURCE WIKIPDEDIA.ORG) And this is exactly how I felt during the game. Every new stage, every new puzzle is raising the difficutly, but motivates you equally to finally finish this classic of the artsy gaming genre. What I liked   Very deep atmosphere with great colour scheme in black, grey and white  Smart puzzles that feel so rewarding after completion  Fair set back points  Native 3D Vision support  Length of the game is perfect for one session the weekend or in the evening after work  Audio fits perfect the graphic style and listening to sounds is important to solve puzzles What I didn't like  Sometimes to difficult to solve without a walkthrough guide / do not feel embarrassed to use one  SPOILER:  the end is definitely not rewarding for all the trouble you have gone through A  2D platformer that was rated overwhelming postive throughout the industry and deserves the designation of "classic" . Every gamer should have taken a look at it. Highly recommended. Not for full price. But pick it up on sale (5 EUR would be fair)

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Limbo, an amazing game with stunning design and atmosphere. With a mixture of adventure and puzzle, the game will catch you within a minute. There are no different difficulty settings, but the difficulty rises with higher levels. You will be dragged directly into the story without any information and no more informations are given while playing the game aswell, like a short-novel, but you will instantly try to figure out how to escape the mysterious and even more dangerous environment. You will be happy, if you solve a puzzle within the level and survive, but you can be afraid easily too while playing it. I was a bit surprised of the brutality in the game. Even in black and white you can easily feel the pain when you fail miserably and die one of several deaths. Be aware of the secrets and dangers, that are hidden in the dark. All in all one of the best Indie-games I played so far, but like the most titles kind of short.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												If you're looking for a very unique platformer, than this is the game to buy!The art style of the game is really what makes it unique, as the whole thing is eerie and dark, yet maintains an almost comical sense to it.  Although it may sound messed up, you'll find yourself laughing at your mistakes, which always seem to end in decapitation, obliteration or mutilation of some type.The game is short, it's very easily completed under 5 hours.  For this reason, I suggest waiting for it to be on sale or finding a coupon for it.  I understand that Limbo isn't meant to be some time consuming RPG, but it could have used a little more length.  Regardless, the gameplay that you will experience is nonetheless enjoyable, you'll just be left wanting more.8.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												A simple platformer with an eerily beautiful art style: monochromatic like a slient black and white film, flickering and dark. I loved this game. The puzzles are nigh impossible to solve without dying first but watching the boy get splatter and then figuring out how not to die again is half the fun. There are no voice overs or any backstory - you just wake up in a field and try  to navigate a small lost boy out of the dark and macabre world he finds himself in. It has a great sense of loneliness and isolation. The lack of music adds to this feeling. I liked that you are thrown to the wolves in the begining of the game and left to figure what to do on your own. Too many games hold your hand and don't trust you to figure things out without some boring 15 minute tutorial. Like most platformers, I'd recommend playing this  with a controller as a keyboard doesn't do it justice.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												A simple platformer with an eerily beautiful art style: monochromatic like a slient black and white film, flickering and dark. I loved this game. The puzzles are nigh impossible to solve without dying first but watching the boy get splatter and then figuring out how not to die again is half the fun. There are no voice overs or any backstory - you just wake up in a field and try  to navigate a small lost boy out of the dark and macabre world he finds himself in. It has a great sense of loneliness and isolation. The lack of music adds to this feeling. I liked that you are thrown to the wolves in the begining of the game and left to figure what to do on your own. Too many games hold your hand and don't trust you to figure things out without some boring 15 minute tutorial. Like most platformers, I'd recommend playing this  with a controller as a keyboard doesn't do it justice.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												This game is the reason I heard about steam and the rise of the indies for the first time ever. I saw a friend play part of it and I waited a few years to play it myself so that the experience would be new. The first half in the woods is absolutely brilliant, the mood, pacing and storytelling creates one of the best platforming puzzle solving experiences ever. It certainly makes the player fall instantly in love but the second half in mines and mechanical traps is more contrived and overall less fun. Still, get this beautiful mini-game when it's on sale! You can finish it in one sitting but there are a few secrets to find here and there for some extra replay value...PS: Controller is still not compatible on mac but you'll do fine without one.

												LIMBO is quite the game, the story being expositioned solely through gameplay. And oh boy, does the gameplay hold up. It's a 2D style platformer with abundant physics puzzles, which hit really close to home because I used to always play physics flash games. Anyways, another of the major selling points is the engrossing atmosphere, it being really well executed through soft sounds and a monochrome palette which goes easy on the eyes. Overall, I had a great time with the game and recommend it to anyone willing to pay a few bucks. My only complaint is that it wasn't longer, but I suppose dragging it out would reduce the level of quality.9.5/10

content:
Posted: April 6
												In terms of an eerie, unsettling atmosphere, LIMBO is fantastic. The puzzles too are nicely challenging and satisfying when you solve them. The achievements, too, reward the adventurous and patient player.The let down here is the game's unforgiving set-up. In terms of deaths, the game punishes you for being ignorant of things (traps etc) that you could not possibly have known until it's too late. The developers termed this "trial and death", but the extremely gruesome death sequences lose their impact after the nth unavoidable death on your first run through. This is especially prevalent in the second half, where the game loses a lot of the atmosphere and feel so beautifully constructed in the fist.I'd recommned LIMBO to anyone who enjoys the line between puzzle and platformer being toed, enjoys eerier, less "obvious" games, and above all, is extremely patient.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Spiders, Nightmares and ConfusionA Review of LimboLimbo is a rare gem of a 2D puzzle game. One of those games you can pick up on a lazy, boring Sunday afternoon and get lost in. It has a lightweight story to go with the puzzles, but don't let that put you off if you're not looking to commit to a story in the next game you play. Not paying attention to it won't take anything away from the game, mostly because you'll be wondering how the ♥♥♥♥ to kill that spider.£6.99 may seem a little pricey for a game which can be completed in a short amount of time if you put your mind to it, but then again it's also a timeless classic of game that you can return to many times and still be surprised by. I don't know if it's the dark, misty landscape of the world, or the inevitable and somewhat distracting gory deaths (don't take the term gory death lightly), but every time I've revisited this game, I always find I've forgotten how to solve the more complex of the puzzles, a valuable characteristic for a game, as it lures you add yet more chunks of your day to the total game play time.The game's controls are very simple, arrow keys to move around; with the up key allowing you to jump and grab on to chains, or climb up the sides of crates. Crates play quite a vital part in solving puzzles and can be dragged around by holding control when next to them, but be warned, they are just as susceptible to large, spinning blades as your characters limbs are.Overall a brilliant game. I'm sure if you dug around for long enough you could find a problem with it, or an aspect which you don't like, but they most certainly aren't obvious which is enough reason for me not to go looking for things which would ruin an otherwise fantastic game. If £6.99 sounds like too much for you, give the steam demo a shot and see if you change your mind, and, well, if that doesn't help, maybe pick it up in the steam sales.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												If you're looking for a very unique platformer, than this is the game to buy!The art style of the game is really what makes it unique, as the whole thing is eerie and dark, yet maintains an almost comical sense to it.  Although it may sound messed up, you'll find yourself laughing at your mistakes, which always seem to end in decapitation, obliteration or mutilation of some type.The game is short, it's very easily completed under 5 hours.  For this reason, I suggest waiting for it to be on sale or finding a coupon for it.  I understand that Limbo isn't meant to be some time consuming RPG, but it could have used a little more length.  Regardless, the gameplay that you will experience is nonetheless enjoyable, you'll just be left wanting more.8.5/10

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
Product received for free
												This game won the VGX Award for Best Independent Game in 2010 and the reason is obvious as soon as you start playing. This may be the most enjoyable immersion I have ever experienced in gaming. The use of silence is perfect, and whilst it's innovative for its year, it covers the traditional, subtle video-game learning curve in a very interesting way.Whether you're focused at it or not, eventually you get involved with the story (because there's a story being told) with the right amount of vagueness and beauty to make you think of theories of what really happened to the poor boy.In summary, a masterpiece. The only downside (and it's very minor) is the awkwardness in controls at certain points, which don't respond exactly like I was expecting them to and lead me to some frustration, specially when tackling the less-than-five-deaths achievement. Having said that, I had never felt so satisfied to get a 100% in achievements in my entire life. THAT S*** WAS BANANAS. Super hard.Anyway, try Limbo! Beautiful. 5/5

												This is an unusual game with elements of survival - horror.The game is in black and white, with lighting effects, film grain and a minimal amount of ambient sounds to create a tense atmosphere, which is often associated with the horror genre.The chapters are designed as abandoned misty place full of traps or simply abandoned neighborhoods of dangerous mechanisms, structures. With the death of the boy's body breaks into pieces! Sometimes found corpses and swarms of flies, hear sudden sounds that enhance the atmosphere of this wonderful game.10/10!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I love good indie games. And this one is good. Indie games basicly live from an idea, from originality. Limbo is a game that proves it. Black & white graphics, horror themed forest, little guy in the middle of nowhere and going through lots of puzzles. That's original, I bet you can't name a game like that that's already on the market.Graphics are again black & white, that's cool, along with the "vintage horror movie grain" it really adds an awesome atmosphere. Details are presented also really well, grass, sparks, dust, everything like that. You can't really find something bad about it.Gameplay is simple, 5 keys only. No skill needed there. But it's a puzzle game, it makes you think. So in lots of cases, you need to worry about the timing and figuring out how are you gonna get past each section.In my opinion, a big factor in any kind of game is replay-ability. This game doesn't really offer you that. Although there's an achievement where you have to complete the game without dying more than 5 times. But it's fun to not play it for a couple of weeks, forget about all the solutions and playing it again.Overall, it's one of the best indie games I've ever seen, it's beautiful to look at even after figuring out all the puzzles. I'll give it 8,5/10.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Do you like to get Frustrated!?  Nostalgic for the days of Battletoads & Double Dragon on the SNES!? You know, riding jet skis at a dangerously fast pace jumping off ramps only to die/land into bunch of colorful balls from a reject 90s Chuck E Cheese forcing you to throw your controller against the nearest wall with all of your concentrated rage…only to pick it up and try it again and again. Well, none of that beautiful 90s wacky-ness shows up in this game. 	This game brings the frustration but in a new Spooky-Eerie-Is that a Giant♥♥♥♥♥Spider-atmospheric nature. Almost a throwback to Pitfall with puzzles/obstacles except you will die. You will die a lot. And the deaths are dope!Ethereal moments will blow your mind, along with Looney Tunes Saw blades, Incredible Lighting, Isolation, crippling fear, and jolly Tarzan & Indiana Jones-like moments...This game should win the award: The “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award More reasons to dig on this:Blood, entrails, club with spikes in it…have you ever seen a huge♥♥♥♥♥brick fall on a guy?! Some crazy ghost action and weirdos who throw spears at you as you fun for dear life...And what really happened with the ending?!

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
Product received for free
												This game won the VGX Award for Best Independent Game in 2010 and the reason is obvious as soon as you start playing. This may be the most enjoyable immersion I have ever experienced in gaming. The use of silence is perfect, and whilst it's innovative for its year, it covers the traditional, subtle video-game learning curve in a very interesting way.Whether you're focused at it or not, eventually you get involved with the story (because there's a story being told) with the right amount of vagueness and beauty to make you think of theories of what really happened to the poor boy.In summary, a masterpiece. The only downside (and it's very minor) is the awkwardness in controls at certain points, which don't respond exactly like I was expecting them to and lead me to some frustration, specially when tackling the less-than-five-deaths achievement. Having said that, I had never felt so satisfied to get a 100% in achievements in my entire life. THAT S*** WAS BANANAS. Super hard.Anyway, try Limbo! Beautiful. 5/5

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Do you like to get Frustrated!?  Nostalgic for the days of Battletoads & Double Dragon on the SNES!? You know, riding jet skis at a dangerously fast pace jumping off ramps only to die/land into bunch of colorful balls from a reject 90s Chuck E Cheese forcing you to throw your controller against the nearest wall with all of your concentrated rage…only to pick it up and try it again and again. Well, none of that beautiful 90s wacky-ness shows up in this game. 	This game brings the frustration but in a new Spooky-Eerie-Is that a Giant♥♥♥♥♥Spider-atmospheric nature. Almost a throwback to Pitfall with puzzles/obstacles except you will die. You will die a lot. And the deaths are dope!Ethereal moments will blow your mind, along with Looney Tunes Saw blades, Incredible Lighting, Isolation, crippling fear, and jolly Tarzan & Indiana Jones-like moments...This game should win the award: The “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award More reasons to dig on this:Blood, entrails, club with spikes in it…have you ever seen a huge♥♥♥♥♥brick fall on a guy?! Some crazy ghost action and weirdos who throw spears at you as you fun for dear life...And what really happened with the ending?!

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												It's a rare thing, these days, to walk into a game with literally no idea what to expect.In the day and age of big cinematic trailers and youtubers playing the game for you before you even buy it, you've often got a good grasp of something before you even press play, not withstanding that many games cash in on very tired, but very trusted formulas.But LIMBO certainly caught me and many others off guard by throwing everyone in blind and introducing us to a world to both fear and admire. Similar to one of my all time favourite games, Another World, the game on it's face is basically a 2D/3D physics platformer puzzle game. But the theme, music, mood, atmosphere, everything else makes this game just an awesome thing to own. It will challenge you, satisfy you, make you wonder what the hell it is you're seeing, but also make you unable to look away.Go in blind and enjoy it.Love this game! <3

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6
												In terms of an eerie, unsettling atmosphere, LIMBO is fantastic. The puzzles too are nicely challenging and satisfying when you solve them. The achievements, too, reward the adventurous and patient player.The let down here is the game's unforgiving set-up. In terms of deaths, the game punishes you for being ignorant of things (traps etc) that you could not possibly have known until it's too late. The developers termed this "trial and death", but the extremely gruesome death sequences lose their impact after the nth unavoidable death on your first run through. This is especially prevalent in the second half, where the game loses a lot of the atmosphere and feel so beautifully constructed in the fist.I'd recommned LIMBO to anyone who enjoys the line between puzzle and platformer being toed, enjoys eerier, less "obvious" games, and above all, is extremely patient.
