number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
Product received for free
												It's a rare occasion for a game to present itself in such a unique way and accomplish so much by just letting the player figure it out.Minimalistic albeit very pleasent art style accompanied with satisfying gameplay mechanics that don't do anything revolutionary but manage to keep you fairly interested have left a really memorable experience. I'm not a huge fan of puzzles games mainly because I get frustrated if a puzzle is overly complicated and ridiculous. During my LIMBO playthrough, I never felt the need to check guidance for tutorials or instructions on how to 'beat' a certain puzzle. Puzzles despite not being very hard, still require a decent amount of perception regarding the stuff and objects around you. The game is relatively short, and it kinda ends abruptly, but it definitely is a terrific experience that I'd recommend to anyone. Rating: 7.5/10 TL;DR: Combining interesting mechanics, various puzzles and minimalistic but charming art style, LIMBO will entertain you for a solid few hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
Product received for free
												You know, I have a lot of indie platforming side scrolling games that I either buy on sale or in a bundle somewhere and I just never really get around to. However, I am very glad that I finally got to LIMBO.It's a surprisingly dark, depressing experience that is light on content and story, but there's just enough there to form your own opinions of what the game is about in your mind. The game is 100% puzzles and platforming but the difficulty is nearly perfect in my opinion. Not too obtuse, or too simple, I had to exercise my brain cells quite a bit. People may be disappointed by the small narrative component, but I actually feel like this helped add to the game's mystery, which is further enhanced by the noir, film-grainy, black and white aesthetic that just allows your own imagination to run wild.If Call of Duty is a big bag of Nacho Cheese Doritos with a two liter bottle of Mountain Dew, and the Witcher 3 is  a Five Course hearty meal paired with Hennessy on the rocks, I would say Limbo is one of those delectable, indulgent, dark chocolate truffle desserts. Bitter, dark, and small, but ultimately a satisfying and enjoyable experience that has deeper layers of flavor to consider.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2013
												This game is an original masterpiece.  I was surprised, disgusted, drawn in, and found myself loving all of it.   The entire game is in black and white.  There is no music, only environmental sounds.  This silence coupled with the eerie atmosphere creates such a creepy, cautious feeling.  The puzzles are simple, clever, and dangerous.  Failure in some puzzles can create some twisted and sickening results.  The irony of an innocent-looking child lost within a dark and twisted and dangerous environment has never been crafted so beautifully as it has in LIMBO.  This one deserves two thumbs up.  I highly recommend it, but not to everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Product received for free
IF your brain is compatible with 2D games and able to solve some logical puzzles using laws of physics, THEN go for it. If you want to see something new and meet new game climate, then go for it.I LOVE the ATMOSPHERE and the MINIMALISM. The game has many original ideas and contains both: easy and hard challenges. Creators did all things the right way in my opinion.How to enjoy this game? In my opinion you should simply install it, turn on your sound and play it without reading anything. The dark room without other people is best for it. If you fail passing the chapter, then close the game and re-try it next day.I do NOT recommend using any tutorials. I do NOT recommend watching Let's Plays BEFORE beating the game for the first time! It may destroy the whole experience!I did ~85% of the game and I really enjoyed the WHOLE time. I had NO problems with controls, graphics, etc. It was so much fun after all those repetitive 3D multi-player games with (quite often, unfortunately) toxic communities. IF you play ONLY the newest 3D AAAAA+ SLI/Crossfire games with colorful explosions covering the whole screen, then well... you may not find this game so much fun.If you cannot or do not want to use your brain, then well... find another game.If you want to T.K./troll other players during multiplayer, then... I hope it is the only game in your library...Is that game 5 years old? Well, is anything wrong with that if the game is OK? At least you get no new dumb reason to buy a new PC...I would like to thank creators for doing the giveaway. I enjoyed using their product.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Verdict: Heartily recommendedLIMBO: sidescrolling monochromatic atmospheric mind-stimulating multisyllable-evoking treasure of a game.Buy it. Play it. Chuckle at its simplicity. Continue playing. Watch horrified as your little illuminated eyes close at unexpected dismemberment. Curse it for its merciless deviousness. Play some more. Die some more. Marvel in disbelief at the previously missed subtle hints that made the seemingly impossible obstacle suddenly inexplicably logical and simple to surpass. How did I miss that?! Hear the eerie echo of your glee maniacal laughter die off against the walls as you watch yourself being squished like a bug after skipping ahead from the last obstacle. Scream. Play some more. Wait, why is it getting light already? Spend your work day mulling over the last fateful steps in your journey. Surprise your boss by finishing that project early just to get back to try your theory on how to beat that last obstacle. Die some more. Overcome some more. Oh my.... I.. I think I.. really... I won?!PositivesPrice point: worth the current €10. If you pay this money for a full-feature movie where you complain about how the main character is disposed of, you should get at least the same playtime out of this, probably more, with no one to blame but yourself for the multitude of ways your character bites the bullet.Interface: proof positive that a great game does not need a complicated interface, or really, much of an interface at all. All works exactly as expected or as discovered after a bit of trying. Nothing superfluous. Checkpoints are saved automatically after each main obstacle, which is all that's needed. The Thomas Edison Path-to-Success exemplified: succeed by finding 1001 ways to fail. Every gruesome death will teach you something (if only that you just repeated the same stupid mistake). Learn and overcome.Replayability: if you are the type that doesn't look back once the end is reached, admittedly not much. For completionists/perfectionists: you *will* sink a multiple of the original playthrough time to go back from the top and try and get all achievements, especially to try finish it in under 5 deaths. Guaranteed.Negative:Game length: This may arguably be the weakest point of LIMBO. Even after all the achievements are done, you may find yourself wishing there was a next catacomb to explore, another monster to outrun, another trap to outwit. Who are these other kids so hell-bent on separating me from my limbs? Where did/do they go when they are not ending up in their own traps? What places did my sister visit, and devious traps survived, that I haven't seen yet? In other words: where's LIMBO 2? Please let me throw money at you?

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Limbo is a game in which the "story" is severely lacking. In the wake of Braid I remember quite of a bit of derision for how little there is plot-wise to this game. Regardless, as a game that coasts entirely on unique (for its time) art style and mood building, this is basically the perfect version of that game. It is a game that justifies style over substance by making that style brutal and dark. The puzzles are simple - you will have to die to complete some of them (this is partly the point), and if you want explanation that are explicit you won't get any. If you want an incredibly dark moody romp through a horror-scape forest, you'll get exactly what you're looking for. So - easy recommend at full price if you are looking for that , grab it on sale if you're just curious.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Limbo, n, pl > Supposed region between heaven and hell.in Limbo > not knowing an outcome of something you are powerless  to influence. Limbo, n, pl > West Indies dance in which the dancers lean backwards to pass under a bar.Ok so this game has nothing to do with the latter meaning of this word, but this game would have to have been THE most enjoyable indie side scroller game ever for me... the dark, sinister & spooky environment is just perfect and the sound, which is of high quality, is perfect for full immersion... The game begins with you waking up and that's it... no tutorial, no story, no talking, no clue... the only thing you know ito do, is to go that way ----->But don't fret with the lack of instruction or story... it's absolutely PERFECT and with very simple controls that even my dead great granny can master...As you play, you constantly ask yourself...'What the #@!*% am I doing here???', 'how the #@!*% did I get here?', 'am I looking for something in particular?' and of course the most frequently asked question of all... 'WTF???'Don't be fooled by my recorded hours as an inexperience to review... i owned this game on xbox live from day one, I also bought a hard copy for PC 2 years ago and I just tried entering the code into steam two days ago and it worked... I have finished this game several times and including now as I write this review... It is a very short game, it only took me like 2 hours and 50 minutes, BUT... that's because I knew every puzzle, when you first play it, it should last for about 5-6 hours, anything less and you need to turn that difficulty up...The puzzles are magnificent, and you often find yourself over thinking and dying more...and when you finally solve it, you could totally b1tch slap yourself for not solving it sooner... This whole game was very well thought out, this game is definitely worth between $10-$15USD, just because the artwork, style, sound and gameplay are brilliant, for those that want value/replayability for your money, you should probably turn elsewhere or wait till this game is $5... This game is only for those REAL gamers that appreciate true art over the whole bang bang pow pow...I give this game a 9.5 out of 10, it loses half a point because I want MOOOOORRRREEEEEEALSO... I highly recommend playing this game completely stoned, coz you'll just trip out hard and you'll concentrate so much that you'll be unaware of the puddle of drool at your feet (I lean forward when i concentrate), it's even a good drinking game by yourself OR with your friends (The way I played it is when ever someone dies they hand over the controller....and everyone smashes down a SHOT of rum!!)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Verdict: Heartily recommendedLIMBO: sidescrolling monochromatic atmospheric mind-stimulating multisyllable-evoking treasure of a game.Buy it. Play it. Chuckle at its simplicity. Continue playing. Watch horrified as your little illuminated eyes close at unexpected dismemberment. Curse it for its merciless deviousness. Play some more. Die some more. Marvel in disbelief at the previously missed subtle hints that made the seemingly impossible obstacle suddenly inexplicably logical and simple to surpass. How did I miss that?! Hear the eerie echo of your glee maniacal laughter die off against the walls as you watch yourself being squished like a bug after skipping ahead from the last obstacle. Scream. Play some more. Wait, why is it getting light already? Spend your work day mulling over the last fateful steps in your journey. Surprise your boss by finishing that project early just to get back to try your theory on how to beat that last obstacle. Die some more. Overcome some more. Oh my.... I.. I think I.. really... I won?!PositivesPrice point: worth the current €10. If you pay this money for a full-feature movie where you complain about how the main character is disposed of, you should get at least the same playtime out of this, probably more, with no one to blame but yourself for the multitude of ways your character bites the bullet.Interface: proof positive that a great game does not need a complicated interface, or really, much of an interface at all. All works exactly as expected or as discovered after a bit of trying. Nothing superfluous. Checkpoints are saved automatically after each main obstacle, which is all that's needed. The Thomas Edison Path-to-Success exemplified: succeed by finding 1001 ways to fail. Every gruesome death will teach you something (if only that you just repeated the same stupid mistake). Learn and overcome.Replayability: if you are the type that doesn't look back once the end is reached, admittedly not much. For completionists/perfectionists: you *will* sink a multiple of the original playthrough time to go back from the top and try and get all achievements, especially to try finish it in under 5 deaths. Guaranteed.Negative:Game length: This may arguably be the weakest point of LIMBO. Even after all the achievements are done, you may find yourself wishing there was a next catacomb to explore, another monster to outrun, another trap to outwit. Who are these other kids so hell-bent on separating me from my limbs? Where did/do they go when they are not ending up in their own traps? What places did my sister visit, and devious traps survived, that I haven't seen yet? In other words: where's LIMBO 2? Please let me throw money at you?

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
Brought to you by the minds at Playdead, LIMBO is a bleak puzzle-platforming title that follows the bizarre trials of an unnamed adolescent as he journeys through perilous territories. Though the boy is simplistically presented, portraying no characteristics of audio cues, and the puzzles require much experimentation to achieve completion, the story it has to tell is engaging, as the protagonist perils through increasingly difficult struggles that occur subsequent to each other in a search for his lost sister.Here are a few items that I enjoyed about LIMBO:Gameplay - LIMBO holds a striking comparison to other Indie titles when it comes to the control layout: it is entirely straightforward. As you may or may not have experienced in prior games, this title utilizes the directional keys for basic movement-with down allowing your character to drop down and grab onto a ledge-, the Space Bar to jump, and the Control key to interact with objects and the environment itself; others have stated that this is much more fluid while playing with a plug-in controller. This painless layout aides the player in not forcing them to have to remember too many needless actions; if the controls could be remapped, a player could even be able to play it with one hand. In summary, the controls are of simple design for a simple game. As described previously-without revealing too much in terms of story progression-the player directs the young boy through treacherous territories, which prompts the solving of intricate puzzles. These stages-numbering twenty-four in total-generally require the player to test the mechanics in a ‘truth and error’ approach, unless applied thought is given to the situation for a considerable amount of time prior to action. A decent reaction time is necessary for certain portions since platforming is included into the general mechanics, which can be somewhat frustrating and rewarding due to the intense precision specific stages necessitate.Atmosphere - LIMBO is very black and white in terms of its color palette in that it is literally variants of black and white (if you have read my previous reviews, you know that I am not permitted to make jokes due to the overall lack of comedy involved, hence this current display.) This helps to depict the grim depth of this title’s occurrences, as well as developing tone that is not distracting from the gameplay. Even the game’s playstyle is murky since the protagonist’s death is intended to remind the player what they had done wrong in a specific segment and as an indication of how the level’s mechanics are set. The game shifts seamlessly between transition periods with minimal loading and intractable events. Hence the end of the game, which directly transfers into the beginning and causes the player to feel as though the protagonist’s ordeals are hopeless. Throughout, however, you may just become attached to said protagonist as though his struggles become your very own. The protagonist portrays no vocal characteristics, though the background effects add enough ambience to compensate for this.TL:DR - For those with keen senses in regards to game mechanics, you will find LIMBO to be trivial yet enjoyable. This title is a deep, brooding tale with no words and only atmosphere to speak its demented thoughts. It is a relatively short title that can be frustrating at times but is worth its cost as an experience. Though the protagonist does not and cannot outwardly portray his ideals, you will surely fight for him to learn of his sister’s fate. You will learn much as a player and an adventurer, but do not lose hope in LIMBO. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												I'll start off by saying that this is one of my favourite games ever. Behind a rather linear 1,5 hour-long 2D puzzle platformer lies a masterpiece with a story of highly emotional background and astonishing aesthetics. I won't go into detail regarding the story, but the things that make this piece of art a game are solid. Gameplay mechanics are intuitive and sometimes provide a challenge (at least the first few playthroughs), the controls are fluid and responsive (I'd recommend a controller but keyboard will do just fine as well), visually the game looks very atmospheric and grim and the sound design lacks music, which is a good thing, since you're immersed by the cold-sounding ambience of the world of LIMBO. The game had many discounts already and you're likely to get this game for a single dollar. Get it. It's perfect. 10/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Limbo is a beautifully stylistic and well-made puzzle platformer. The silent and bleak atmosphere is expressed very well and the movement feels natural. It’s a very relaxing and ambient game, and However, I did have my problems with the game.GameplayLimbo is a puzzle platformer, but neither part was exceptional. The platforming is mostly bland, and, even with the introduction of new and interesting features, still seemed lacking for the most part. The main character is slow and cannot sprint, making getting from point to point tedious and boring, especially with the music-less bleak scenery and atmosphere. The puzzles themselves aren't that difficult, but they are tedious and require a lot of waiting usually. Waiting for the bolder to roll, waiting for the light to swing back, waiting for the platform to move, etc. Everything just moves so slow in this game. In addition, you die a lot. This isn't bad considering the theme and mood of the game, but its irritating in relation to the puzzles.  Although the respawn points are very generous with their frequency, the puzzles are slow and repeating the same puzzle multiple times can be frustrating. There’s a lot of auto scroll or waiting on things out of your control, and often can be failed in a simple mistake, making repeating the puzzle multiple times feel boring and unnecessary when you already know what to do. StoryThere’s not much of a story to this game, which is okay since the game is about Limbo, but for most of the game there isn't much drive to continue moving forward outside of finishing the game. The highlight of the game is the first third, where a giant spider is pursuing the character. This spider is threatening, brutal, and scary. It gives a lot of tension to the game, and really pushes the player forward to escape from it, but it is only present in the first third, and the rest of the game you are just wandering forward any real overarching threat or goal, and it just makes it less interesting. By no means is this a bad game. It’s a cheap, short, interesting game that does its unique aspects well, and I don’t regret taking the time to play through it, but at the same time I didn’t find anything really special about it that makes it stand out as a game other than its cool atmosphere and style. Is it worth the price, yeah? Did I find it that enjoyable, not really.

												All game developers stuck in a rut on how to make games should be locked away in a room and forced to play this game start to finish. Shouldn't take them more than a few hours and at the end of their session, the realization that it is possible to make a good, enjoyable game without always relying on ridiculous explosions, cliche chase sequences, dumb 'bro' side characters and more explosions. Sometimes, less really is more.So, should you buy this game? Well it is certainly not the most mind bending puzzle-platformer ever created, but if you like simple, enjoyable-yet-slightly-frustrating ambient games, then you really can't go wrong with Limbo. It's a decent buy for that loose $5 or so in your pocket. Now 'Add-to-Cart' and enjoy!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Limbo is something different, not your usual platformer. It adds a unique approach and a distinctive style to the platformer genre and it uses a dark atmosphere to create an unsettling environment. The gameplay is simple and the progression is continuous not level oriented, one puzzle leading to the other. The checkpoint system is great and the game is very forgiving when you fail something and die, be it a jump, a timed event or something else. You are respawned very close to the spot you failed at. Did I like it? Yes. Do I recommend it? Yes. Should you try it? Probably. It's something different and the overall experience is nice. One thing I found interesting is that it has no story nor any spoken, written or interactive description of any sort. Basically you are thrown into the game and you must figure out what your next step is, what is your objective and what are your available options. The game doesn't hold your hand at all and everything you do, you do on your own. The puzzles are not difficult although their difficulty level slightly increases towards the end. You can beat the game in under 4 hours first time around without knowing anything about it.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												I'd say this is one of those games you either love or hate. Personally, I loved it. I can't, however, see any reason whatsoever to spend $10 on this game. It's dark and tricky but the length of gameplay kills the price tag. Steam has me registered with 111 minutes on Limbo. I'd say a good 30 minutes of that, if not more, was registered while I was paused, doing things around the house. When I got to the end, I figured I had just completed the first chapter. Nope, no more story. If you've played the demo and like it then wait for it to go on sale. I'd say $3 is reasonable but I can't in good conscience recommend you spend any more than that on it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												What can I say about Limbo that has not already been said.  It Dark, disturbing at points, atmospheric, beautiful and enchanting.  It is easy to play but engaging at all times, presents puzzles to you but not obviously as a puzzle.  The main character is childlike but the world is harsh.  The story is subtle but evolves perfectly as the play and leaves you with questions.This game should not be remade, changed or even have a sequel. It stands on its own in many respects and just is.If it was £30 it should still be bought and played, just so that you can say you were there when it happened. I have been playing games since pong and there are many games that I am proud to be able to say I was part of at the time of their breakthrough.  Limbo is one such game.  So much so that I have ordered the special edition on Amazon, just because I want to be able to hand it to my children when the time is right.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Limbo is a puzzle platformer that will keep you on your toes until the very end as you regularly encounter unfamiliar obstacles.  The controls are minimal and the puzzles aren't terribly difficult to solve, making the game inviting for people of all ages.  The game is masterfully designed and animated.  From the very beginning you will feel immersed in the strange dark world of Limbo.  The story is not very long, and there is not much replayability unless you want to go for all of the achievements.  Keeping this in mind, Limbo remains one of the best indie games on the market.  I highly recommend adding it to your collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												LIMBO is an indie/adventure puzzle-platform video game, the first released title brought to us by the Danish developers Playdead. While the game itself was first released in July 2010 as an exclusive title on the Xbox Live Arcade, Playdead decided to re-release the game on other platforms after the Xbox exclusivity had ended. This meant that PS3 and PC players could get their hands on this amazing title after all. The developers never stopped there as they continued to release the game on other platforms such as OS X and Linux in 2012 and eventually even for the PS Vita and iOS in 2013. By continuously expanding the platforms this game can run on, the developers show us that they are proud of their first title and rightfully so.SettingsYou wake up as a nameless boy, who I named George, in the middle of a dark and eerily forest. There is no explanation to how this boy got here, nor what his tasks are, so the start of the journey leaves you with an infinite amount of questions. If you don’t feel sorry for this young boy at first, you will certainly feel more pity towards this adolescent adventurer as the story advances when he comes across human characters who would rather have him dead then be helpful or died of unexplainable reasons. Other creatures are also lurking in the forest, such as giant spiders who enjoy spiking this poor boy with their legs. The end has us bringing the boy to a girl, presumably his missing sister when the game abruptly ends leaving us with yet more questions.GameplaySince LIMBO is a 2D platform video game, you can only steer the boy left or right, jump up, climb on ledges and up or down ladders and ropes. There is also an action-button where you can push or pull objects which are mostly part of a puzzle. Those who find more joy by playing with controllers are in luck since the Xbox Controller works perfectly. The graphics are dark and grayscale to provide more depth in the scenery. The sounds are kept at minimal, which leaves you with a setting that is both stunning and alarming. If your spider-senses aren’t tingling with this game, you sure are one hell of a cold-blooded player. At some point you may find yourself laughing hysterically, if you are evil-kindred that is, when you hear the splash-sounds the game creates when you’ve killed a creature or unkind humans. Since you will not always understand what you need to do to solve a puzzle, numerous amounts of deaths is inevitable. These horrifying deaths are accompanied with gruesome sounds and images of the boy being dismembered or beheaded. As if the creepiness of the settings wasn’t enough to cause panic in my mind.Final conclusionOverall this game has left me amazed with the fact that such a simple design and story can leave me with such an eerie feeling. It may be an older game but I would certainly recommend it for any player who enjoys puzzles and platform games.This review can also be found on nearlyenoughdice.com

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Over all I like this game, but I still have some mixed feelings about it. I'm not sure whether to recommend it or not because it completely depends on who the person. This game requires a LOT of patience as the puzzles become extremely challenging. There is much trial and error involved. I would sometimes spend a half hour trying to find a solution to a puzzle just to stumble into another one ten minutes later that stumped me. As you can imagine, I grew very frustrated. It did feel highly rewarding to over come each section and to finally figure it out, but there came a point where I just wanted to beat the game. There were a small handful of puzzles that I couldn't seem to figure out on my own no matter how hard I tried, and I was at the point where I was so eager to get it over with that I eventually looked up the solutions for a few of them. I hated to cheat, because there's no better feeling than figuring something out on your own, but I had just ran out of patience. And the demo, I felt, was very misleading. I was given the impression that it was all about platforming. There weren't any puzzles in it or at least, if there were, they were very benign and not noticeable. I get that games raise in difficulty, but the difficulty in puzzles had escalated to a shocking height to me. I will give it a lot of credit though. The puzzles are extraordinarily clever and well thought out. I haven't seen a game where the puzzles were designed so great, except for Portal. And maybe the problem lies in me. I have never enjoyed puzzles that much. I have a lot of patience in life, but not much in puzzles. You're also thrown right into the game, with no dialogue or spoken plot or cutscenes or instructions. For the most part, it's executed well, but I was upset to know that I had to actually look in the options menu at the controls to see that ctrl was the action button, mostly to pull and push things which is a large part in this game. I will still recommend this game, if only you are prepared for the difficulty. It looks to be a simple game, and the demo makes it out to be a simple game, but be prepared to invest more time into it than expected, to die a load more than expected, and possibly even to look up a guide when stuck.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2012
												I thoroughly enjoyed Limbo. It starts out eerie, moves into creepy, then becomes downright disturbing before returning to simply eerie through a series of increasingly challenging platforming puzzles. Death is frequent and humorously macabre, but checkpoints are also frequent so it is not frustrating. Towards the end the puzzles require some precision timing and fast reflexes. The whole game takes about five hours to complete and you'll be tempted to do it in one sitting (appropriately, there's a Steam achievement for doing just that ... and for dying less than five times, which is decidely harder). Bottom line, this is an indie game that lives up to all its hype.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Product received for free
												First off, I highly recommend this game. It's unique.This review is about my thoughts about the story behind the game and it may inculde some spoilers so you might do not want to read my review if you haven't played and finished the game. Note that the creators of the game, did not give a clear answer to what really happened to that boy and his sister and they wanted us to make our own theories about it. There are a lot of theories and we cannot take one of them as the correct one. Here's what I believe.Let's begin from the title. Limbo. That's a place where, based on some religions, after people die in real life, their souls go there for an unspecific period of time until God judge them and decide if they deserve to go into heaven or hell. So, by the time that the boy is in the limbo, we clearly understand that he has died.As the game begins, he wakes up in the middle of a forest looking for her sister. The reason why he is doing that, is because he doesn't understand that he's dead and he believes that he has lost her sister, so she's searching for her. We don't know how he died, but it's possible that he fell from their treehouse because his sister is kneeling in the last scene and there's a rope ladder besides her. Each area of the game represents his life. Starts off in a mysterious forest with spiders being his fear that he tries to overcome. Next "level" is the school life with other kids who were bullying the homeless guy. He then had a traveling job, traveling and living in motels and hotels and getting to new places and he eventually end up working in a factory. I also believe that the light worms that stick to his head represent the community who wants to control his brain and make him unable to reach his final destination. You continue the game passing through many obstacles just like you do in real life before you reach your purpose.In the end, he eventually finds his "missing" sister and sees her kneeling. The scene is not clear enough, but I believe that she was crying about his death and praying for him. Her sister doesn't turn around to greet him but she feels the presence of his soul and that's why she somehow gets upset. In that moment, the boy finds out that he's dead as he approaches his sister and the game ends abruptly. As I already said, there are a lot of theories that we can imagine and seem to "fit", but we don't really know what happened. That's all I believe, even if my theory has some flaws (didn't mention the Glass part).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												This is a beautiful game. The art style and music set a mysterious and sinister ambience. The puzzles are nicely varied so the game never feels like a grind. It is divided into zones which morph so naturally that you won't notice until you're right in the next one. The transition to the underground and watching all the cogs and mahinery feel as if you're delving to the inner workings of Limbo. While the puzzles are a little too easy and you will only be stuck scratching your head a few times, they are fun and satisfying to complete. The mute boy you play as is surprisingly endearing. Despite receiving no hints as to who he is, you feel compelled to protect him in this dangerous world and help him to his final goal. You will feel the blow of every brutal death as if they were your own. This game is a wonderful journey and well worth checking out.

												Dark, atmospheric, and delightfully morbid at times. LIMBO is a fun little puzzle platformer that'll test your brains and your timing.The artstyle is incredible, an entirely greyscale noir feel that adds to occasional spooky and horrific elements. Controls are crisp and animation is fluid.There isn't a "story" in the traditional sense, but you can probably interpret it as an allegory for childhood, growing up, and how our fears change as we mature, if you're into that sort of thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												LIMBO is a 2D platformer taking place in the very dark environments of Limbo ; the "speculative idea about the afterlife condition of those who die in original sin without being assigned to the Hell of the Damned" Wikipedia says. The gameplay is pretty darn classic if you ask me. You can interact with some items like boxes, ropes, etc. in order to solve puzzles. What makes LIMBO such a great game is its graphical style and most importantly its atmosphere. Even though it is a 'die-and-retry', LIMBO will definitely make your heart go insane at times. First you have the musics, which aren't much diferent from one another, but they do so much on your immersion. Secondly, the game not giving you any kind of defense or way out sometimes, your conscience keeps the idea that you are very vulnerable. Another topic I want to aboard would be the story, which by any means is NOT inexistent. You can Google that and get some speculations and hypotheses on that. The players actually make their own interpretation of this game's story, and that's what makes this game so mysterious and questionable. LIMBO is one good enigma you HAVE to get your hands on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
Product received for free
												A short dark puzzle platformer that is left up to interpretation. A piece of modern gaming interpretive art. Pros--Simple mechanics easy to pick up-Dark tones catch me off guard at times -Extra levels and challenges for more hardcore puzzle players-Story left up to your imagination-Relaxing yet keeps you on guardCons--Very short at around 3 hours-Nothing groundbreaking in terms of gameplayThough some people will read too much into this game making up their own version of events and symbolism that was not unintentional as there is no definitive knowledge aside from a boy trying to find his sister as he is in limbo. A quiet and relaxing game with little to criticize as there isn't anything new or anything to tell from the story. It seems like an experimental way to use gaming as an art. Whether you think it is a masterpiece or a simple little experimental game is left entirely up to you to decide. Worth a play just to find how you interpret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Over all I like this game, but I still have some mixed feelings about it. I'm not sure whether to recommend it or not because it completely depends on who the person. This game requires a LOT of patience as the puzzles become extremely challenging. There is much trial and error involved. I would sometimes spend a half hour trying to find a solution to a puzzle just to stumble into another one ten minutes later that stumped me. As you can imagine, I grew very frustrated. It did feel highly rewarding to over come each section and to finally figure it out, but there came a point where I just wanted to beat the game. There were a small handful of puzzles that I couldn't seem to figure out on my own no matter how hard I tried, and I was at the point where I was so eager to get it over with that I eventually looked up the solutions for a few of them. I hated to cheat, because there's no better feeling than figuring something out on your own, but I had just ran out of patience. And the demo, I felt, was very misleading. I was given the impression that it was all about platforming. There weren't any puzzles in it or at least, if there were, they were very benign and not noticeable. I get that games raise in difficulty, but the difficulty in puzzles had escalated to a shocking height to me. I will give it a lot of credit though. The puzzles are extraordinarily clever and well thought out. I haven't seen a game where the puzzles were designed so great, except for Portal. And maybe the problem lies in me. I have never enjoyed puzzles that much. I have a lot of patience in life, but not much in puzzles. You're also thrown right into the game, with no dialogue or spoken plot or cutscenes or instructions. For the most part, it's executed well, but I was upset to know that I had to actually look in the options menu at the controls to see that ctrl was the action button, mostly to pull and push things which is a large part in this game. I will still recommend this game, if only you are prepared for the difficulty. It looks to be a simple game, and the demo makes it out to be a simple game, but be prepared to invest more time into it than expected, to die a load more than expected, and possibly even to look up a guide when stuck.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
REVIEW: LIMBOLimbo is one of those games I had heard of, but never really put on the to-do list. It was only thanks to the generosity of a friend on Steam that I gained a copy to try and complete. But I haven’t been a fan of platformer games for some time, so would I enjoy Limbo?In a mysterious, monochrome world, a boy awakens in a dark forest. He sets out in search of his sister. But in his way are the various denizens of this world, from giant spiders to parasitic worms, and even other kids…There are four words that sum up Limbo: dark, artistic, minimalistic, and frustrating. Easily, the best part of the game is the presentation. It’s dark and moody, the graphics are just right for the macabre style, and the whole atmosphere is enhanced by a dark and appropriate soundtrack. Music and sound effects contribute to an eerie and intimidating atmosphere. It’s like Silent Hill, but, if anything, even darker. While at first glance it appears to be a kid’s game, it is anything but. I dunno what the rating is, but parents, THIS IS NOT FOR KIDS. This is a violent and dark game. Bleakly beautiful and beautifully bleak, but definitely not for kids.The gameplay is another matter entirely. It is hard, even by the gold standard of Nintendo platformers. The gameplay consists of avoiding death and figuring out how to progress by trial and error, or as the publishers once called it, ‘trial and death’. And you will die. A lot. In manifold gruesome fashions. But figuring out how to get by the latest obstacles or adversaries will give you a feeling of accomplishment. Unfortunately, I tended to get more frustrated than feeling like I accomplished anything meaningful.The game comes across as the illegitimate offspring of Silent Hill and Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysey (which, incidentally, was recently re-released on Steam). While the difficulty feels right for such a game, I just wish it wasn’t quite so hard. And the payoff in the minimalist story doesn’t quite work.That being said, Limbo is pretty good. I like it mainly for the presentation more than the gameplay, but the gameplay itself has its own charms. It’s just a touch too hard for my liking…RATING: ***½

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Limbo is an Inde Puzzle Platformer that is mostly standard in the sense of its mechanics (aside from a couple of shiny moments in the "late game"), but that has a strong point in its artistic choice and the way that the whole aesthetic of it is. It is a very interesting idea that I haven't seen in a lot of other games of this class (if at all really, I can't remember any other game that has done that before).The mechanics of it, as I said, are very standard in comparison to any other puzzle platformer: you jump, you move stuff around, you try to find a way to keep moving forward and not to fall to your dead. The interesting thing about the game comes to play when you are confronted with some of the "enemies" of the game, but then again it is more of a time pressure in the puzzling than an actual fight against the AI of the game. Other special things that might happen in the game that changes the mechanics a little bit are some of the puzzles (I cannot explain them without spoiling a bit of the game though).The game can be completed very fast. I finished it in about 3 and a half hours. I did not finish it to a 100% because that includes looking for little "light bubbles" around the world that are meant to be collectables or achievements, but these do not affect the game in any way. And again, I cannot imagine that finding all of them might extend the game all that much. The game itself in a mechanic point of view is okay. Maybe a little bit about average, but not much more than that. Challenging at moments and has some interesting ideas. You can be sure that you won't get trough a whole are without dying a couple of times, but it has nothing to do with skills, it has to with the game being a♥♥♥♥♥♥and setting you up to some traps you CANNOT see coming at all. I guess dying is just a part of the game, which actually makes sense considering the artistic view of it.The artistic view and aesthetic of the game are the most attractive elements of this game. The way I would describe it is a black and white world (light and shadow kind of thing) that looks beautiful, but has a creepy and impressionistic element to it. It made me feel a little bit uncomfortable at some points because of the impressionistic nature of the art style. It is not "gore" in any way, but it is something that get's close to it in a 2D shadow-like graphics. Nothing to worry about, though; just a dark game. The world is very well made and it pays attention to little details, which is weird considering that you are basically seeing shadows of the world in a 2D view. A very good thing that I have to point out is that the game makes a very good work of letting you know what is actually a platform you can jump on and what is just a part of the background/fordground.There is a story element to the game that, as far as I am concerned, is left to free interpretation throughout the whole game and up to the very end as well, not giving you any answers to any of your questions. Where are you? What/who are you looking for? Why is there other people here? The game has no dialogue at all, but it manages to get across just as much story as it wants to, leaving you with just enough questions for you to keep pushing forward and looking up theories in some forums after you have finished the game.Warts and all, this game is good. It is an experience that I enjoyed. Short and simple, but worth some of your time. Get it if you care more about story than about mechanics.7.5/10

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Quick Breakdown: Limbo is a beautiful looking puzzle platformer, whos biggest appeal is its art style and ambience.Length: 3-4 hoursScore: 7/10Full Review: Limbo is a fairly simple and straight forward puzzle platformer. You play as a young boy, traversing through limbo to rescue your sister. You’re simply thrown into the game with no real indication of what is going on, and the story doesn’t really develop past that.But let’s talk about the gameplay itself, as a platformer it’s pretty simplistic, there aren’t a whole lot of tricks to master, nor do you really even need to master any. It’s not a game about pixel perfect platforming. Nay, it places greater focus on its puzzles. While there are a few tough puzzles throughout the game, most are able to be solved in a fairly reasonable time frame. Long enough to make you think and feel satisfied once you do solve it, but not so long as to become frustrated with the game. More importantly the puzzles are fun to solve, and the platforming is enjoyable.Now for the main attraction of Limbo, the wonderful looking art style and it’s excellent atmosphere. Limbo has a simple black and white art style that frankly looks fantastic. It’s nothing fancy, but it’s a pleasure to look at.	The art style plays a large part in helping create the wonderful, bleak, atmosphere of the game. There’s a general sense of loneliness, despair, and death hovering in the world of Limbo and pervading throughout the game. Music is used sparingly, occasionally flaring up to indicate danger and heighten the tension, and it helps contribute to the ambience of the game.My main criticism of the game is the lack of anything useful in the options menu. Limbo is a fairly simple game, so it’s not like it needs a bundle of configurable settings, but it lacks options to adjust anything but the brightness. The main thing I would have liked is to have been able to remap the controls, as I much prefer using WASD to move than the arrow keys. Thankfully the controls and gameplay are simple enough that this ends up being a fairly minor complaint, but it would still be a nice addition. (One can also use a controller to play, but as I don’t own one at this time I obviously haven’t used one).Nonetheless, Limbo is a rather fun puzzle platformer with a wonderfully bleak and depressing atmosphere to it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2012
												Is it possible to enjoy a game purely on an aesthetic level? "Limbo's" puzzles are perfectly fine. If you liked "Another World" or "Flashback" back in the day you'll probably enjoy Limbo's approach to puzzles (others who hate trial and error in gaming might pull their hair out though). But the puzzles, adequate as they are, are really just a pretext to look at the game, which I think, is one of the better looking I've ever played. With its stark black/white artwork, layers of film grain, and analog hiss the effect is a bit like the video game equivalent of a Guy Maddin movie (Don't know him? Take 5 minutes and see: 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



. Of course it is a bit strange that a game would take the silent era of film as its "retro" model rather than, say, the 8 bit era of video gaming (there's something odd about using digital technology to so lovingly recreate the analog imperfections of another medium), but it's just so gosh darn pretty you don't have much time to think about how it doesn't make much aesthetic sense.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Considering the fact that we constantly have to upgrade our computers or buy new game consoles to just to play new games because of the intense graphics or sound or storylines, it's truly refreshing to not only see a minimalist game, but to see one that does it so astonishingly well. The minimal sounds and visuals create the perfect eerie mood, and the minimal story allows everyone to take something unique away from it. The physics are spot-on and the puzzles are simple while still very challenging. I don't think we'll ever see a game quite like Limbo again, because I can't imagine a future game accomplishing these things at this level of quality without actually ripping it off.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												This is an amazing game. Creative and decently challenging puzzles, and a backstory that has you still wondering.***Spoiler***How about this theory? He would always play at the tree house with his sister. One day climbing down the ladder, it broke and he fell along with it, or he may have slipped. The beginning starts off with his uncertainty and fears. Hence the giant spiders, and the other kids you encounter could either also be in limbo or represent his peers as bullies which explains why they try to harm him. The Hotel, and machinery could be because him and his sister lived near a growing city heavy with construction. At the end, he is trying to find his sister because she is the one he holds dearest and always felt comfort playing in the the tree house with his sister and she straightens up because what she was looking at was your unconscious body and felt your presence behind her as if you are watching over her. Other theories end with the same thing, but he could have been in a car crash. He may have fallen through a window of a hotel, or even a hotel under construction because at the end you see the hotel signs again and more saws. Just some things to consider.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Limbo is an Inde Puzzle Platformer that is mostly standard in the sense of its mechanics (aside from a couple of shiny moments in the "late game"), but that has a strong point in its artistic choice and the way that the whole aesthetic of it is. It is a very interesting idea that I haven't seen in a lot of other games of this class (if at all really, I can't remember any other game that has done that before).The mechanics of it, as I said, are very standard in comparison to any other puzzle platformer: you jump, you move stuff around, you try to find a way to keep moving forward and not to fall to your dead. The interesting thing about the game comes to play when you are confronted with some of the "enemies" of the game, but then again it is more of a time pressure in the puzzling than an actual fight against the AI of the game. Other special things that might happen in the game that changes the mechanics a little bit are some of the puzzles (I cannot explain them without spoiling a bit of the game though).The game can be completed very fast. I finished it in about 3 and a half hours. I did not finish it to a 100% because that includes looking for little "light bubbles" around the world that are meant to be collectables or achievements, but these do not affect the game in any way. And again, I cannot imagine that finding all of them might extend the game all that much. The game itself in a mechanic point of view is okay. Maybe a little bit about average, but not much more than that. Challenging at moments and has some interesting ideas. You can be sure that you won't get trough a whole are without dying a couple of times, but it has nothing to do with skills, it has to with the game being a♥♥♥♥♥♥and setting you up to some traps you CANNOT see coming at all. I guess dying is just a part of the game, which actually makes sense considering the artistic view of it.The artistic view and aesthetic of the game are the most attractive elements of this game. The way I would describe it is a black and white world (light and shadow kind of thing) that looks beautiful, but has a creepy and impressionistic element to it. It made me feel a little bit uncomfortable at some points because of the impressionistic nature of the art style. It is not "gore" in any way, but it is something that get's close to it in a 2D shadow-like graphics. Nothing to worry about, though; just a dark game. The world is very well made and it pays attention to little details, which is weird considering that you are basically seeing shadows of the world in a 2D view. A very good thing that I have to point out is that the game makes a very good work of letting you know what is actually a platform you can jump on and what is just a part of the background/fordground.There is a story element to the game that, as far as I am concerned, is left to free interpretation throughout the whole game and up to the very end as well, not giving you any answers to any of your questions. Where are you? What/who are you looking for? Why is there other people here? The game has no dialogue at all, but it manages to get across just as much story as it wants to, leaving you with just enough questions for you to keep pushing forward and looking up theories in some forums after you have finished the game.Warts and all, this game is good. It is an experience that I enjoyed. Short and simple, but worth some of your time. Get it if you care more about story than about mechanics.7.5/10

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Limbo is a puzzle game set in a black-white coloured world which tends to get harder and darker the more you progress. The controls are basic, so you can get started right away without a big learning curve.As I said, the puzzles you encounter get harder the further you are into the game, which is a good way to introduce the player into the type gameplay that Limbo offers and how the players can interact with the world and the environment.More about the puzzles; They are quite unique and the sometimes disturbing or gruesome solutions for them are not what you'd expect. This in combination with the perfect matching atmospheric audio (Which are even a must to complete some puzzles. Dont turn them off!) can/will give you some moments of scare. But that only makes the game feel more alive.The only thing that bothered me was the fact that you can not set the audio volume lower. The loud audio at some chapters of the game became pretty annoying a few times.Overall, this is a great game where you have to set your mind to. It is worth the price if you are into these kind of games. But even if you aren't. It is still an amazing game.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
REVIEW: LIMBOLimbo is one of those games I had heard of, but never really put on the to-do list. It was only thanks to the generosity of a friend on Steam that I gained a copy to try and complete. But I haven’t been a fan of platformer games for some time, so would I enjoy Limbo?In a mysterious, monochrome world, a boy awakens in a dark forest. He sets out in search of his sister. But in his way are the various denizens of this world, from giant spiders to parasitic worms, and even other kids…There are four words that sum up Limbo: dark, artistic, minimalistic, and frustrating. Easily, the best part of the game is the presentation. It’s dark and moody, the graphics are just right for the macabre style, and the whole atmosphere is enhanced by a dark and appropriate soundtrack. Music and sound effects contribute to an eerie and intimidating atmosphere. It’s like Silent Hill, but, if anything, even darker. While at first glance it appears to be a kid’s game, it is anything but. I dunno what the rating is, but parents, THIS IS NOT FOR KIDS. This is a violent and dark game. Bleakly beautiful and beautifully bleak, but definitely not for kids.The gameplay is another matter entirely. It is hard, even by the gold standard of Nintendo platformers. The gameplay consists of avoiding death and figuring out how to progress by trial and error, or as the publishers once called it, ‘trial and death’. And you will die. A lot. In manifold gruesome fashions. But figuring out how to get by the latest obstacles or adversaries will give you a feeling of accomplishment. Unfortunately, I tended to get more frustrated than feeling like I accomplished anything meaningful.The game comes across as the illegitimate offspring of Silent Hill and Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysey (which, incidentally, was recently re-released on Steam). While the difficulty feels right for such a game, I just wish it wasn’t quite so hard. And the payoff in the minimalist story doesn’t quite work.That being said, Limbo is pretty good. I like it mainly for the presentation more than the gameplay, but the gameplay itself has its own charms. It’s just a touch too hard for my liking…RATING: ***½

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Limbo is an Indie platform  melancholic game that extends beyond the casual indie games, when you first start it you dont see much talk arround the plot, in fact I had to see the reviews so I could find out what the game was about. Apparently, its about a boy who goes for a quest after his sister who fell  in the Limbo. All of the game is played on a grey, white and black environment so that we could get that a sad, creepy, melancholic visual experience. The fact is that when we reach a certain level we get bored with all thoose environments.The game offers us some great puzzle/platform challenges, but also gives us a slow and boring gameplay  which ruins all the emotion.I would recommend this game for those who truly love indie games, and for those who are looking for a different type of game.It wasn't execlly money well spent, actually, but since it was made by an independent developer, it's acceptable.Limbo had excelent scores on Metacritic and IGN, I think you should check some other reviews and watch some gameplays (without spoiler) before you buy the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												This is a beautiful game. The art style and music set a mysterious and sinister ambience. The puzzles are nicely varied so the game never feels like a grind. It is divided into zones which morph so naturally that you won't notice until you're right in the next one. The transition to the underground and watching all the cogs and mahinery feel as if you're delving to the inner workings of Limbo. While the puzzles are a little too easy and you will only be stuck scratching your head a few times, they are fun and satisfying to complete. The mute boy you play as is surprisingly endearing. Despite receiving no hints as to who he is, you feel compelled to protect him in this dangerous world and help him to his final goal. You will feel the blow of every brutal death as if they were your own. This game is a wonderful journey and well worth checking out.

												um... wow.  just wow.  A person playing this game for the first time is plopped right into the game with no explaination, the protaganist still asleep in a strange 2d silouette world.  it took me a while to figure out what to do, i would suggest to press "esc" and check options for the controls (i don't know why its in options, you cant change them...)  this game consists of many simplistic puzzles that require skill and exceptional timing, which are challenging and satisfying to solve.  in all honesty, the gameplay itself is nothing to be amazed over.  it's simple, and a little repetetive.  That is not, however, why i personally love this game, it has a wonderful ambience, and does a good job of making the player feel truely alone and hopeless.  the anamation style used is incredable for this purpose, and just to increase the intensity, no music plays during gameplay. very little sound at all realy.  the whole experience is truely one of a kind, and nigh unmatched.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												A decidedly dark twist on the classic puzzle genre.   It's very physics driven, with some of the traps being sprung by levers and see-saws, gravity switches, rope swings, and the like all come into play when you're rushing through Limbo to save your sister. The game is challenging, and can make you chuckle with a few easter eggs, but it lacks some replayability and doesn't have a story other than you're a boy looking for his sister. At about three hours (if you nab all of the achievements) the price to play ratio is a little steep if you grab it full price.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												I'll start things off by saying that I did have a hard time getting this game to work at first, which was a disappointment considering how much I was looking forward to playing it. The issue being that after installation, the application would get hung up on the "preparing to launch" dialogue box without actually launching the game.That being said, after quite a bit of research I discovered that many others were having the same problem as I was and came to the unfortunate realization that there were no actual solutions to be found. I immediately headed over to Playdead to contact their support team and to my surprise, they responded very quickly. Just to give you an idea because frankly, I think it deserves mentioning; I sent out my initial e-mail at 3:41am, to which I received a response at 6:17am, less than three hours later. Needless to say, I was quite impressed.The individual that contacted me seemed genuinely nice - as far as these things can be judged without speaking to the person directly - and found them to be friendly, concise and very helpful. I was provided a number of possible solutions and steps to take, along with clear instructions on how best to solve the problem.I'm not sure if the issue is the same for everyone, but if I were to make an educated guess based on the system requirements and my own experience, it seems Limbo throws an error if the Shader Model hardware utilized by your GPU is outdated. In order for this to work properly, the easiest thing to do would simply be to download the latest drivers for your particular video card. I also updated DirectX and made sure there were no pending updates for my system whatsoever, just to be on the safe side. With that out of the way, the problem I had was a thing of the past and wasted no time in booting up the game to see what I had been missing out on.My opinion may be a little biased given that I'm a sucker for these types of games but with that in mind, on to the actual gameplay...You start off in the middle of a somber forest filled with various dangers, obstacles, and good old-fashioned film grain effects, which I have to say were an interesting design choice; one that was quite beneficial as it added to the overall feel of the game. Within the first couple of minutes, you quickly discover that the concept and control scheme are simple enough, which is what you want for a puzzle-platformer.All you need are five buttons (four arrow keys and "Ctrl") on your keyboard: walk left, walk right, push/pull objects and climb ropes and ladders. That's all you get. Can't get much simpler than that, right? Well, I suppose you can, but that's beside the point. Don't let this fool you though because the game is quite challenging in certain areas as you brave the perils of various twisted environments as a young boy in search of his sister.The story elements present in LIMBO are subtle and left up to the interpretation of the player, inciting a great deal of speculation among fans as to what the boy's treacherous journey actually means. If your curiosity was strong enough to warrant a search of the game's plot you would have found out right away that there aren't any definitive answers, yet there are some clues and a general understanding regarding certain aspects of the story.There was no BGM to speak of like you would traditionally be expecting but rather just the subdued, ambient background noise that seems to fit the developer's intentions very well. The black and white tones and sparse lighting came together nicely and added a great deal to the experience. The effects seemed appropriate to the situation in which the player finds themselves and added to the atmosphere and immersion of the game to give it an eerie, haunting feel.One thing of note that I don't see or rather hear in a lot of games are that certain areas actually employ the use of auditory cues in order to progress. This is most prominent in the secret level, where the player must traverse an entire stage - that is somewhat longer than prior chapters -  in complete darkness. Do yourself a favor and crank up the volume before attempting this. Having a good headset or even a pair of speakers here will make your life a lot easier.The puzzles had an interesting curve and there was a definite, noticeable progression to the difficulty, which flowed exceptionally well and I felt kept things from getting tedious. At the same time, the puzzles weren't so easy as to induce a coma from mind-numbing boredom or hard enough that they would make you rage-quit or suffer for hours on end trying to solve them. LIMBO found the perfect balance between the two by providing enough challenge and stimulation that makes you want to play it again and again.All in all the game was quite fun. I've played through 3 times already collecting all the achievements and it still hasn't gotten dull. It has 39 chapters, not including the secret area, which may seem like it's a bit longer but is honestly on the shorter side of that spectrum. Start to finish I'd say it's possible to complete the game in roughly forty-five to an hour, give or take a few minutes; after you get your bearings on the first play-through that is. Keep in mind, however, this doesn't account for speed-runners, who I can only assume are capable of finishing in much less time.Bottom line is, Limbo is a simplistic, streamlined puzzle-platforming game that has a certain charm to it and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the genre or anyone else for that matter. It was well worth the effort it took to get the game working and after I had a chance to play it for myself, I have to say that all the hype surrounding it has not been exaggerated. LIMBO is a phenomenal piece of creativity, a credit to the indie community and the industry as a whole.

												Limbo is a relatively short but very worthwhile voyage. The game took me a little over 3 hours on first play-through but for more casual gamers should last a little longer. From the beginning you are thrown into a very dark depressing place with no real understanding of why you are there. The graphical style is beautifully creepy and the sound is second to none. Play with headphones turned up loud to get every rain sodden footstep and every sickening thud of the bear trap severing you in two. The puzzles are quite challenging requiring both skill and thought, with a great sense of achievement upon completion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2012
												Another Indie game that deserves all the praise it can get. LIMBO is original, dark (literally), and disturbing. What I especially love about this game is that the story is so vague that it allows you to draw your own conclusions about any questions you have about the game. Like "Why is the boy stuck in LIMBO?", "How did he in his sister die?",  "Does everything in the enviornment tie in together somehow?" Like I said it's all up to your interpretation. (You should see some of the theories on TVtropes.com). If you love puzzle platformers, or dark and disturbing piece of entertainment, I'd say give it a buy. Though if a vague story can take the fun out of a game for you stay away from this game, like I said the story is all about interpretation.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game is possibly the most unique game I have ever played. The search for a fun, mind-working, and HD side scroller has been going on for me for a while now. Well the search has come to an end. This game makes you think but it has more than just that. While it is simply black and white, its really really HD and is super smooth. The fact that there is no music is absolutly the right way to go. It makes it seem that much more unique and really adds to the mystery aspect of the game. They tell you nothing at the beginning, not even the controls. You dont know who you are, where you are, OR what you are doing. And let me tell you...I've never been more entertained with such a lack of information in my life. BUY. THIS. GAME.

												I would rate this a solid 8/10. I loved the rich tone that is set from the very beginning. This game is fantastically creepy and horrifying yet extremely intriguing. Who are you? Where are you? Why are you there? LIMBO is minimal in design and story, but it does not disappoint. The game itself is gorgeous. The puzzles are just challenging enough that you get frustrated but feel accomplished when you figure it out. I killed myself in ways I didn't even know were possible. My only gripe is the ending, but I think everyone interpretates it differently. Regardless, well worth your time if you enjoy unique puzzle platformers and games that have a strong ambiance.

												Want something to exercise your brains? Try Limbo.The game is very atmospheric puzzle/plat-former game. I found it to be very enjoyable for the most part but some parts were frustrating. It's not that the puzzles were hard, most of it made sense and you will find solutions easily. Performing it was the difficult part, like jumping on a very specific spot and a few millimeters off and you will fail. Reminds of the old Famicom/NES games. It doesn't have any deep story. You woke up in a forest and while exploring you found out that everyone and everything was out there to kill you so your main goal was to escape. The ending was one of those that left it for the players to decide it's meaning. You will play Limbo mainly for its puzzles.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Long story short: a great puzzle platformer!Details:The graphics style with its only two colors (black and white, and its mixing gray) is causing a very nice oppressive atmosphere. All animations are very detailed and smooth, in fact you can only see silhouettes. Depth is created with blur.Level transitions are fluent, no loading screens, which creates a nostalgic feeling. You think you can always go back from where you came from. In Fact you can't, as some geographical obstacles block the way back.Even though the main purpose of this game is to solve puzzles, which are using physics and differ in grade of difficulty, LIMBO also has a profound background story or at least events.First you have to defend yourself against a spider, and cut of three of its legs. Then it's fleeing, but catches you later on a webbed floor. As you escape the spider is following you again, and you head it to a small village. The people are not delighted of course, as the spider is killing them. So they also try to kill you, in return you have to kill them. Afterwards you also manage to escape from the spider, which is so hurt, that only one leg is left. To get further, you have to tear out also the last leg, and use the spider's body.Later you see that the people of the village are sometimes controlled by a worm, which causes them to walk into water and to drown. Again you have to use a dead body to complete your journey.Several times you try to reach a girl, but you are led away by a worm or cannot reach her.All these incidents are disturbing in some kind and thought-provoking.It's a lot of fun to get all hidden eggs, and find the hidden level.I completed the game on Linux, it was running perfect, even the XBox 360 controller rumbled.

												What can I say about Limbo that has not already been said.  It Dark, disturbing at points, atmospheric, beautiful and enchanting.  It is easy to play but engaging at all times, presents puzzles to you but not obviously as a puzzle.  The main character is childlike but the world is harsh.  The story is subtle but evolves perfectly as the play and leaves you with questions.This game should not be remade, changed or even have a sequel. It stands on its own in many respects and just is.If it was £30 it should still be bought and played, just so that you can say you were there when it happened. I have been playing games since pong and there are many games that I am proud to be able to say I was part of at the time of their breakthrough.  Limbo is one such game.  So much so that I have ordered the special edition on Amazon, just because I want to be able to hand it to my children when the time is right.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Limbo is a puzzle platformer that will keep you on your toes until the very end as you regularly encounter unfamiliar obstacles.  The controls are minimal and the puzzles aren't terribly difficult to solve, making the game inviting for people of all ages.  The game is masterfully designed and animated.  From the very beginning you will feel immersed in the strange dark world of Limbo.  The story is not very long, and there is not much replayability unless you want to go for all of the achievements.  Keeping this in mind, Limbo remains one of the best indie games on the market.  I highly recommend adding it to your collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												This is a beautiful game. The art style and music set a mysterious and sinister ambience. The puzzles are nicely varied so the game never feels like a grind. It is divided into zones which morph so naturally that you won't notice until you're right in the next one. The transition to the underground and watching all the cogs and mahinery feel as if you're delving to the inner workings of Limbo. While the puzzles are a little too easy and you will only be stuck scratching your head a few times, they are fun and satisfying to complete. The mute boy you play as is surprisingly endearing. Despite receiving no hints as to who he is, you feel compelled to protect him in this dangerous world and help him to his final goal. You will feel the blow of every brutal death as if they were your own. This game is a wonderful journey and well worth checking out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Limbo is an Indie platform  melancholic game that extends beyond the casual indie games, when you first start it you dont see much talk arround the plot, in fact I had to see the reviews so I could find out what the game was about. Apparently, its about a boy who goes for a quest after his sister who fell  in the Limbo. All of the game is played on a grey, white and black environment so that we could get that a sad, creepy, melancholic visual experience. The fact is that when we reach a certain level we get bored with all thoose environments.The game offers us some great puzzle/platform challenges, but also gives us a slow and boring gameplay  which ruins all the emotion.I would recommend this game for those who truly love indie games, and for those who are looking for a different type of game.It wasn't execlly money well spent, actually, but since it was made by an independent developer, it's acceptable.Limbo had excelent scores on Metacritic and IGN, I think you should check some other reviews and watch some gameplays (without spoiler) before you buy the game.

												I would rate this a solid 8/10. I loved the rich tone that is set from the very beginning. This game is fantastically creepy and horrifying yet extremely intriguing. Who are you? Where are you? Why are you there? LIMBO is minimal in design and story, but it does not disappoint. The game itself is gorgeous. The puzzles are just challenging enough that you get frustrated but feel accomplished when you figure it out. I killed myself in ways I didn't even know were possible. My only gripe is the ending, but I think everyone interpretates it differently. Regardless, well worth your time if you enjoy unique puzzle platformers and games that have a strong ambiance.
