number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												A beautiful, short platformer. Although it only uses a simple dark style, this creates a very special and unique atmosphere that is hardly ever seen in video games. Simply put, the artwork of the game is just awesome and I’m surprised at how much can be achieved just by using silhouettes. Playing through Limbo felt like discovering a work of art. Its puzzles are sometimes challenging, specially towards the end, but they don’t really become annoying at any point. The music is fitting, but what I liked the most is how well silence is used throughout the game. It really makes you feel lonely and lost. The biggest highlight of the game is, however, the appearance of the spider. Just seeing the way it moves sends shivers down my spine. It’s the kind of stuff that would have given me nightmares back in the day. Definitely one of the scariest and creepiest enemies in video games ever. Seriously, kill that thing with fire and bury it as deep as you can.   And last we've got the "story". Yeah… well, I’m not sure I really understand what the game is about, but that doesn’t mean I did not enjoy playing it any less. it's true that I felt kind of puzzled at the end of the game when I realized I didn’t know what was going on though. As it happens to be fairly short, I’ll gladly return to it at some point in the future and maybe then I’ll be able to propose a theory or two about the true meaning of the game... until then… well, just stay away from that six legged terrifying creature and enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Limbo is a phenomenal game. I was reading through both positive and negative reviews, and noticed that the negative review section complained that this wasn't a skill game, it was a trial and error game, and that there was no story. The story is obvious and is included in the title. A boy is thrown into limbo to save his sister. The rest of the story is for the user to piece together. It gives hints and clues throughout the entire game, and shows you what may be important, and what may not be important. It's amazing how much we can speculate. Onto skill, this game isn't as much of a trial and error game as people say. Once you understand how the puzzles in limbo work, you can begin to understand while looking at the puzzles and solve. Limbo is a captivating active visual and emotional experience, and I love it.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												At long last, one humble bundle gave me the oportunity to finally play this game, which i knew for years thanks to publicity in gaming and technology blogs.Sure as hell, this is a really good looking game. It plays like platforming games from 20 years ago (think first Prince of Persia), but the difficulty is not about reflexes and good timing, but about how you approach every part of the level, shall i say 'rooms'.The game consists in a series of puzzles, where one time you have to use a box to keep moving, and another time you have to deal with switches or monsters.Really rewarding, almost soozing, and amazingly beautiful.The bad side: you can complete the game in about 2 hours or so. Once you have done it, you are left with the achievements (which are finding hidden objects throughout the game), and a secret level, which is amazingly hard to finish, the best part of the game in my opinion.All and all, really good game, short, and without any replay value other than completing it without diying, or showing it to your friends, but without a doubt a really nice experience, suitable for a one sitting run down.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Limbo is a beautiful, atmospheric puzzle platformer with a hard edge. What story it has is largely implicit—the game contains no dialogue. You simply wake in a dark wood, apparently a child, and set off to explore the dingy place in which you find yourself. But the genre of the game is certainly horror, though without most of the usual tropes. You are fragile—easily hurt, unable to swim, essentially defenseless—in a hostile and trap-ridden place. You will die many times. And the game does not divert your gaze from your death but rather renders each different mode of your demise in somewhat disturbing detail. The artistic style of the game simultaneously keeps this from being too macabre and contributes greatly to the eerie atmosphere. The game's graphics are entirely silhouettes in shades of grey. Yet the landscapes and objects feel very detailed. Beautifully done lighting effects give the impression of a layered world mostly in shadow. All this makes for a beautiful noir environment well worth admiration in its own right. This game is more immersive with black and white outlines than much I’ve played that had expensive 3D-graphics.A subtler strength of the game is the way its physics feel naturalistic—you are acutely aware of the weight of objects and the force of gravity.  I doubt that the game’s engine is particularly remarkable in this regard, it’s an aesthetic effect. Great attention has been paid to the visual details of motion. But I think it also comes from player movement: in many games you play as a character with outsized physical capabilities. Even in shooters and platformers where such isn’t part of the story your movements are subtly superhuman (think of the lateral jumping featured in most platformers). Not here. Here you have a painfully tiny lateral jump and a rather slow top speed. Here objects don’t just slide easily into place but are dragged only with great effort.The largest complaint I had with LIMBO was that it was too short. Though the puzzles were good, and admirably varied, not too many were very difficult. If one is adept at this sort of thing one could easily complete the game in just a few hours. They are an excellent few hours though. The puzzles are crisp, things to be grasped, not just fiddled with. For a little while LIMBO takes you to an unsettling, engrossing otherworld. And I’d very much like to visit again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Limbo manages to prove what many have started to question over the last few years. Are video games art? If you want my opinion, I honestly think they are, but not all of them. That said, Limbo is definitely one of those games that manages to push the boundaries of standard puzzle platformers and great looking little games to the maximum. Not only the sound design is stellar and immersive, probably just as immersive as Amnesia The Dark Descent but the white and black graphical style gives it an unique touch and feel to the game. The storyline is quite tricky because there's no dialogue and you only few a few remnants of civilization on the early to mid game so it's up to the player to make a story of their own.Some of the puzzles might become abit frustrating after a few tries because they require some timing but other than that I have no complains whatsoever. Limbo is a masterpiece and one of a kind that everyone who likes to play videogames or appreciates art should experience atleast once on a lifetime.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												All in all, a dark fun puzzle game.The art is done very well. It is obvious after only a few minutes of gameplay that the game was 50% atmosphere. This dark art mixed with the dark deaths and situations really makes the game interesting to play in of itself. You want to know what kind of craziness is after the next situation. The gameplay is solid as well. They know how to use their engine to make some really neat and sometimes frustrating puzzles. The story was simple... or I thought. In the beginning I would say that escaping this dark world would be the goal of the character. But it slowly drifted towards killing everything that moves. And the end seems a little out of character for what I was just put through. But conquering this dark world felt fun and dodging death is always a good time so it kept my attention pretty well.

												limbo is a "relaxing" platformer horror which is extreamly adicting and extreamly tense. the feeling that the game gives you is anxiety as you worry what is a head  of you. the game play is fun a smooth nothing more to be said. but the best part of the game is the story, people who have played the game may be thinking "What story there is no character interaction or dialog". but when i played through the game i found that the game is a story of a boy with mental health issues such as depression this is shown by the endless darkness and constant fealing of hopelessness and failure. the best way to describe this game is not calling its a "game" but calling it an "experience" this game is up for interpretation and that is where it thrives, how the game can mean so many diffrent things for diffrent people. it will make you feel horrible but in a good way some how, the world is immersive and interesting.  highly recomended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Limbo is really great. It looks great, feels great, has great controls and especially the level design and all the puzzles in them are very smart. Some call it a platformer, because at first glance there is jumping around and climbing (ladders), but given that the world is primarily filled with puzzles, you could just as well call it an adventure. The game has an almost unique feel to it and it is definitely a true original. Even games that were most likely "inspired" by this, were still rather good. I'm thinking of The Swapper and The Cave. Now I obviously bought the game (:P), but if you are among the people who got it for free in June 2016, please at least play it, instead of just dumping it on your digital shelf.The game is also rather short (you can finish it in 4+ hours), which is another reason why there is no excuse to not play it. Because of that the game gets never boring and it should keep your interest until the end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												All in all, a dark fun puzzle game.The art is done very well. It is obvious after only a few minutes of gameplay that the game was 50% atmosphere. This dark art mixed with the dark deaths and situations really makes the game interesting to play in of itself. You want to know what kind of craziness is after the next situation. The gameplay is solid as well. They know how to use their engine to make some really neat and sometimes frustrating puzzles. The story was simple... or I thought. In the beginning I would say that escaping this dark world would be the goal of the character. But it slowly drifted towards killing everything that moves. And the end seems a little out of character for what I was just put through. But conquering this dark world felt fun and dodging death is always a good time so it kept my attention pretty well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												For a game which took roughly 2~3 hours to beat, not including an hour and a half being out of my house, I can safely say that LIMBO definetly was worth to get while it was free on June 21~22nd of 2016's summer.While the story is nothing too big or tries to go for any twist, it's pretty much a somewhat non-story type of game where you just try to accomplish the goal of going right, and eventually reaching the end.The game itself gives off an atmosphere of uncanny, but instead of just throwing around blood and gore, the mere darkness speaks for itself. Sure enough, there will be some gruesome deaths to your protagonist should you make a mistake, but sure enuogh the game is not on the level of horror as in "oh noes I gots jumpscared", but rather the horror levels of not knowing really what's happening.Gameplay wise though it's a mix of puzzles and platformers. Being that there should be one or few parts where you'd need an almost precise timing, but for the puzzles at most it's either simply using whatever's grabbable by your character, a slight thinking outside the box or trial and error, by which I mean trial and deaths, because it's quite unlikely anyone would get through the first time without dying to something that you didn't expect, which is...kind of annoying, honestly.Besides that though, I really enjoyed whatever little time I had playing this, and I can safely say that this game is a 7~9. Reason is that while the game was definetly fun and the puzzles felt fair enough to not need a walkthrough to figure them out, there was still alot of cases where you'd need either some almost crazy timing that normally wouldn't be deemed as the solution to the puzzle, thus leading to alot of death in the way. And I can't give it a perfect score either because the story in general, while not too terrible, is still kind of basic and almost forgettable.But I'll give you that, the infamous creature of this game sure was the most interesting story I had throughout it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Limbo is just as great now as it was years ago when I first played through it on the Xbox 360. This is the gold standard for puzzle platformers, and proof that indie games can put new life into an old genre, provided that a little creativity is involved.The biggest surprise for me on this second playthrough was the existence of a secret level - it wasn't included in the console version I played. It was fun to experience new content when I wasn't expecting any, and it was the perfect amount of ridiculous combined with challenging - just what's needed for a secret level. I'd encourage anyone who hasn't done that part yet to give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												“Indie Puzzle-Platformer” isn’t the most enticing of terms for a PC gamer. It seems like such an accessible kind of game that every bedroom dev and their mother has made one, but that’s only because of games like Limbo. Probably preaching to the choir here but on the assumption that you’ve never heard of this game, I’ll tell you why it’s great.The mechanics are the standard 2-D side scrolling fare, except your movement speed and jump height feel a little less than other games of the genre. But that really plays into the main selling point of the game, which is the atmosphere. The entire game is in a bleak, high-contrast, black and white and beside some beautiful ambient sounds one might almost call music, the main sounds you’ll here are the ones made by interacting with the environment: Creaking wood or trudging footsteps – sounds normally minimised – are amplified to contribute an atmosphere of I guess “loneliness”. I’m unashamedly in love with this game’s sound design.Limbo’s release rightly sparked up the “games as art” debate when it was released, and if you experience it for a moment you’ll see why. All the above and more contribute to make you feel things: more than a usual sense of accomplishment or kick of adrenalin (although it has those too). It draws you in and makes you feel lost and powerless, but with a sense of hope spurred on by every small victory over the environment. Limbo is after all a game about a journey. Where from or to is not readily explained and it doesn’t really matter because the getting there is the experience. Every obstacle you overcome is simple but satisfying because it brings you closer to your goal, even though you have no idea when or where that is. And the journey never gets boring. The moment you get bored of the trudging moving of boxes on foot, the game shakes things up by rotating the screen or giving you a brain slug (no, really).If you have no patience for trial-and-error gameplay then maybe the puzzles might irritate you a bit. The game will unfairly kill you sometimes, but pick you up right before your death with the knowledge of the oncoming buzzsaw. Also, if you’re expecting an especially long game you’ll be pretty disappointed (unless you SUCK at puzzles). Oh and if you don’t have a wired 360 controller you might fall afoul of imprecise digital keyboard controls.Negatives done? OK, roundup: Limbo is beautiful, atmospheric and (for me) the right level of challenging. I’d hesitate to call it perfect except that I can’t think of anything I’d change, but then I’m not a developer.

Posted: June 11, 2016
												This game is six years old and I finally took the time to play it. Really unique style but has puzzles that are similar to Portal (pushing crates onto buttons and whatnot). Other than that there were some pretty tricky challenges, but just as the difficulty curve began to steep the game suddenly ends in a very anti climatic way - maybe that was the point but it kind of made me wish there was something else for me to go back to, like Portal. So I just uninstalled it, done, finished, five dollars for 3 hours of good fun. If you haven't played it after all this time I suggest you do, but only when it's on sale again or you recieve a discount for it, because once you've finished it (which only takes 2 hours max) there's nothing else.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Quick Breakdown: Limbo is a beautiful looking puzzle platformer, whos biggest appeal is its art style and ambience.Length: 3-4 hoursScore: 7/10Full Review: Limbo is a fairly simple and straight forward puzzle platformer. You play as a young boy, traversing through limbo to rescue your sister. You’re simply thrown into the game with no real indication of what is going on, and the story doesn’t really develop past that.But let’s talk about the gameplay itself, as a platformer it’s pretty simplistic, there aren’t a whole lot of tricks to master, nor do you really even need to master any. It’s not a game about pixel perfect platforming. Nay, it places greater focus on its puzzles. While there are a few tough puzzles throughout the game, most are able to be solved in a fairly reasonable time frame. Long enough to make you think and feel satisfied once you do solve it, but not so long as to become frustrated with the game. More importantly the puzzles are fun to solve, and the platforming is enjoyable.Now for the main attraction of Limbo, the wonderful looking art style and it’s excellent atmosphere. Limbo has a simple black and white art style that frankly looks fantastic. It’s nothing fancy, but it’s a pleasure to look at.	The art style plays a large part in helping create the wonderful, bleak, atmosphere of the game. There’s a general sense of loneliness, despair, and death hovering in the world of Limbo and pervading throughout the game. Music is used sparingly, occasionally flaring up to indicate danger and heighten the tension, and it helps contribute to the ambience of the game.My main criticism of the game is the lack of anything useful in the options menu. Limbo is a fairly simple game, so it’s not like it needs a bundle of configurable settings, but it lacks options to adjust anything but the brightness. The main thing I would have liked is to have been able to remap the controls, as I much prefer using WASD to move than the arrow keys. Thankfully the controls and gameplay are simple enough that this ends up being a fairly minor complaint, but it would still be a nice addition. (One can also use a controller to play, but as I don’t own one at this time I obviously haven’t used one).Nonetheless, Limbo is a rather fun puzzle platformer with a wonderfully bleak and depressing atmosphere to it.

												Creepy and funny at the same time!Best indie-game that i have played so far. The atmosphere from the first 10 (maybe 15) charapters is creepy and tense, with a lot of original and unexpected traps (from which you will certainly die at least once!). The last 2/3 from the game tend to have similar levels, but it wasn't boring for me to finish the game. The hardest part is to find the eggs (for achievments and a super difficult secret level), and of course they are hidden in such spots that it is hard to imagine how first gamers of Limbo found them, without looking in a guide. The puzzle aspect of the game is simply amazing, many different tasks that require imagination, creative solutions, and some skills of controlling the main character.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Limbo is a physics based puzzle platformer, but a first glance at it casts a message as a game full of grim and creepy images. This isn’t a horror game at all as this game is focused on platforming and solving physics puzzles, but Limbo has a distinctly dark atmosphere that suits the style and theme when playing through.There isn’t too much in terms of story. A boy wakes up in a forest, and as the game description states, tries to find his sister. There is no dialogue at all in the game, as the only things that expand on this story are the various interactions with other people and creatures as you keep moving forward in each level. The story does get resolved later on, though that is something that will be revealed along the way as the game continues.As a platformer game, the boy that you control doesn’t have much in terms of abilities. All the boy can do is walk, jump, and perform actions on other objects. As the game progresses, new level objects come in to play with different game mechanics to utilize. In the beginning, most puzzles tend to be simple platforming challenges. Later on, more difficult physics puzzles start to appear, requiring some puzzle solving compared to the easy solutions in the beginning. Toward the end, the puzzles are much harder and more involved, also requiring some good timing as well. Throughout the game, trial and error is a core aspect of solving the puzzles. You can definitely get away by being observant and thinking about each puzzle logically, but the harder puzzles require jumping into hazards to see what things do or to get a clue on how to solve the puzzle. The difficulty starts out quite easy, and becomes quite tough near the end of the game that the puzzles require some thought and coordination. Limbo’s simple platforming gameplay gives way for the interesting and well crafted physics puzzles, which require some deaths to successfully complete each puzzle.The art style for Limbo is one of the biggest motivators for the general tone of the game. The entire game is done like a black and white movie, complete with some film grain and blur to enhance the effect. The 2D design of the world though is quite beautiful in a way, with black silhouettes against gray shaded backgrounds. There is plenty of detail with the background scenery having softer blurred designs while the game objects sport hard, yet rounded shapes. This black and white style does heighten the creepy nature of the game a bit, evoking a feeling like watching old horror movies.The grim, grisly nature of Limbo is evident throughout the game, with many things hiding until they pop out to kill the boy. Early deaths are quite gory and violent, with the boy being dismembered or mauled in several ways. These things work well with the black and white style by simplifying details while still capturing the harshness of the world. These bloody deaths actually happen less later in the game, as more focus shifts on to the puzzles set in a more isolated man made environment. Overall, the dark style of the game works well with the art style for a creepy and bleak world.Keeping in tune with the dark themes of the game, there are no distinct songs in Limbo. Instead, the game uses an ambient soundtrack that heightens the mood and conveys game information. The sounds of each environment sets the backdrop and the tone, while subtle changes in the music sends a message of what is happening in the game. In addition to the ambient soundtrack adding so much in terms of tone and gameplay, the sound design is very well done. The sounds for the hazards sound distinct from the music which helps players recognize obstacles, while the sounds for deaths sound quite gruesome. With the ambient music and well designed sounds, the eerie atmosphere of the game is heighted more as each action unfolds.With heavy dark and grim tones, Limbo delivers some fun and somewhat challenging puzzle platforming wrapped up with a unique style. Each of the various aspects of the game work together to deliver this kind of foreboding atmosphere. As the game’s style is draws you in, the gameplay smoothly runs through the world with difficulty arising later on. Limbo works as a great experience of a game, both in the style it achieves, and the puzzle platforming gameplay that offers some good challenge with its crafty levels.

Product received for free
TL;DR Limbo is a Puzzle / Platformer that is quite trickyRating: 7/10Pros:+Short: Doesn't overstay it's welcom+Interesting Mechanics: Each puzzle starts fairly simply, then eventually ramps up into something quite challenging+Aesthetics: The black and White aesthetics is consistant and quite thought provoking+Achievements mean something: The achievements can be quite tricky to get to, even if you know where they are, especially the hidden achievementCons:-Short: The game for me  quite abruptly ends after You crash through the wall at the end and find your sister under the tree which sort of made me feel underwhelmed at how the ending played out and disappointed in  how the game loops back around to the forest quickly after the factory area-Non-intuitive Puzzles: Some puzzles require knowledge you can only gain AFTER you have died a few times in an area, which makes it extremely tricky to get the under 5 deaths achievement on the first playthrough without resorting to a walkthroughNOTE: I got this game for free as part of the give-away on the Steam Store page

												Minimal graphics and a subtle sound track make for tremendous atmosphere. It is MUCH more fun and interesting than I had expected. The physics made every death hilarious, so even dying is amusing and forgivable. The puzzles got pretty tricky in spots. Very clever game. The ending might make some people crazy, but I thought it was impactful. It brought home the meaning of the title. That being said, I was pretty disappointed that it was sooo short. I guess that is to be expected, but I felt it was pretty short even for a $10 indie. I'm a lover of long games though, so maybe that's just me. I would still most definitely recommend it. Maybe wait for a sale if don't want to spend $10 for one day of gameplay. Awesome overall!

												Limbo is basically a cinematic platform filled with great atmosphere, charming black and white art style, brutal death's animations and clever puzzles based on unexpected enviromental interactivity. The story is loose and understanding its meaning is left to the player's interpretation. A few collectibles and the crazy "finish the game with 5 or less deaths" achievement allow for some replay value. I have to say that this game isn't for everyone since it lacks of intense action and the genre is quite niche per se but it's surely worth a try

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Product received for free
												I originally bought this game on Xbox Live Arcade the day it released and finished it that night with a friend. When I saw Limbo free on Steam a few weeks ago, I had to download it and play it again. Limbo is, in my opinion, a milestone in the puzzle-platformer genre that has yet to be surpassed. While it is only a few hours long, Limbo has made a bigger impact on me than most 60 dollar, AAA games.+ Great gameplay with fluid animations and interesting puzzles that grow gradually in difficulty.+ Minimalist story told through engaging imagery rather than words.+ Sound design on par with big budget titles, possibly better.+ Art direction that is disturbingly beautiful.I look forward to playing "Inside",  Playdead's follow-up to this game.

content:
Posted: January 14
												Initially I thought a game that was made in black and white would be too dreary and monotone to hold my attention for very long.  However the dark, atmospheric environments combined with the grainy light effects creates a really engrossing 2d world.  The subtle use of sound, with little to no music, adds to the eeriness of the game.  There were times where the music would kick in towards the end of a chapter/zone and make me wish that it played for most of the game.  Some of the levels, especially those that took a while to solve, got a little bare for me and I think music would've added quite a bit. The game is very minimilast in general.  There are direction keys and an interact button.  Its strictly linear, and there is really nothing to explore.  The game consists of chapters, each of which take place in the same environment with similar puzzle physics.  The first half of the game containst mostly creatures and other enemies, while the second half seemed to only have puzzles.  The real challening puzzles probably didn't kick in until the last hour or two.  And I almost wish there were zone bosses or something bigger that you were progressing to, other than different puzzles.So shortly after playing the game I had one major complaint, and that was rooted in the games minimilast style.  I've never been a fan of games or movies where the player or viewer is supposed to create their own story through imagination.  I have no problem when open-endeness adds to the story or create conversation.  For example, the spinning top at the end of Inception adds to the movie, the film doesn't depend on it.  But when your game or movie has a wide open gap that is supposedly intended for you to supplement with your own version, I think its just lazy or an excuse for poor writing.But, after thinking about it, the game is certainly catered to be more episodic.  It's not intended to be completed in 1-2 sittings like I did (4 hours total).  There is no plot or characters for you to worry about. There is a minimal story to hang the framework of the game on, and the rest is just fun, atmospheric puzzles to explore zone to zone.  And in this way it succeeds.I would almost recommend you purchase it on iOS than PC, or at least plan to play it in short sittings. I believe I got it on sale but even for $10 you get your mon

As if Michel Ocelot made a Grimm's Fairytale.+A dark story told entirely and abstractly through the visuals.+Sound effects and soundtrack matching the tone of the art style and story perfectly.+Minimalistic controls. Depression?  Love?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												LIMBO is a puzzle-platformer that raises many questions. But it is not gameplay related, it is rather yourself starting to wonder these thoughts: Who is this nameless boy?Where is he?Why is he here?What is going on here?!The story is awfully vague, only saying "Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO". There's not much telling where he has gone to to come to said place..or -what- he has done...or worse, what -might- have happened to him.Or his sister.The controls are very responsive and smooth, and smooth fits the animation work of everything in the game. The game has a touch of realism, where you'll die if you jump off from too great heights for example. He is a resilent individual, not making a single human noise from himself, but you'll hear plenty of other sounds like those of sawblades decapitating him.The game has a very depressing color scheme being in black and white with all these horrific things that can happen to the boy. He can die some awfully brutal deaths such as impalement, crushed under and even get decapitated from giant beartraps. The puzzles are very clever thought and brings much variety, such as using the dead for your own good or even playing traffic light with a giant bug. At some points you're even challenged to survive a situation in where the majority of your freedom is taken away from you.The game itself can be called a trial and error game. For a first timer, it takes a few attempts before you realize what you are meant to do. For someone like me who knows what's coming, it teaches you that the game is very short (A speedrun with minimal casualties takes around an hour to complete from start to finish). For this reason, I recommend buying the game ONLY during sales and not otherwise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												It doesnt matter if you are into jump n run or not, this game is a fricking masterpiece. Normally I wouldnt even mind writing a review because you should already know it anyway, but a friend of mine told me a few days ago, he didnt know it yet. If you havent played this game, do so now. You are welcome.The only reason I can think of for disliking it is the rather dark atmosphere. The game is cartooney, but while there is no gore or blood, you will still see your little hero die. A lot. Buzz saws, spikes, traps, giant spiders, you name it. The game is not difficult in terms of controls etc, you only use the arrow keys and Ctrl to grab stuff, pull levers, etc.But. it. will. screw. with. your. mind. (in a hilarious way)There is a checkpoint on every corner, so dont worry about getting frustrated. If you die, it is because you didnt know yet, or because you messed up and jumped off the cliff. The puzzles are clever and original and solving them is - while not too hard - very rewarding.If you still have doubts, there is a free demo somewhere, but seriously, there is no need for that. I completed the game and I had a lot of fun watching my friends complete it about 4 or 5 times in total, last time yesterday, after owning it for over a year already. The only downside is that it is a one-time-only-experience, as you remember how the puzzles work after you completed them. Thats why I have so much fun watching others who do not know yet, try, fail, try again and laugh their♥♥♥♥♥off. :PGo play it. For your own sake.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Limbo is a great indie game. You are thrown into the game completely clueless about the plot and you are not briefed about the character's background, environment or any other aspect of the game. Throughout gameplay of Limbo, you follow along the experiences of a little boy in which you play as. You are presented with some challenging obstacles in which you learn many things from along with the character through your mistakes and the use of the method of trial and error. The game and levels are cleverly designed and though the obstacles are challenging to an extent, I have never found them to be overwhelmingly frustrating but in fact, I have found them to be rather enjoyable.The mood through the use of simple music and an unique artistic style involving dark monotonal colours is great at immersing the player into the scene. You begin to develop an attachment with character throughout the game.The physics/movement is applaudable, the character control is smooth and the controls are simple and easy to use.This game is an amazing piece of work. It is definitely worth the price. I have no regrets buying this game and I highly recommend this game to those considering to purchase and all of those who have not purchased this game. What are you waiting for?! :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												My feelings on Limbo are conflicted. On the one hand, I feel that the game overall is quite good. The puzzles are well done and the game is fairly entertaining throughout, but I also feel there are a few issues that hold the game back.	My first major gripe with the game is its minimalist story. The game is supposed to be about a boy trying to find his sister, but the game just begins with you waking up in a field and then progressing along a 2D plane. There is no introduction as to who you are or why you are here. One could argue that this leaves the player to create his or her own story, and normally that would be ok, but the game gives you absolutely nothing to base your thoughts on. The only reason I knew the game was supposed to be about finding the boy’s sister is because the description on Steam says so. If you want to leave interpretation up to the player, that is fine, but at least give them something to go off of. I have no context as to why I’m going through these trials or why there are people/creatures trying to kill me. It feels frustrating to me as a player because I want some context. The setting for this game is fantastic and I would love to know more about it, but the game offers no explanation.	On a somewhat related note, the game offers nothing in the way of instruction, either. Not even at the very beginning of the game. To find out the controls, you have to open the pause menu and check them out yourself. There is a growing complaint that video games hold the player’s hand too much, but this game does the exact opposite. You basically have to find out everything yourself as you go. For me, this lead to some frustrating moments where the solution to a puzzle was pretty simple, but I missed it for so long because I didn’t know I could move that object etc. The protagonist does move his arm a bit when he is in range of something he can touch, but that does not show up when running. As a result, you may run past the solution to a puzzle a few times before finally getting it. 	My final gripe with the game is its use of trial and error. On your first playthrough of this game, you will find yourself dying… a lot. The game uses trial and error as the primary means of solving puzzles. You’ll often find yourself dying to things that you didn’t know could kill you. The player is forced to run through things and die several times before he can fully understand how things work. This can get pretty frustrating after a short amount of time. These deaths feel cheap and unfair. Deaths should serve to punish the player when he makes a mistake. Instead, there is a sense that there is no way to get through the game without dying unless you know exactly what is going to happen and where it will happen.	All that being said, the game is still deserving of praise. First and foremost, the art style in this game is fantastic. The usage of black and white is incredibly well done and creates an interesting world that is fairly grim. It fits the game world which is hostile and brimming with evil. Using a limited color palette, the developers create a world that is surprisingly engrossing. It is easy to get lost in the game as you walk around and wonder what these places are and who (or what) lives there. 	Additionally, the puzzles are pretty solid as well. I’m not exactly a puzzle game buff by any means, but I found the difficulty to be reasonable (barring one or two exceptions). They are complex enough to require some thought, but not too complex for the average player. I was able to solve most of them after some critical thinking. This area does suffer a bit from the game’s minimalistic approach though. The exceptions I refer to are frustrating because it usually involved doing something that I had no idea I could. The lack of any indication left me scratching my head until I got so frustrated I had to consult a guide. 	Finally, the art style is awesome. The world is portrayed as fairly negative and hostile, and a simple black and white color scheme really helps convey that. It’s another factor that helps immerse the player in the world of the game. The contrast between light and dark has some interesting elements, and are even used in puzzle solving a bit. 	Overall, I’d say that, despite the problems I found in the game, it was a quite enjoyable experience. I dwell so much on those negative aspects, but I feel that they hold the game back from truly being a masterpiece. It has so much potential, and I just wish the developers would have done things just a bit differently. That would have taken the game from “great” to “fantastic.” 4/5

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Review Limbo (German/Broken English)Ein kleiner Junge in einer einfachen und ausreichenden schwarz-weiß Grafiklandschaft, der seine Wege mit wirklich sehr angenehmer und leichter Steuerung geht. Durch die verschiedenen Ebenen der Grafiken erhält es eine schöne Umgebungsdynamik, die mich sofort verschlungen hat. Er spaziert durch die verschiedensten und teilweise sehr kniffligen Rätsel. Ein oder Zwei Abschnitte können sehr den Durchhaltewillen fordern, jedoch wie ich die Lösung herausgefunden hatte, war ich super happy. Obwohl ich das Spiel wirklich zu 100% empfehlen möchte, gibt es einen Punkt der mich gestört hat. Es gibt keine Musik, die das Spiel noch mehr untermalt und noch spannender gemacht hätte. (Ich habe die Gamemusik von HackNet nebenbei laufen gehabt – war auch passend). Die Töne und Sounds die im Spiel hörbar sind, sind sehr leise und dann gibt es Momente wo es um sehr viel lauter ist. Abgesehen von Sound und Musik ist es ein TOP Game und bin froh es in meiner Bibliothek zu haben und kann es wirklich sehr empfehlen, wenn dir knifflige Rätseln gefallen.Pro/Kontra Liste+ Einfache Steuerung+ Spannende und knifflige Rätseln+ Grafik im schwarz-weiß Stil wundervoll umgesetzt+ Spielspaß bleibt (fast) durchgehend- Keine Ingame MusikA little boy in a simple and sufficient black and white graphic scenery. He goes his ways with really very pleasant and easier control. The different levels of graphics make a nice environment dynamic that has swallowed me up immediately. He walks through the most diverse and sometimes very tricky puzzles. One or two sections can be very demanding to perseverance, however, as I had found the solution, I was super happy. Although I would really recommend the game to 100%, there is a point of bothered me. There is no music in the game. That's a shame. With music, the game would have made even more exciting. (I have heard the game music of HackNet - was also suitable). The tones and sounds that can be heard in the game, are very quiet. At other times the sound effects are too loud. Apart from sound and music, it is a good game and I am glad to have it in my library and can really recommend it if you like tricky puzzles.Pro / Contra List+ Easy control+ Exciting and challenging puzzles+ Wonderfully graphics in black and white style + Game enjoyment remains continuously (almost)- No Game music

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Limbo, the game, is special in that while it does not wholly depict that mysterious dimension as my mind did, it captures its essence. You are a boy who wakes up in a lonely world made up only of black, white, and shades of gray. Video game logic demands you walk from left to right, jumping over obstacles as they appear, a simple task that needs little attention in the initial moments. This is your chance to absorb your surroundings. The background provides an illusion of depth, but its branches and bridges are out of focus, as if you are dreaming them into existence. The pint-sized hero, his bright blinking eyes shining from his blackened silhouette, trots ahead with the charming gangliness of a six-year-old.Pros :- Striking atmosphere that chills the heart- Excellent, poignant moments that stay with you- Cold, gruesome deaths are presented with memorable and horrific apathy- Introduces more involved puzzles at a satisfying paceCons :- The most haunting imagery is limited to the first half- Ending doesn't emerge organically from the hour leading to itSummary :Limbo is an incredible achievement. Very few games are as original, atmospheric, and consistently brilliant. It belongs in everybody's collection. The journey may be over too quickly, but you will be entertained every minute. This is one of my favorite games. I give it a 8/10.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												I got this game while it was free, so I can't exactly comment on if it's worth full price.It's an amazing game though, with a vague but interesting... story? It doesn't tell you much, but that's the beauty, personally. The difficulty curve is comfortable, with the beginning puzzles very easy, and the last few taking some real thought and effort. There's no unique gameplay mechanic, but I was sucked into the game world, and that's, I think, what the real unique selling point of this game is. It's very immersive, and it's atmosphere is incredible.I don't think the gameplay is perfect, but Limbo makes up for it with (somtimes disturbing) immersion.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Minimal graphics and a subtle sound track make for tremendous atmosphere. It is MUCH more fun and interesting than I had expected. The physics made every death hilarious, so even dying is amusing and forgivable. The puzzles got pretty tricky in spots. Very clever game. The ending might make some people crazy, but I thought it was impactful. It brought home the meaning of the title. That being said, I was pretty disappointed that it was sooo short. I guess that is to be expected, but I felt it was pretty short even for a $10 indie. I'm a lover of long games though, so maybe that's just me. I would still most definitely recommend it. Maybe wait for a sale if don't want to spend $10 for one day of gameplay. Awesome overall!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Creative and fun 2D puzzle platformer that is hard to stop playing.  The dark but cartoonish style to the game makes it appealing for a wide variety of game preferences. At first I thought the game was a simple "solve the puzzle" type but after a few checkpoints (which are very gracious throughout the game) the storyline starts to become more apparent adding another layer of depth to the game. I would highly recommend this game to everyone!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Limbo is a decent puzzle game that starts simple but gets slightly harder towards the end. It has a nice/creepy atmosphere and the art feels unique (even though it is black and white only).Most of the times the puzzles rely on timing rather than thought so be prepared for some trial and error before progressing further.There is no actual story and the game can be finished within 3 hours on average, which doesn't justify the 10€ price tag.Personally, I got this game during sales with a -80% discount (for 1.99€) so that was a good deal.Overall, it is a well-made and pleasant experience for a cold or rainy afternoon while you enjoy your tea/coffee.I would recommend to put this game on your wishlist and buy it only when it goes on discount again because the short duration and lack of replayability does not justify the 10€ price tag.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												Initially I thought a game that was made in black and white would be too dreary and monotone to hold my attention for very long.  However the dark, atmospheric environments combined with the grainy light effects creates a really engrossing 2d world.  The subtle use of sound, with little to no music, adds to the eeriness of the game.  There were times where the music would kick in towards the end of a chapter/zone and make me wish that it played for most of the game.  Some of the levels, especially those that took a while to solve, got a little bare for me and I think music would've added quite a bit. The game is very minimilast in general.  There are direction keys and an interact button.  Its strictly linear, and there is really nothing to explore.  The game consists of chapters, each of which take place in the same environment with similar puzzle physics.  The first half of the game containst mostly creatures and other enemies, while the second half seemed to only have puzzles.  The real challening puzzles probably didn't kick in until the last hour or two.  And I almost wish there were zone bosses or something bigger that you were progressing to, other than different puzzles.So shortly after playing the game I had one major complaint, and that was rooted in the games minimilast style.  I've never been a fan of games or movies where the player or viewer is supposed to create their own story through imagination.  I have no problem when open-endeness adds to the story or create conversation.  For example, the spinning top at the end of Inception adds to the movie, the film doesn't depend on it.  But when your game or movie has a wide open gap that is supposedly intended for you to supplement with your own version, I think its just lazy or an excuse for poor writing.But, after thinking about it, the game is certainly catered to be more episodic.  It's not intended to be completed in 1-2 sittings like I did (4 hours total).  There is no plot or characters for you to worry about. There is a minimal story to hang the framework of the game on, and the rest is just fun, atmospheric puzzles to explore zone to zone.  And in this way it succeeds.I would almost recommend you purchase it on iOS than PC, or at least plan to play it in short sittings. I believe I got it on sale but even for $10 you get your mon

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												LIMBO is an idie puzzle platformer that is very reminiscent of "Heart of Darkness" with its learn-from-your-deaths game mechanic. The game is designed completely in grayscale, and completely devoid of any music; with only the sound effects of the world around you, this all lends itself to a very creepy atmosphere. The puzzles and collectibles themselves are relatively challenging, and gaining all of the achievements makes it even more so.However, for as much as I enjoyed the game, I feel like $9.99 is a little steep. Aim to buy it on sale for $6.00 or less.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												It doesnt matter if you are into jump n run or not, this game is a fricking masterpiece. Normally I wouldnt even mind writing a review because you should already know it anyway, but a friend of mine told me a few days ago, he didnt know it yet. If you havent played this game, do so now. You are welcome.The only reason I can think of for disliking it is the rather dark atmosphere. The game is cartooney, but while there is no gore or blood, you will still see your little hero die. A lot. Buzz saws, spikes, traps, giant spiders, you name it. The game is not difficult in terms of controls etc, you only use the arrow keys and Ctrl to grab stuff, pull levers, etc.But. it. will. screw. with. your. mind. (in a hilarious way)There is a checkpoint on every corner, so dont worry about getting frustrated. If you die, it is because you didnt know yet, or because you messed up and jumped off the cliff. The puzzles are clever and original and solving them is - while not too hard - very rewarding.If you still have doubts, there is a free demo somewhere, but seriously, there is no need for that. I completed the game and I had a lot of fun watching my friends complete it about 4 or 5 times in total, last time yesterday, after owning it for over a year already. The only downside is that it is a one-time-only-experience, as you remember how the puzzles work after you completed them. Thats why I have so much fun watching others who do not know yet, try, fail, try again and laugh their♥♥♥♥♥off. :PGo play it. For your own sake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Limbo is a beautiful, atmospheric puzzle platformer with a hard edge. What story it has is largely implicit—the game contains no dialogue. You simply wake in a dark wood, apparently a child, and set off to explore the dingy place in which you find yourself. But the genre of the game is certainly horror, though without most of the usual tropes. You are fragile—easily hurt, unable to swim, essentially defenseless—in a hostile and trap-ridden place. You will die many times. And the game does not divert your gaze from your death but rather renders each different mode of your demise in somewhat disturbing detail. The artistic style of the game simultaneously keeps this from being too macabre and contributes greatly to the eerie atmosphere. The game's graphics are entirely silhouettes in shades of grey. Yet the landscapes and objects feel very detailed. Beautifully done lighting effects give the impression of a layered world mostly in shadow. All this makes for a beautiful noir environment well worth admiration in its own right. This game is more immersive with black and white outlines than much I’ve played that had expensive 3D-graphics.A subtler strength of the game is the way its physics feel naturalistic—you are acutely aware of the weight of objects and the force of gravity.  I doubt that the game’s engine is particularly remarkable in this regard, it’s an aesthetic effect. Great attention has been paid to the visual details of motion. But I think it also comes from player movement: in many games you play as a character with outsized physical capabilities. Even in shooters and platformers where such isn’t part of the story your movements are subtly superhuman (think of the lateral jumping featured in most platformers). Not here. Here you have a painfully tiny lateral jump and a rather slow top speed. Here objects don’t just slide easily into place but are dragged only with great effort.The largest complaint I had with LIMBO was that it was too short. Though the puzzles were good, and admirably varied, not too many were very difficult. If one is adept at this sort of thing one could easily complete the game in just a few hours. They are an excellent few hours though. The puzzles are crisp, things to be grasped, not just fiddled with. For a little while LIMBO takes you to an unsettling, engrossing otherworld. And I’d very much like to visit again.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Product received for free
												I originally bought this game on Xbox Live Arcade the day it released and finished it that night with a friend. When I saw Limbo free on Steam a few weeks ago, I had to download it and play it again. Limbo is, in my opinion, a milestone in the puzzle-platformer genre that has yet to be surpassed. While it is only a few hours long, Limbo has made a bigger impact on me than most 60 dollar, AAA games.+ Great gameplay with fluid animations and interesting puzzles that grow gradually in difficulty.+ Minimalist story told through engaging imagery rather than words.+ Sound design on par with big budget titles, possibly better.+ Art direction that is disturbingly beautiful.I look forward to playing "Inside",  Playdead's follow-up to this game.

												I got this game while it was free, so I can't exactly comment on if it's worth full price.It's an amazing game though, with a vague but interesting... story? It doesn't tell you much, but that's the beauty, personally. The difficulty curve is comfortable, with the beginning puzzles very easy, and the last few taking some real thought and effort. There's no unique gameplay mechanic, but I was sucked into the game world, and that's, I think, what the real unique selling point of this game is. It's very immersive, and it's atmosphere is incredible.I don't think the gameplay is perfect, but Limbo makes up for it with (somtimes disturbing) immersion.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Limbo is a physics based puzzle platformer, but a first glance at it casts a message as a game full of grim and creepy images. This isn’t a horror game at all as this game is focused on platforming and solving physics puzzles, but Limbo has a distinctly dark atmosphere that suits the style and theme when playing through.There isn’t too much in terms of story. A boy wakes up in a forest, and as the game description states, tries to find his sister. There is no dialogue at all in the game, as the only things that expand on this story are the various interactions with other people and creatures as you keep moving forward in each level. The story does get resolved later on, though that is something that will be revealed along the way as the game continues.As a platformer game, the boy that you control doesn’t have much in terms of abilities. All the boy can do is walk, jump, and perform actions on other objects. As the game progresses, new level objects come in to play with different game mechanics to utilize. In the beginning, most puzzles tend to be simple platforming challenges. Later on, more difficult physics puzzles start to appear, requiring some puzzle solving compared to the easy solutions in the beginning. Toward the end, the puzzles are much harder and more involved, also requiring some good timing as well. Throughout the game, trial and error is a core aspect of solving the puzzles. You can definitely get away by being observant and thinking about each puzzle logically, but the harder puzzles require jumping into hazards to see what things do or to get a clue on how to solve the puzzle. The difficulty starts out quite easy, and becomes quite tough near the end of the game that the puzzles require some thought and coordination. Limbo’s simple platforming gameplay gives way for the interesting and well crafted physics puzzles, which require some deaths to successfully complete each puzzle.The art style for Limbo is one of the biggest motivators for the general tone of the game. The entire game is done like a black and white movie, complete with some film grain and blur to enhance the effect. The 2D design of the world though is quite beautiful in a way, with black silhouettes against gray shaded backgrounds. There is plenty of detail with the background scenery having softer blurred designs while the game objects sport hard, yet rounded shapes. This black and white style does heighten the creepy nature of the game a bit, evoking a feeling like watching old horror movies.The grim, grisly nature of Limbo is evident throughout the game, with many things hiding until they pop out to kill the boy. Early deaths are quite gory and violent, with the boy being dismembered or mauled in several ways. These things work well with the black and white style by simplifying details while still capturing the harshness of the world. These bloody deaths actually happen less later in the game, as more focus shifts on to the puzzles set in a more isolated man made environment. Overall, the dark style of the game works well with the art style for a creepy and bleak world.Keeping in tune with the dark themes of the game, there are no distinct songs in Limbo. Instead, the game uses an ambient soundtrack that heightens the mood and conveys game information. The sounds of each environment sets the backdrop and the tone, while subtle changes in the music sends a message of what is happening in the game. In addition to the ambient soundtrack adding so much in terms of tone and gameplay, the sound design is very well done. The sounds for the hazards sound distinct from the music which helps players recognize obstacles, while the sounds for deaths sound quite gruesome. With the ambient music and well designed sounds, the eerie atmosphere of the game is heighted more as each action unfolds.With heavy dark and grim tones, Limbo delivers some fun and somewhat challenging puzzle platforming wrapped up with a unique style. Each of the various aspects of the game work together to deliver this kind of foreboding atmosphere. As the game’s style is draws you in, the gameplay smoothly runs through the world with difficulty arising later on. Limbo works as a great experience of a game, both in the style it achieves, and the puzzle platforming gameplay that offers some good challenge with its crafty levels.

												I bought Limbo when it was on sale like maybe a year ago and didnt play it too much because, as its always, there were many other games to play, but the first thing i can say, is that the game is worth every cent, even if you buy it for 10 Dollar or whatever. Limbo has on of the best and most scary atmospheres in indie games i've ever seen. Although it's only 2D and you don't get to know the boy really well, you learn to feel his feelings and fear his fears, like huge and gross monster-spiders and stuff like this. Furthermore, it's has some nice puzzle elements, which makes it one of the best indie games i've played so far.So as a conclusion, i strongly recommend the game to everyone who likes games with great atmospheres and puzzle elements.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												LIMBO is a puzzle-platformer that raises many questions. But it is not gameplay related, it is rather yourself starting to wonder these thoughts: Who is this nameless boy?Where is he?Why is he here?What is going on here?!The story is awfully vague, only saying "Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO". There's not much telling where he has gone to to come to said place..or -what- he has done...or worse, what -might- have happened to him.Or his sister.The controls are very responsive and smooth, and smooth fits the animation work of everything in the game. The game has a touch of realism, where you'll die if you jump off from too great heights for example. He is a resilent individual, not making a single human noise from himself, but you'll hear plenty of other sounds like those of sawblades decapitating him.The game has a very depressing color scheme being in black and white with all these horrific things that can happen to the boy. He can die some awfully brutal deaths such as impalement, crushed under and even get decapitated from giant beartraps. The puzzles are very clever thought and brings much variety, such as using the dead for your own good or even playing traffic light with a giant bug. At some points you're even challenged to survive a situation in where the majority of your freedom is taken away from you.The game itself can be called a trial and error game. For a first timer, it takes a few attempts before you realize what you are meant to do. For someone like me who knows what's coming, it teaches you that the game is very short (A speedrun with minimal casualties takes around an hour to complete from start to finish). For this reason, I recommend buying the game ONLY during sales and not otherwise.

As if Michel Ocelot made a Grimm's Fairytale.+A dark story told entirely and abstractly through the visuals.+Sound effects and soundtrack matching the tone of the art style and story perfectly.+Minimalistic controls. The player learns from their mistakes quickly, learning to adapt to and foresee the challenges as the game progresses.+Short and bittersweet.-404 Error Page.A robot wonders what this feeling is.  Depression?  Love?

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												You are a boy searching for his missing sister. You wander through gloomy forests, explore forbidding caves and try to escape a industrial complex of whirring machines and smoke stacks – all painted in silhouette against the smoky greys of an old flickering film.It's amazing that such a simple approach can create such a nightmarish atmosphere.This game is a polished diamond. It's nothing for hardcore nerds who don't like to use their brains.Limbo is a piece of game-art and should be treated like this. The optics ,sound designs are mindblowing.Everyone should play this clever straight up jump and run thriller at least once.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												You know, I've been playing video games since I was a kid. In recent years though games went from being difficult and chellenging to rewarding you for taking a step out of your house and in this age of coddling and babying it's nice to see a game that isn't afraid to punch you in the face. Limbo is short but it's dark atmosphere and difficult platforming more than make up for it. This game takes me back to when I had to buckle down and sit through a game for hours. Like I said, the only drawback to this game is that it's so short.If anyone out there still enjoys good platforming I'd highly recommend it. A solid 7/10.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
LIMBO is a masterpiece of platform games.  Title LIMBO   Developer Playdead   Publisher Playdead  Release 21 July 2010 for Xbox 360 (Xbox Live Marketplace), available on Steam in 2 August 2011  Graphics 2D   Genre Platform  Price €9,99  Rating 8/10 The game.LIMBO is a puzzle platformer indie game released in 2010. It was first released on the Xbox 360 in 2010, before moving to the PlayStation and PC in 2011, it latter got another port to PlayStation Vita and iOS, and yet another one onto the Xbox One and PlayStation 4.A memorable game. LIMBO demonstrates that a game is not all about crazy graphics or well produced story line. It's hard to classify it: it's a platformer, but it will rarely require good timing; it's a puzzle game, but you won't spend hours trying to figure out solutions; it's a horror game, but there's no blood, no jumpscare, not even fear, just a disturbing atmosphere.Gameplay.You’re a boy who wakes up in a lonely world made up only of black, white, and shades of gray. Video game logic demands you walk from left to right, jumping over obstacles as they appear, a simple task that needs little attention in the initial moments. This is your chance to absorb your surroundings. The background provides an illusion of depth, but its branches and bridges are out of focus, as if you are dreaming them into existence. The pint-sized hero, his bright blinking eyes shining from his blackened silhouette, trots ahead with the charming gangliness of a six-year-old.Then comes death. Limbo is a hostile place, home to giant spiders that would feast upon you, and traps apparently scattered by the world's other denizens. You step onto a claw trap, and it closes on your neck. Your head falls to the ground and wobbles just for a moment before lying still. No tears are shed, no music plays. The game provides no grand gesture to honor your demise. It simply happens, and you revive at the most recent checkpoint to try the puzzle again. Some of these deaths aren't outright fair; stepping on a pressure plate could mean certain death, but so could jumping over it. Such inconsistencies aren't common, but your first time in Limbo requires some trial-and-error experimentation. Loading times are short, and checkpoints are frequent, however, so death is rarely a frustration, though often a horror.I had heard a lot about this game and it don’t disappoint me. I bought it in winter sale 2016 for €1,99. I don't hesitate. This black-and-white 2D puzzle platformer is one of the best games you'll play on any platform. It’s, for sure, one of the best physics puzzle games out there. A clever game. And a good Christmas present.Pros. (+)(+) PresentationThis game establishes a strong connection with the player despite the lack of story, dialogue, text, or explanation.(+) GraphicsYou've never seen anything quite like this. The black and white visuals make everything creepier and the animation is very smooth.(+) SoundNot only do the eerie sound effects set the mood, you often have to listen carefully for clues to solve puzzles.(+) GameplayThe trial-and-death gameplay avoids being frustrating. LIMBO always has a surprise waiting for you around the next corner.(+) Lasting appealIs a fairly short game that might take around 4-6 hours to finish, but you’ll enjoy every minute of it. Finding every hiddden achievement will take a while.Cons. (-)None.Review Edition:When I did this review I still hadn't completed the "DING achievement" and it's extremely insane, very, very difficult - I died 20/25 times to do it. The achievement of "dying 5x or less throughout the game", to me, is unthinkable.Definitely recommended. LIMBO is a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												What a haunting, melancholy experience...To me, this is the type of game that helps define video games as art.In the simplest of terms, Limbo is a platforming puzzle game. Moving ever forward, the player is confronted with puzzle after puzzle, some requiring pure reflex and careful jumping, others requiring a more thoughtful approach. Regardless of whether the player is manipulating objects in the environment or simply dodging lethal terrain, the difficulty in Limbo feels organic and fair. There are moments that are more challenging than others, but having just finished it, I can say that all of the puzzles have a simple solution.But it's so much more than just the puzzles that Limbo has to offer. It's in its very name: Limbo. A space between reality and dream. A stasis between life and death. In its hazy monochromatic fog, Limbo leads the player through surreal and nightmarish landscapes. Why? Piecing together and creating the story for ones self is what makes Limbo so enthralling, at least to me. Very little is given, and for a generation of games that spoon-feed their players and hold them by the hand, the stark ambiguity of Limbo is absolutely refreshing.I won't share my interpretations of the story/ending. In some ways, I feel that it's all very obvious, as long as you're observant. In the end, do I recommend Limbo? Yes. If your taste is bombastic colors and sound, however, you'll find yourself disappointed. For anyone else interested in a title that encourages you to think: this is your game.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Product received for free
												Haunting and difficult but not always fulfilling. Limbo is a a challenging platformer in a drab grayscale world, A boy ventures his way through various puzzles and jumps to his final destination. The player progresses through different areas, meeting few inhabitants, in a story that is without words. The visuals and complimentary music create an atmosphere of dread, adventure, and uncertainty. Despite the lack of color, deaths are fairly graphic.The game, though charitable with auto-saving, is not without its frustrations. The controls feel slightly delayed and in game physics in regards to manipulating objects can be difficult to predict. Most irksome is the inevitable failures resulting in drawn-out deaths. I found one jump particularly vexing, and when I missed it, instead of being able to reset\ to the previous check point, I had to wait for my inevitable death, then wait for the death animation before finally restarting (i counted 20 seconds of waiting). 15 attempts later an you realized a single jump just took 8 minutes to complete. I appreciate the aesthetic and some of the challenges but felt kinda meh about the whole thing when I was done. I would give it a lukewarm recommendation

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												The name Limbo is an honest introduction to this game as a whole.Like limbo, for its duration the game is enigmatic, undefinable, and otherworldly with black and white graphics and a film grain, everything in the game animated as black silhouettes against a dreary, lonely backdrop made of shifting shades of gray. It has minimalist but effective sound design, think drippy water and receding footsteps, or a few flies buzzing at you. It's not full on horror, but it's a beautiful and perfect feeling of dread, wandering and isolation, all quite poetic, which is why critics just sweet talked the pants off of it and made sweet love to it in their reviews.You'll like it mostly for these one-of-a-kind aesthetics more than for its pretty standard puzzle platforming - you might be disappointed if you are a 'gameplay first' type of hardcore indie gamer. The puzzles all come in the form of risky or deadly traps or mysterious enemies that you have to somehow negotiate or kill. This is as close as the game ever comes to horrific, with some panic of imminent death punctuating the usual thick melancholy.If you want a short, sweet game that, if played in a dark room with headphones will really suck you in, it's definitely worth it for half or 75% off (I grabbed it for $2.50). Expect to seriously use your imagination every few levels, because though there aren't many parts to the puzzles, their solutions are not always apparent, and this adds to the game's enigmatic feeling. Plenty of puzzles you just have to die through several times to understand, but there are a ton of checkpoints, and this trial and error is intended, so don't let it get to you.Now that I think of it, it makes sense that the development team is Danish. Its sensibility of *bleh* is very cold, very pretty, and very Scandinavian.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Product received for free
												Although it may not be important for some, I originally got this game after playing the PS3 demo hoping to add it to the list of low spec games playable on my netbook. Linux users please note that Limbo will not run on the GMA3150 included with most netbooks, and likely laptops or computers using the same on board graphics, even with OpenGL 2.1 support enabled.Nonetheless the game runs beautifully on my main computer. The puzzles in game are interesting, but not too complicated, making it a nice casual platformer. Checkpoints (or "chapters" in game) save after most puzzles, so if you die you never have to backtrack too far.Overall if you're looking for a casual platformer with a dark atmosphere, I'd highly recommend this game, albeit with the caveat that Linux users should be aware that it may not run at all on older hardware. For those who've played the demo and are wondering if the full version is much better, I can say that the game only gets more interesting once you've passed the demo section.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Product received for free
												Although it may not be important for some, I originally got this game after playing the PS3 demo hoping to add it to the list of low spec games playable on my netbook. Linux users please note that Limbo will not run on the GMA3150 included with most netbooks, and likely laptops or computers using the same on board graphics, even with OpenGL 2.1 support enabled.Nonetheless the game runs beautifully on my main computer. The puzzles in game are interesting, but not too complicated, making it a nice casual platformer. Checkpoints (or "chapters" in game) save after most puzzles, so if you die you never have to backtrack too far.Overall if you're looking for a casual platformer with a dark atmosphere, I'd highly recommend this game, albeit with the caveat that Linux users should be aware that it may not run at all on older hardware. For those who've played the demo and are wondering if the full version is much better, I can say that the game only gets more interesting once you've passed the demo section.

												Limbo is an interesting puzzle game, i'd say it found a good balance in its puzzle difficulty. Its approachable and easy enough but every once in a while hit me with something that kept me guessing. The gameplay progresses with varying hazards and abilities such as gravity and lasers. Its art style and lack of sound (music not effects) really gave it an atmosphere that i enjoyed.  The length of the game was a pleasant suprise too, something quality that is less than 10hours can be a struggle to find sometimes. A nice story told even with a lack of dialog and a really creepy spider interaction makes this a little gem of a game.

												Limbo is a simple 2D side-scrolling platforming game with a few puzzles near the end. There is no color, but only black and white which creates the tense and spooky atmosphere. The platforming and puzzles are creative and very fun. The game is short (~3 hours) but the adventure is worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
 "Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO..." That's just it. No other information given. The story is vague, even after you finished it. And still,... got huge of recommendations with overwhelming positive reviews. How could that be possible?And here's what I though: Detailed Score: AspectScoreExplanationGameplay9.0Like other platformer games, in this game you have to finish the puzzles in order to advance to the next chapter. Actually, there is no clear distinction between each chapter in-game. You can see it, though at Load Chapter on main menu. The puzzle is quite easy at the beginning, but is getting more difficult in the mean of time. You'll have to die a lot just to discover the hint of the puzzle.For first walkthrough, it needs so much time (and a lot of headache) to finish this game. (I remember my first walkthrough and it needed days for me to complete it.)One little flaw (probably) of this game is the length of game. Especially for second walkthrough and more, the game can be finished for a couple of hours. It is more likely because much of chapter is quite short and the key to finish the puzzle is easily remembered once you have finished it before.World Design9.5"Hey, why would we have to discuss the world design here?""Well, as a platformer game, it does a matter, right?"Okay, no matter how good the gameplay is, it's going to a waste when the world is poorly designed. Gladly, LIMBO is smart enough to avoid that problem. The world is mainly divided into three regions: forests, sub-urban cities, and mechanical factory. Each place has their own unique design, given the player to do the different approach to finish the puzzle in each regions.Not much more to say? Okay, to the next criteria.Story9This is where one of most unique aspects of LIMBO lies. You have no clue about what's really happened from the start (to the ending). All we know is our character, a boy, anonymous, wake up in the middle of forest, go through puzzles and puzzles, and finally meet your little sister.For some people, the story is very annoying given the lack of information about it. But, I love it. It give us the feel that the game "don't guide us". You are the player, you define the story, you define what's really happened. It's pretty unique way about how developer put their story.Graphic and Sound10The most remarkable aspect of LIMBO. Instead give us he player a full-detailed graphic, the developer gives us a grey-ish, silhouette world. You have to imagine about the world itself, what our character looks like, what those giant spiders look like, what those big chainsaw looks like, etc etc etc.Those big aspect of graphic become more immersive with the sound effect. I love how developer use minimalistic sound effect in their game. Sometimes they makes use calm. Sometimes, they gives us some kind of nightmare, take example of sound effect when you died because of chainsaw. (ugh...)Those two aspect are combined pretty well, and we have an immersive, dark, terrifying, and yet beautiful world. TL;DR LIMBO is a great example of what a game should be. Every aspect of this game is amazing, if you don’t want to call it perfect. A must-have for every platformer fans and common gamers alike.Some people say the price is a little bit high for a 3-5 hours of gameplay. For me, it’s worth every cent of your money. Score: 9.5/10  NB: I only spend less than 10 hours for this game when I reviewed this game. I’ll tell you, I have finished this game long time ago.  Well, at piracy. Forgive me!!!  But then, I still buy this game on Steam because I love this game so much. I want to give my support for the developer and I can’t wait for their upcoming projects in the future.
