number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												You play as a boy who is on a quest to find his sister for whatever unknown reason. You will face the trials of gaint spiders, ancient tribe warriors, gigantic saws and much more. All this takes place in a fluid black and white atmosphere with a soothing set of ambience in the background. However it is not without its flaws. I have two major complaints against this game, the first being that there is zero help whatsover on how to play this game. To learn the controls, I had to find which key opened the  main menu to open to the control manager. (For future players, this menu can be opened with the "escape" key and the controls on a standard keyboard are the arrow keys and the control key for interacting with an article. Also, when you are upside down, the jump key is the "down" button.) The second major issue with this game was the story. Except for the game's description, there is no way for the player to understand the story. Also, the end of the game was... open ended to say the least. I feel the developers could have done a better job explaing to the player what had happened to cause this "limbo." All in all, the game is great, but for ten dollars, I expect at the very least, a help section in the game's menu. GENRE TYPE: Puzzle/Action-AdeventureMUSIC: 2/5 - There wasn't much music involved with the game. A bit too quiet for my tastes. SOUND: 4/5 - Excellent job with the background noise. You hear everything from birds to the boy's breathing.STORY: 1/5 - This is the main issue here. The developers neglected to inform the players of the objective and the end result.PUZZLES: 4/5 - You should be able to figure them out yourself, but an optional hint system would have been appreciated. GRAPHICS: 5/5 - While monochrome, the game's fluid-like phsyics and detail makes the world pleasing to the eye.DIFFICULTY: 4/5 - Simple enough at first, but it gradually increases to a fairly moderate challenge in the end.OVERALL SCORE: 3.8/5 - Great job on physics and puzzles, but poor execution of main storyline.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												There has been much written about heaven and hell. The absolute paradise of the former and the absolute pain of the latter are some of only a small handful of human ideas that are immune to hyperbole; our mortal descriptions of such places will never be too much and of that we can be sure.But what about what lies between? The concept of purgatory is a much harder one to pin down. Thoughts on the concept, both lay and philosophical, have defined it as anything from a second mortal existence to an afterlife of absolute nothingness. If the title is to be believed, LIMBO ostensibly takes place in this in-between afterlife. It may not be hell, but it is a far cry from heaven."Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO." This lone sentence is the closest thing to a synopsis that the creators have given us. How the boy got to limbo is unclear. Why you must press forward is unclear. But to stand still is to both promise and condemn yourself to nothing.But after all, LIMBO is a puzzle platformer and the instinct to move forward is natural. The puzzles are elegantly designed and make the most of your limited capability for interaction: running, jumping, and moving objects. Everything feels right and the game plays as a good platformer should.LIMBO is not content to only be another decent indie platformer, though, as the puzzles very quickly become trials of dread and fear. Death has always been part of platformers, but LIMBO is almost eager to remind you of the pain. In your desire to move forward, you only introduce to your character more ways to die. If you miss that jump, you will fall down a pit and be impaled on the spikes below. You will have your body torn to pieces by the crushing force of a giant bear trap. You will fall into a ragdoll's seizure as electricity fries you. Even the more quiet deaths feel horrible; drowning in water is a whole process of struggling and sinking before becoming still. The screen will linger and you will sit with it until you are ready to press a button to respawn. Do you want to try again?The hazards of LIMBO seem too much to all be manmade, but they all seem purposeful. It is hard to ignore the sense of malice that pervades this world. The colorless settings and the silhouetted character designs do some amount in making the deaths less gruesome, but only so much. You might find yourself standing still when you get that second chance. To stand still is to do nothing, but to move forward is to create your own hell.But maybe you do keep pushing forward and maybe you do succeed more often than you fail. The purpose of this boy's search for his sister is unclear: it could be a journey of redemption, or love, or curiosity. Either way, that there is even a chance at success and a chance at relief at the other end of each dangerous trial is, in a way, a promise of heaven. There will be hard times ahead, but the pain is not infinite. To be given the chance to find an answer and reach an end is a small but merciful thing. But before that, the hard times will only get harder.There will always be ideas about what lies between heaven and hell, life and death. LIMBO has earned its spot among the best artistic representations of such a place – not only through its undeniable dark beauty, but also the fear that a similar world might await us.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22
												This is what I'd call an atmospheric trial and error simulator.The strong point is the atmosphere: the lighting, the ambient sound and the minimalist contextual storytelling which slowly, horror by horror, unveils one of the grimmest video game worlds the medium has ever seen. Bravo on that point.Then we have the mechanics, inevitably the core of any game. The verb set is fairly rudimentary; you can run, jump, climb, push and pull things, and that about summarises it. The mileage you can get out of these basic actions, coupled with some rudimentary physics, is fairly limiting. But from what I saw of Limbo, the designers compensated somewhat for the repetitive nature of the puzzles by dressing them up in some inventive and creepy set pieces, each one revealing more about the world you find yourself in. So I was ok with the mechanics, at first.Where the game fell apart for me is the checkpoint trial and error nature of the gameplay. The world of Limbo is so perilous that you're only ever a few footsteps away from the next new death animation, and the problem is that for the most part these are not telegraphed to the player. By telegraphed I mean to have just a second where the player senses imminent danger and can react accordingly if they are thinking on their feet. There are too many cases where this doesn't happen in Limbo, such is the sudden and unpredictable nature of many of the traps and hazards. The result of this is that the player is soon conditioned to move forward expectant of death. And the designers know this, that's why there is a checkpoint before and after every little puzzle, trap and monster. So the combined effect of both expecting death and knowing that it's of no consequence results in the player pushing onward carelessly, allowing themselves to be killed and then hoping to learn from their death how to overcome the section on the next attempt. Or the third, fourth or fifth attempt.Unfortunately this no-consequence, checkpoint kind of gameplay adds an extra layer of repetition onto mechanics already inherently repetitive (as mentioned). But worse, much worse, is that it saps any kind of fear or tension from this wonderfully atmospheric world that has been crafted. With no reason to worry about death, no reason to feel triumphant at a near-miss, and no reason for the palms to sweat because of the high stakes and terror, the power of that atmosphere is stripped away. And without that atmosphere what is left behind amounts to an assault course of trial and error physics puzzles that you will attempt dispassionately, again and again, until eventually they just come to bore and irritate you.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
Product received for free
												I got this game when steam had the big giveaway a few months back.Short and sweet, this game just isn't my cup of tea. I can appreciate aesthetics that some people might like, but it goes against most of what I look for in a video game. To be specific, everything is black, white, and gray. There is no narration whatsoever. The character you play as is a boy that can do 3 things: run, jump, and activate stuff (either push/pull an object or press a button generally). You face mostly automated obstacles, with a handful of biological and plenty of static obstacles as well as you try to puzzle platform your way through a 2D world. It's a pretty dystopian world, where the people, giant spiders, and Plankton from spongebob are all out to get you.If you like those kinds of things, go for it. It's a 2-3 hour adventure, and the puzzles are pretty good honestly, but the entire aesthetic isn't for me.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												Very artistic and stylized, but not very cohesive. The "challenge," of this game comes from it's trial and error attitude. Why does the game feel the need to punish me by showing three seconds of my character's brutal death after "failing?" It's not a challenge if I didn't see it coming. Trial and error gameplay works with games like "I Wanna be the Guy," or "Super Meat Boy," where respawn time is instant... but for a puzzle game that requires you to wait and be patient? It just seems like poor game design. I found myself getting annoyed more than getting immersed, and that's never good.Pick it up during a sale. It's not as good as everyone seems to believe, unfortunately.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Honestly, I think this game gets more hype than it deserves. I mostly finished this to prove that I could rather than because I wanted to. The environment is eerie, beautiful, and quite unique as well, certainly offering an enticing atmosphere like the title would suggest. Most notably for me was the soundtrack. Though consisting of only a few pieces, the music is haunting and enjoyable to listen to, helping to build onto the world. I only wish it was more present in the game since my main dose of it came from listening to the soundtrack that I acquired with my bundle purchase. The controls are also simple, intuitive, and tight so most things are down to player timing and ability rather than mushy controls. Other than that... a lot of the puzzles were kind of tedious. Many deaths felt kind of cheap, because so many things just felt unavoidable the first time you're playing through something, so multiple attempts at puzzles were a must. Additionally, while I did mention this as a plus, the controls make it so your timing needs to be SPOT ON. A fraction of a second could mean yet another infuriating death. While a lot of people praise the story in this game, I felt like it wasn't there at all. It's so open ended that it doesn't even feel like a plot exists. You're dropped into gameplay and after a few hours it ends. Nothing explaining who you are, why you're there, or what your goal is aside from not dying a ridiculous number of times. So overall, I don't think I'd really recommend this game unless all you're looking for is a puzzle/platformer and you don't mind the lack of a story.

												A cute puzzle game, but the description on the store page is more story than the entire game will give you. Some of the puzzles make very clever use of character momentum, but I just didn't feel like I was having much fun solving the puzzles and I kept thinking things like, "Why are we in a factory now?"  and things like that. There's some undertones that the forest is causing all sorts of hallucinations and that most of this is just in the kid's head, but as I mentioned before, the game never decides to give you a single line of text as an explanation. The game might be worth it if it's on a big sale, but I beat the thing in three hours and it really doesn't have any replay value.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												For what it is, I can't find a true fault with LIMBO. The game doesn't claim to be anything it isn't, it's a simple puzzle/sidescrolling game that will at times leave you frustrated and put out, only to experience that giddiness of figuring it out shortly thereafter. It never traipses about claiming to be anything more than it is. For lack of the ingenuity to phrase it better, they whole♥♥♥♥♥♥♥what they envisioned, and left the rest by the wayside.The plot is vague, so secondary it might as well not exist... and I'm quite alright with that in this case. You are tossed into a bleak, unforgiving, and cruelly beautiful world to... move to the right (and die quite a few times on your way). Might not seem like much, but it's stunning and worth every minute.Obligatory mention that Martin Stig Andersen's work on this only reinforces my mild to manic obsession with well done soundtracks. Phenomenally moody, reminiscent of quite a bit of John Luther Adams' work. I can't imagine anything more fitting.A small part that I particularly enjoyed are that the achievements... are actually achievements. It doesn't throw you one every time you remember to blink or jump for the first time.Wonderful game.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												When all's said and done, it's the art style and atmosphere that made this game a success. The puzzles are generally above average for games of this type, although they mostly use rather vanilla mechanics that have been seen before in countless other games (push blocks around, swing on ropes, pull levers to change states of machinery etc. etc.) It's an amazing game at first: artistic, eerie atmosphere; an intriguing story; and a variety of clever mini-puzzles.  Sadly, at about the halfway point it stops being about puzzles and starts being about running as fast as you can and perfect-timing every jump. The puzzle design becomes far too reliant on precision timing, and frustration tends to dominate. What I found was that you fairly quickly work out *what* you are supposed to do, but the act of *actually* executing the sequence is bogged down with endless trial-and-error as you have to constantly micro-adjust the positions of things, and re-adjust your timing until you hit that split-second and pixel-perfect "sweet spot" that allows progression to actually occur. When it takes 30secs to figure out the solution, but 10 minutes of repeating the same sequence over and over until you hit that jump just right (for example), then there is something obviously wrong with the design. Best way of summing it up - it's a bit like how Braid would have played if you were allowed to rewind time. Ouch.Just as it was introducing some interesting mechanics, the game ended. Add to that the ending is a huge disappointment story wise (no real spoilers, but suffice to say: it ends like an Arthouse movie, not at all like a fantastic mystery). Thoroughly disappointing beyond the first half.

number of helpful: 16 of 31 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												Play this game only if you hate fun.This game has a handful of mechanics that really detract from the fun. First, your character dies when he touches water. What is this, 1998? This would not be so annoying, except for the fact that it piggy-backs off of another problem with this game: not solving puzzles correctly results in you dying, and therefore reloading a checkpoint. Tons of these puzzles involve water or some stupid insta-kill mechanic. However, neither of these two mechanics would annoy me nearly as much if it weren't for a third mechanic: it is almost impossible to solve a puzzle without failing it first. So, there are annoying insta-kill mechanics to puzzles that you are set up to fail. This makes the game artificially hard. None of the puzzles are difficult, except for the fact that you get stuck dying at one part over and over just to realize to had to backtrack (yes, another annoying mechanic) a few screens and pick up some object you thought was part of the background to solve a puzzle.What this game does have going for it are a unique art style and mood. However, after a few minutes of the "soundtrack" (read: ambient synthesizer nonsense), you feel like you OD'd on benzo's and are unsure if the blurriness of the game is the art style or your brain dissolving in your skull. This game is apparently a great example of minimalist narrative, but I can't get past the gimmicks and archaic game mechanics to care.

												While it only took me 3.4 hours to beat, those 3.4 hours were some of the best I have had in my gaming history. Lately, indie titles like Braid, Trine, Limbo and others have been some of my favorite games overall. Not only does Limbo have amazing puzzle solving gameplay but it also has a... I feel weird saying this... a very touching storyline. Also, for a game with no writen or spoken words, Limbo has possibly the greatest atmosphere of any game (only competition would be S.T.A.L.K.E.R.) and it never gets old. I hope to God there is a sequel to this game, either way, I cannot wait to play the next game from developer Playdead, and please do yourself a favor and experience this game.5/5

												Ok, it was nice to play, I can't say it wasn't. Maybe it's just I heard to many good opinions about this game. I probably expected too much, therefore I've been disappointed...The puzzles are clever and not so easy, the ambience is interesting, but... Ok, it's not that I don't like to move a character from left to right but... at least, give me a small reason to do so ? A story for example ? Anything ? And that end, I'm sorry but this is not an open ending like I've heard sometimes. To make an open ending, you need to have a story in the first place. This, was, eventually, the begining of a story. Which happens after 4 hours of "wtf am I doing here ?".(SPOILER) When I saw the first human in the game, a kid who was activating a trap in order to kill me, I thought "oh, nice ! it finally begins, so mysterious !" And no, nothing, no explanation, just all the living things you meet are trying to kill you. Like in any poor game with a poor storyline. Sigh...So, no, I don't understand why this game has so many good comments. It was "ok", but not that good... And it had a very good potential. Frustrating.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Ultimately, not what I expected. I normally hate 2D platformers/sidescrollers because of the oversaturated market, but this was actually a good game despite its flaws (which was the inherited overhype). I think what made me respect this game was the excuse for having such a simple artstyle. That gets so abused today, but I liked this. Maybe the simplicity is what makes it what it is? At least the story anyway. The dystopian world could do with more details, but you don't always need details to send a message. Many take a really obvious explanation to the ending, but I like thinking of it much more philosophically; something everyone can relate to sometime in their life. This makes the game so much more powerful, and particularly interesting, and I believe it to be the very best way to enjoy it. Play it by yourself on a lonely evening and ponder about life as a whole. "I swear, when did I experience something like this?" was the thought I got after every chapter. Truly wonderful.The game as a whole I don't think is commendable other than that. The format is classic, which doesn't make it worse, but I don't understand the sacredness of it. This is just how a game should be felt like playing I think, a real game for once!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Wonderful presentation - lackluster game design.That's how I would sum up Limbo in one sentence, and it is a shame. I love difficult games and I have a high tolerance for frustration, but this is the wrong kind of 'difficult'. Solving puzzles feels brainless and uninspiring in this title, especially towards the end. My main complatint is that you cannot use logic to do so, but rather have to apply trial and error in pretty much every situation. Usually, you will have a general idea of how to approach a puzzle, but in order to execute it correctly you have to repeat the same sequence over and over with just tiny variations.. In my opinion, a good puzzle game should give the player different elements to play around with and find out how they interact. Unfortunately, this is not Limbo's focus, as most puzzles feel very one-dimensional. Just compare that to Portal: In Portal, there is a general sense of achievement after solving a puzzle, even though the game is by no means hard. That's because the solutions are not apparent right away, and you have to mentally rearange the elements, thus making the player actively involved. In Limbo, on the other hand, you can see right away that you have to stop a cogwheel at the right moment in order to advance, but figuring out the right timing may take you about 20 attempts. What you feel after finally succeeding is not wonder at the imaginativeness of the devs, but disbelieve that you had to repeat the same boring task 20 times.On the positive side of things, the atmosphere in this game is deep and brooding. If for nothing else, it might be worth checking it out just for the experience of the early game stages. If you enjoy it enough and do not mind the highly repetetive game play, this might just be the right title for you. Unfortunately, I just can't give it a thumbs up, as I felt more annoyed at the lacking puzzle design than enchanted by the artistic quality. This is one of those games that might really appeal to some people but not to others, so best try it out for yourself. The majority of folks here on Steam appear to have a different opinion from mine, which I am perfectly fine with. I am glad that others got more enjoyment out of this game than myself.(BTW, the amount of hours played in my profile is misleading, as I played most of this game off-line)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Sort of like if Mario had a really bad trip. In terms of it's basic mechanics, LIMBO's basic premise is that the protagonist (who seems to be a young boy) wakes up in a forest, and it's your job to guide him through the many dangerous in this terrifying world. The game pairs traditional platforming with light puzzle-solving elements through a fairly linear exploration/progression; basically, keep going right, and solve the puzzles so you can keep going in that direction. Though this a short game, in the process of completing it you'll pass through forests, caverns, sewers, and derelict factories and cities.The atmosphere is utterly enthralling; the entire game is in grainy black-and-white; there is almost no soundtrack, only very dark and minimalistic ambient effects; there is no dialogue at any point in this game, and the only other NPCs you meet all try to kill you in a variety of ways. And this game really is dark; giant spiders impale you on their legs, boulders crush you, worms take control of you and often force you to run off cliffs, and bear-traps crush you in their vice-like grip.  his is an utterly hostile and terrifying world. One section has the player cross a lake by jumping across the floating corpses of people forced to wade into the lakes to their deaths by mind-altering worms. Having crossed the lake, the solution to the next puzzle is to then drag one of the bodies out and to push it over a ledge onto a button, which causes a huge block to fall crushing the body, which would have been you had you activated the button yourself. This is a very, very dark game.And the puzzle-solving elements do become quite challenging as the game goes on, through it never reaches the difficulty of games such as Braid. The game steadily introduces new mechanics to keep things fresh, with switches that can reverse gravity or active giant magnets, while the feedback for failure is always immediate and brutal. Thankfully the game has no loading screens even upon death so you can be back to have another go in a matter of seconds.The plot itself is thread-bare. There is no dialogue and no non-hostile characters besides one recurring one, whose finding seems to be the only real objective in this game. That does not mean the plot is not there though, and to me it seems like the team behind this deliberately left the game open to interpretation; the game is called LIMBO, how does that relate to the environments you find yourself in and the things that happen to you on your journey? Who are these other people you encounter from time to time? What happened to these factories and sewers and cities? These questions are never answered straight-forwardly, but it's for you to decide for yourself what this game is about and to me that makes it more powerful.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2011
												While it only took me 3.4 hours to beat, those 3.4 hours were some of the best I have had in my gaming history. Lately, indie titles like Braid, Trine, Limbo and others have been some of my favorite games overall. Not only does Limbo have amazing puzzle solving gameplay but it also has a... I feel weird saying this... a very touching storyline. Also, for a game with no writen or spoken words, Limbo has possibly the greatest atmosphere of any game (only competition would be S.T.A.L.K.E.R.) and it never gets old. I hope to God there is a sequel to this game, either way, I cannot wait to play the next game from developer Playdead, and please do yourself a favor and experience this game.5/5

You get to face a lot of different puzzle challenges from throughout the years, with an amazing backdrop to accompany you. They very few humans encountered with try their hardest to kill you, but you're just a little too badass for 'em. 												What is Limbo? Is it Fear? Is it Despair? Is it Beauty? Is it Freedom?Limbo is the answer. Limbo is the question. Limbo is the Beginning. Limbo is the End. "Limbo" is a One of a Kind Experience, one that must not be overlooked. Touching in many ways and surprising in others. Generously Simple in Mechanics and Masterful on its Art Design. And while the game does not, at first, speak much of itself, be mindful of the little details that do actually breath out a story. Do I recommend Limbo?Yes.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												The hype around this game, while having finally died down, was entirely undeserved. The script for this game seems to have been taken straight from the "I'm so deep" musings of your average high school teen, with an ending that is as groan-inducing as it is anticlimactic. While the game features a few neat gimmicks here and there, the inconsistent design and half-baked controls ensure an experience that fails to overcome its nuisances. This would perhaps capture the heart of young teens who just finished reading (the sparknotes for) 1984, but otherwise Limbo absolutely fails to live up to the love it has been given.

												I am a ferret wearing a bowtie.My eyes work best at night. This is probably why i like Limbo. It takes place at night. If not night then maybe in purgatory. I've always imagined walking form left to right in purgatory to be very much like walking left to right in Limbo. Did you know that some people claim ferrets have very poor depth perception? Some even say they have none at all! maybe that is why i walk off the tables edge all the time. Maybe this is why i love Limbo so much. You know being a ferret and how we play video games on a 2D screen. I am certainly NOT looking forward to this virtual reality nonsense. And what the hell was up with 3D TV? They'll never capture the ferret market with silly extra dimensional crap like that.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												A game with not much to it, following a very controversial, in-depth plotline with a young boy stuck in Limbo. You get to face a lot of different puzzle challenges from throughout the years, with an amazing backdrop to accompany you. They very few humans encountered with try their hardest to kill you, but you're just a little too badass for 'em. The controls are very easy and willing, and the graphics are good for an Indie game.If you're looking for a game with a lot spunk and ideas thrown you're way, with the ability to craft your own ending, then you'd enjoy LIMBO.

												A minimalist game built on emotion and mystery, is the easiest way to describe this haunting, quiet adventure. Similar in scope to Ico, yet more pared down in both visuals and motivation, the understatement itself becomes a key feature: is this a straight forward tale of a young child navigating a mysterious, hostile environment? content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Limbo is an extremely dark puzzle-adventure game. The game is hilariously sick, creating an atmosphere easily meant for older crowds, despite the childish appearance of the game. The graphics and rendering are amazing and beautifully crafted. The puzzles start easy and increase in difficulty at an even pace, building up in darkness as well as becoming more challenging. The game forces the player to pay close attention and really think of what they have to do. The only downside to the game is how relatively short the gameplay is. After only a few extremely short hours, one reaches the end of the game. While the game itself is interesting and fun, the shortness creates an overall sense of one being unfufilled. Unless, the player is someone who enjoys a quick and challenging game. Any sequals or exstensions for the game would be greatly anticipated.Fun 4/5, Originality 4/5, Mature 4/5, Graphics 5/5, Addictive 2/5, Repetative 2/5, Worth the Price 3/5

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Mixed feelings, and not in a good way...Yes, this game is beautiful in terms of art. At first, it really sets this gloomy mood that I enjoy.The first few levels are finely balanced, just tricky enough to be challenging, but still easy enough to pass if you try.But somewhere along the way, the atmosphere fades and all that's left is frustration. The majority of puzzles require precise timing and trial and error, with some fake difficulty thrown in for good measures. Even the slightest mistake means death, and while the checkpoints were (luckily) generous, you were still forced to repeat some very annoying sections. In short, I would say the utterly disappointing ending just wasn't worth the hassle.And then came the terrible hunt for the DING! achievement.While completely optional, this part was just one huge step in the wrong direction. Walking in pitch-black darkness for long minutes only to be killed by a randomly positioned sawblade that you cannot see really isn't my idea of fun...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Sort of like if Mario had a really bad trip. In terms of it's basic mechanics, LIMBO's basic premise is that the protagonist (who seems to be a young boy) wakes up in a forest, and it's your job to guide him through the many dangerous in this terrifying world. The game pairs traditional platforming with light puzzle-solving elements through a fairly linear exploration/progression; basically, keep going right, and solve the puzzles so you can keep going in that direction. Though this a short game, in the process of completing it you'll pass through forests, caverns, sewers, and derelict factories and cities.The atmosphere is utterly enthralling; the entire game is in grainy black-and-white; there is almost no soundtrack, only very dark and minimalistic ambient effects; there is no dialogue at any point in this game, and the only other NPCs you meet all try to kill you in a variety of ways. And this game really is dark; giant spiders impale you on their legs, boulders crush you, worms take control of you and often force you to run off cliffs, and bear-traps crush you in their vice-like grip.  his is an utterly hostile and terrifying world. One section has the player cross a lake by jumping across the floating corpses of people forced to wade into the lakes to their deaths by mind-altering worms. Having crossed the lake, the solution to the next puzzle is to then drag one of the bodies out and to push it over a ledge onto a button, which causes a huge block to fall crushing the body, which would have been you had you activated the button yourself. This is a very, very dark game.And the puzzle-solving elements do become quite challenging as the game goes on, through it never reaches the difficulty of games such as Braid. The game steadily introduces new mechanics to keep things fresh, with switches that can reverse gravity or active giant magnets, while the feedback for failure is always immediate and brutal. Thankfully the game has no loading screens even upon death so you can be back to have another go in a matter of seconds.The plot itself is thread-bare. There is no dialogue and no non-hostile characters besides one recurring one, whose finding seems to be the only real objective in this game. That does not mean the plot is not there though, and to me it seems like the team behind this deliberately left the game open to interpretation; the game is called LIMBO, how does that relate to the environments you find yourself in and the things that happen to you on your journey? Who are these other people you encounter from time to time? What happened to these factories and sewers and cities? These questions are never answered straight-forwardly, but it's for you to decide for yourself what this game is about and to me that makes it more powerful.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2011
												Wow. I first came across this game when Yahtzee did a ZP on the original XBox Live Arcade release, and eagerly awaited the release of a PC version. Thankfully we didn't have to wait too long, and it was well worth it.This game is *bleak*. You are insignificant, you will die a lot, and nothing and nobody cares about you. The atmosphere is wonderfully downbeat, especially when you think things can't get any worse and then the rain starts coming down...The less said about the plot the better. Not so much because I don't want to spoil things, but because it doesn't really have one, besides "You're looking for your sister". But that's not the point. Just walk right, get killed, try again. Walk right, die, try again.It won't take more than a couple of hours to finish this game, but it's very pretty and enjoyable to play. Plus the red/blue 3D mode is kind of interesting if you have a pair of glasses lying around.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												One of the classic indie games, Limbo is a puzzle(ish) platformer that absolutely nailed aesthetic and inspired imitators for years to come. Sometimes the controls don't feel precise and the deaths feel contrived due to lack of prior knowledge of the traps, but that's well mitigated by a competent checkpointing system that helps relieve any potential frustration. It's the kind of game where you can give it an initial run just to enjoy the experience (and get to see all the horrific death animations), then replay it and challenge yourself to do better, even avoid dying altogether. Not a perfect game, but still a great one. It's pretty easy to find cheap and worth picking up.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												I decided to play this after having heard so many great things about this game. Other games that I have enjoyed are sometimes compared to this game. Conclusion: this game is massively overrated.Yes, the game is atmospheric (although there is pretty much only one uniform atmosphere). The greyscale is good and the sound effects are a nice touch in some spots. Use of lighting (or lack thereof) is interesting in some areas. It's a straight up puzzle platformer though. It's mysterious, but not particularly "dark". Story and soundtrack are non-existent. There is a lot of trial and error where the way to pass a puzzle is to get killed through no fault of your own, and then figure out how to avoid the death, which makes it feel like the game is playing against you, not with you. The character you play is not particularly agile and doesn't always feel responsive to the controls. The game was short, but that's probably a good thing.

number of helpful: 24 of 49 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												LIMBO is not a good game. It is not a great game. It's an alright game that molds quickly when left out too long.The graphics are pretty interesting, and are the game's main gimmick in terms of bringing new ideas to the world of Platformers.The setting starts out beautifully, the dark and morbid forest full of disturbing atmosphere straight out of Dark Souls, but then quickly falls apart about halfway through. Once you leave the forest, the entirety of the rest of the game is in a disgustingly boring industrial factory-esque area that leaves pretty much anything the game had going for it behind in the dust, changing the mood of the game pretty dramatically in a way that I can't say I enjoyed whatsoever. It's pretty much just straight puzzles, a box-moving gravity-flipping gauntlet of nonstop boring puzzles, without any of the flavor the early levels had.There is no story. Any. At all. If you expect anything more than "go to the right" you'll be disappointed. This is a great game for illiterate gamers, since there is no reading proficiency needed to enjoy the non-existant plot.                The puzzles are usually pretty simple, but I'll admit got me stumped once or twice, so there's still some challenge in it. My major complaint about the level design is that the primary source of difficulty comes from the slow and clunky movement of the child, given there are many many challenges that revolve around you moving very quickly and even at your fastest may only make it by a thin margin.All in all, If this game's second half hadn't been such a terrible turn of scenery, atmosphere, and gameplay, this game could have gotten a reccomendation from me. The opening sections were so much fun. But seriously though everything past the forest is just hot garbage, and I don't want anyone to have to play through that again unless they're stuck in a twelve hour flight layover and forgot any other source of entertainment to bring with them besides a laptop and this game on it. It's that bad.

												Cuando te encontras con un juego como Limbo te das cuenta que ya no es solo que los videojuegos forman parte del Arte, sino que estos pueden formar parte de esas obras únicas, a las que llamamos, obra maestra. Sí, Limbo es una obra maestra, un juego de puzzles en plataformas, con una estética y apartado gráfico únicos, el juego pone a prueba tu habilidad y a la vez te regala un paseo visual digno de un cuadro de exposición de alto coste.Una obra de arte maestra suele pagarse millones, pero es que hasta los devs pusieron este grandioso juego de forma gratuita para añadirlo a nuestra biblioteca, de forma abierta y desinteresada, para que más gente lo pueda jugar.El sonido esta muy bien logrado, los efectos en pantalla, particulas, desenfoques, animaciones en general, todo esta perfectamente cuidado a lujo de detalle.Sí, te lo recomiendo, si no lo conseguiste gratis, pagalo... pensa que hay gente que pagó por el overwatch 60 euros, porque no gastar un poquito, en algo tan grande como este juego?Si tengo que poner un puntaje, le doy un 10.

												If you like little to no story with lots of frustrating and unforgiving puzzles, this game is for you. LIMBO has a cool ambiance and art style... that's about it. There's no naration, the character doesn't speak at all, you traverse random landscape after random landscape of some dystopian black and white h*ll hole with no explanation as to what's happening or why you're here. And also, screw whoever thought brain burrowing parasites was a cool idea. There's no way to avoid them, they're annoying as f**k, and they're disgusting. You get some white p.o.s. that lands on your head and burrows into it; which makes you go whichever direction it pleases until you find some sort of light sorce to burn it to make you turn around. THEN you have to find another nasty insect thing to rip it out of your head and eat it... as if it wasn't hard enough to figure out what the h*ll was going on or what you're suppose to be doing. I'm glad I got this game for free from some one day random Steam deal cause if I spent money on it, I'd be asking for a refund. The ending was also the epitome of the term anti-climactic that made the reason for you being there more or less confusing depending on how you interpret it as well as the whole game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Product received for free
												I had this game on my wishlist for awhile as it seemed to have been unanimously praised. When it was offered for free on Steam 6/21 and 6/22, I was eager to try it out. I was ultimately very disappointed with the game. Several times during my playthrough, I commented to friends that had I purchased Limbo, I likely would have refunded the game without hesitation.Positives: + The graphic style is unique and the developers succeeded in creating an atmosphere that makes the player feel isolated and uncertain. It reminded me a bit of how Spider-Man: Shattered Dimensions used the noir graphics. From an aesthetic standpoint, Limbo is a treat. The game runs at a constant 60FPS (locked) at 1080p.+ The game length (about 3-4 hours on a first playthrough) is just about right. I didn't really want to play it any more than this (more on this below).+ The checkpoint system is generous. Given the instant-death, trial-and-error nature of the puzzles, it is necessary.Negatives: - The trial-and-error nature of the puzzles is more frustrating than it is motivating. Successfully overcoming the objectives doesn't feel rewarding and oftentimes the solutions can only be discovered by dying repeatedly. Cheap deaths occur regularly, often from unavoidable hazards intentionally obscured by the shadows. Limbo seems to go for the "gotcha" and it ranges from irritating to frustrating. There is one particular puzzle (about 2/3rds through) where the game provides a paradigm to follow and then a second later rips the carpet out from under the player by shifting it so that the same action results in instant death. It isn't clever. I enjoy games that challenge me to think, and failing in games like Portal or The Talos Principle felt fair and motivated me to try again. Limbo left me wanting to press on simply so I could get through the game. After 3-4 hours, I had enough.- Movement feels floaty. The best comparison I could make would be Little Big Planet as that also features wonky platorming, but Limbo is worse. For a game that oftentimes requires precise timing/jumping, character movement is oftentimes sluggish.- The game lacks any graphics options and in general the settings are extremely bare-bones. Before playing through Limbo I thought this was at worst an oversight, at best an attempt by the developer to emphasize the experience rather than having the user worry about tweaking framerates and texture levels. After playing, I am inclined to think this was a conscious decision done not in the spirit of emphasizing a certain aesthetic but rather to scold the player for daring to want to adjust or customize the experience to their liking. Maybe that's unfair, but given the "gotcha" moments experienced in the puzzles, it combined with the lack of options to give me that sort of feeling.Conclusion:Had I paid for this game, I would have refunded it. Given that it was offered free for a limited time, all I lost was my time. Limbo is a game that has a unique aesthetic that is tarnished by the worst sort of trial-and-error puzzles, I would not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Product received for free
												Limbo is one of the bigger disappointment I've encountered in my roughy two decades as a video game connoisseur, which is mostly due to realizing that this game could have been so much better. Don't get me wrong, though. There is a lot to like here: the art style is great, the animations are very good, the ambient music is well-done. However, the main gameplay loop is unsatisfying. The problem is that, juding from what I have seen of the game (a little over half, just based on the amount of chapters), the puzzles all have only one solution, which is not something I appreciate in a puzzle game. A much bigger problem, though, is that the pace of the game is so incredibly slugglish. Your avatar walks as if he is geriatric. To add insult to injury, some sections do demand a bit of dexterity, leaving not much room for error. If the controls were tight and responsibe, the occasional trial and error gameplay wouldn't be so bad.The game being as it is, though, there is plenty of frustration to be had. Due to shortcomings with regards to the controls as well as the design (some puzzles are too much based on trial and error; most gameplay mechanics are introducted in a situation that quickly kills you instead of giving you some room to experiment without any danger), you easily end up dying. For instance, you figure out the solution to a puzzle but misjudge a jump. Thus, you slowly fall to your death. So, you watch the character move in slow-mo, he dies, the game draws out this moment much too long. A cinematic (?) pause has to pass afterwards before you can try again. Just to avoid any misunderstanding: it is not the case that I had been fumbling through half the game and then quit. No, instead I realized that this game is artificially drawn out due to questionable design decisions. With better controls and a faster feedback loop this game would take only about half as long. I couldn't see myself suffering through the rest of the game, so I quit.(I got Limbo for free during a special promotion on Steam.)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I guess I'm in the minority.I can't say I enjoyed this game. It's hard to write that. The game is clearly special, from a sound design and visual esthetic perspective. However, from a gameplay perspective, it's terrible. And I don't say that just because I'm bad at the game - I am. But that's not why I didn't like it. I didn't like it, because so much of the game expects you to play by trial and error. There's visual and sound cues, sure. But that doesn't make it better when you're still trying in vain to figure out what you're doing wrong and you've died 27 times in the same spot. Almost worse is when you know what you are supposed to do, and you still can't quite manage to get that one jump timed correctly. To add to that, there's moments (many of them) where you're not dying (no, really) and you simply have no clue what the game expects of you. Maybe I'm thick-witted and slow-fingered. Maybe I'm just tired after work. Limbo punishes me for everything that I do wrong and some of the things I do right. But that's not why I play games - I play them to have fun. Limbo isn't fun; it's annoying, obtuse, and requires regular backtracking and exploration of areas that you don't even know exist.Visuals: 9/10Sound: 9/10Fun: 3/10 (all the various deaths are entertaining, briefly)Overall: 4.5/10Would not die in Limbo again.I got Limbo for free, and it still cost me too much.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												While I did pick this game up for free on the Steam Sale I can say I actually paid for it via Humble Bundle a while back. This is just my summary of what the game's about. You can decide if it's your thing for yourself.-A puzzle platformer that, interestingly, does NOT rely on a single gimmick to sell the game. It's just your character, no special powers, you can run, jump, and push things. The game frequently switches from puzzle to platformer and back and forth, some "Puzzles" just being rather difficult platforming challenges and some things that seem like platforming challenges actually being puzzles, or a mix of both.-REQUIRES trial and error to get ahead. There are times where the game will just kill you through no fault of your own. It does often use this to clever effect, but this can feel frustrating and unfair. However as the checkpoints are very lenient I don't mind this much and just see it as a different game design approach. LIMBO treats death not as failure but a learning opportunity, though what you learn is sometimes sadly just "Don't do that next time".-First half of the game focuses on atmosphere, second half starts focusing on some significantly harder puzzles. There is a point in the last part of the game where it pretty much just becomes purely puzzles. Thankfully IMO these lategame puzzles are actually pretty good.-Several well-hidden secrets to find that sometimes require you to "Break" puzzles outright doing something you might initially think was an exploit. I love it when games make you think you broke them and then reveal they actually planned for you doing that.-Platforming and general character interaction is what I'd define as, interestingly "Hyperrealistic". What I mean by that is your character moves and interacts with the environment, dies, and platforms is done in a way that feels realistic to the extreme. For some they won't like this platforming approach, and it also makes the game veeeery child-unfriendly as the kid's deaths are often pretty gruesome. It's not Mortal Kombat where the game takes joy in the fatalities, however, but in fact what happens is pretty much exactly what you would in real life, which only makes it more disturbing. This also makes the controls feel "Unresponsive" for some people but if you ask me from actually playing it just means you can't turn your character instantaneously or bunny hop like it's CS:GO.-Very atmospheric art style. This is not a game you want to play if you want to feel bouncy and happy.-Story is at best minimalistic and at worst nonexistent.Overall LIMBO is NOT for everyone. That's gotta be stressed. Even if you like puzzle platformers it's not guarenteed you'll like this. However, if you've got 4 or so hours to kill you can sit down for an atmospheric jaunt that you'll probably enjoy somewhat.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
Product received for free
												Christians sure put the 'un' in 'fun' - even croaking at a young age won't spare you from infinite damp darkness filled with impalement, mutilation, electrocution, drowning and giant♥♥♥♥♥spiders.It's amazing what can be accomplished atmospherically with 2 colors and a bit of fog though. The aesthetic of this game is a sweeping victory for minimalism. It also somehow reminds me of the classic Russian cartoon 'Ёжик в тумане' - http://ria.ru/infografika/20151211/1340103447.htmlAlthough seemingly a very simple game, I can imagine lots of work was put into its mechanics. It tickles the brain in a good way seeing objects keep their momentum like in the real world and some of the puzzles are quite delightful physics wise.Sadly though, Puzzle and Platformer are among my most disliked genres and I'm going to have to go with a negative here, since there's no in-between. I don't think I've even played Super Mario for longer than 30 minutes at a time, so it's not that Limbo is a bad game, I just generally don't like it's ilk and find that there's tons of better stuff to spend my precious few gaming hours on.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												This is the "Shadow of the Colossus" of Indie games. I mean it. No, you don't ride a horse around and stab through giants. But this comparison to Limbo is justified in another way. This is a staple for Indie games. This is video game art. Like Shadow of the Colossus on the Playstation 2, Limbo tells gamers that a game can be beautiful, mysterious, and a subtle, yet deep tale about what one would do to bring back the one they hold dear.It took me about three hours to beat this game. The average gamer could probably beat it in 3-4 hours. But that's really not a big deal, because the "puzzles" are so intuitive and the overall game is so beautiful in its simplicity that it demands another playthrough. Not verbally, but I simply doubt that one's heart could bear abandoning this game after the first playthrough.9.3/10. A must have.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												Go right, find puzzle, die, repeat until you find the arbitrary, non-intuitive solution; whole game can be summed by that. Controls are simple in a bad way (oversimplified I think it's the term), and you often find yourself just hitting action everywhere in the hopes that you will find the place devs want you to hit. There is zero learning curve, as in, unlike games such as Portal where mechanics are explained in a non-hamfisted way, every puzzle expects you to already know and master the mechanics of it, and timing slightly short than perfect means doing everything over again. There is little sense of achievement, and you feel like you just finished a tedious chore, rather than you solved an intrincate puzzle. Probably didn't get to the part where you could get any sense of story, narrative, or anything at all that makes you feel SOMETHING for your character, other than "you can drown in 3' of water? Whoa you're useless kid".Also unlike Portal (ik, but it's the gold standard for puzzle platforming) there are no multiple approaches for a problem either, just find the one, cookie cutter solution, keep going right and that's that. Really no incentive whatsoever to keep playing, will probably watch someone doing some highlights on YouTube. One of those games where watching someone else play doesn't make you say "damn I want to get my hands on that!", but instead feels like "eh, think I got the whole experience from watching that". Goes to show me that I must play whatever I buy right away, before refund window closes.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I realize the game is a little dated, being from 2011 and all. It has been rotting in my library since then, but today I finally had time to play it.This game is alright. It's a short story about a boy wandering through a forest and being victim of all kinds of bad stuff.He also solves puzzles along the way, which never become much more interesting than pushing a block onto a switch. So it's basically the first test chamber of Portal 1, drawn out over multiple hours of gameplay. The game looks pretty nice, with the dynamic lighting and all. It stands out in its own way. The enemies and surroundings are subtly animated, but that's about it. It's mostly a black and white flickering experience.The puzzle gameplay is okay-ish. There are a lot of non-intuitive puzzles, which means that you will die on your first try. This trial-and-error gameplay is just game length padding. Were these puzzles designed in a better way, then the game would be twice as short and twice as exciting.The rest of the game is platforming. This is also okay, not great. The character feels sluggish, but none of the platforming segments require good timing or mechanics anyway. It's hard to say whether this is on purpose to hide the poor controls, but it occasionally looks that way.What bothers me greatly is how incompetent the character is. You can literally pull a minecart towards you on a flat road and die that way. You can't fall very far, which is a very strange mechanic for a platformer. If they were going for realism, then...they just didn't do a good job.In terms of art and uniqueness and whatever, yeah, there are some elements of that in here as well. It feels too forced to me, but I'm sure some people like this sort of approach. In conclusion, I wish there was a meh option instead of a Yes/No recommendation. Sure, I'll recommend this for when it's 75% off during a sale, but please don't buy it at full price. For the less than 3 hours of puzzle platformer gameplay, you can spend your 10 bucks in infinitely better ways.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												This is one of those games that has sat in my Steam library for years in the 'Another Artsy Indie Game I'll Try Someday' category.And now I wish I had tried it sooner.The first time your character gets decapitated by a bear trap, you will feel a tingle up your spine. When the spider catches you and spins you into its web, you will shudder with revulsion. When you finally (and brutally) tear the final leg from the spider's  body, you will marvel at how satisfying such a gruesome act could be.And all this is after just 48 minutes of playing the game! Any game that can tap my emotions so deftly will earn a resounding recommendation from me, regarless of how good/bad/ugly those emotions happen to be. Bonus points for acheiving this feat in such a minimalist environment with no vocals/text or any other in-game guidance (other than said environment itself).Final thought: I don't enjoy horror games. While this game has caused me to feel terror, I don't clasify it as 'horror'. This game is not violent or scary for the sake of being violent/scary, but uses the induced emotional state as a mechanic within the game (although you may not realize this at first).Duly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
Product received for free
												When this game came out, there probably weren't a whole lot of quality original indie games to choose from, or so it seems, as critics basically creamed their pants and showered endless praise over this one. However, the game is severely overrated. The visuals are quite good and the atmosphere is by far the game's strongest suit. It's actually very immersive and unsettling, especially when wearing a decent pair of headphones, but that's where my praise ends.The gameplay, the most important part of any indie game, falls flat on its face here. Instead of ingenious level design that constantly thrills you and keeps you glued to your controller like true indie masterpieces such as Shovel Knight and Freedom Planet, the game shoves moronic trial-and-error gameplay in your face at every moment. It tries too hard to be the Demon's Souls of platformers and just ends up being a complete bore full of cheap, unavoidable deaths, and a lackluster sense of progression. After a strong opening, everything starts to feel the same relatively fast and you're then left with a very unfulfilling experience. That is, if you're able to force yourself all the way to the abrupt ending like I did, and saying I had to force myself to complete it is really an understatement, but since the game was recently given away for free and I always finish everything I start, I figured why not. If you like gorgeous looking indie games with cheap, artificial difficulty, lack of story, and mundane puzzles, this is the game for you. For everyone else, check out an overlooked indie gem like Shadow Blade: Reload instead that actually respects your time as a gamer. I guarantee you'll have a lot more fun.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2011
												Like this game provides no text explanations or cutscenes for the plot, I have no right words to discribe what it is like. Limbo - a place on the edge of Hell, full of symbolism and allusions. The path, fear of darkness, insects, of coming water, sharp edges, fear of changes and inevitable death. Fear of meeting with someone beloved. Something that you've almost reached but slips away as soon as you approach. Limbo has it all and even more, it is possible to search for second, third and so on meaning of each aspect of the game.Open ending is a proof of how more important the path you've traveled comparing to the outcome.You don't even have to understand the events in the game, you have to feel it. It leaves both charming and sad feeling in my soul and that is something I appreciate the most.LIMBO presents both outstanding visuals and brilliant game mechanics. This game is one solid proof that "Games are an Art". Excellent art in this case.I'M STRONGLY RECOMMENDING IT TO EVERYONE.

												An amazing game that will keep you in fear and misery throughout the whole experience. The artstyle is black & white, but the sound is rather realistic than what you could consider 'old-styled'.Sometimes, certain actions can happen out of nowhere and jump-scare you, it has happened to me quite some times, but unlike other games like Five Nights at Freddy's where the jumpscares are cheap and badly-formatted (except for the second game), in Limbo you have to take notice not to repeat that again, in order to continue.Only problem I have found on my mac is the resolution, but maybe that's because I have a 27" screen.Overall, I give this game a 9.5/10, and I definetly recommend that you should check it out. Definetly worth the 10 euros.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Limbo is a great game and I recommend it to everyone willing to challenge their mind.Limbo delievers it's dark moody art style and mind boggling puzzels. Some puzzels may leave you confused for awhile as they did for me, but eventually you will figure it out, and the feeling of completing a hard puzzel is quite satisfying.The game also manages to be unpredictable. Occasionally dropping in a new feature in, to either make gameplay harder or rarely easier. I would consider my self a fps player more than anything else but I still enjoyed this game. Sometimes you have to leave the game and come back to it later and I recommend that so the game feels longer.I had a lot of fun with Limbo and I recommend it to everyone, especially people who like puzzels!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Who needs colors when you have atmosphere?There is no dialogue, you go in clueless.NO LOADING TIMES. It loads fully on startup. It's a continuous game; it doesn't seperate the levels.The puzzles themselves are genius. Some require you to do something ahead of time before you can do the initial thing.As all puzzle games do, this one really makes you think.There are a variety of challenges: Some physics based, some timed, and some you just get lucky on.The replay value in this game is to collect all the 'eggs' to get a secret achievement "DING" and just the achievements in general.8/10 Great looking monochrome game, and plays well too.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												Limbo is a very relaxing puzzle adventure that should take you less than 4 hours to complete. It's a fine example of what I would call a worthy Indie title to play.Despite the art work being nothing more than a silhouette, there is a lot of body language in the animations. There's also a lot of camera zooming in/out/panning smoothly and some nice background shadows all of which when combined create a peaceful yet creepy atmosphere. The creepy mood is also reflected within the music ambience and sound effects.There is a bit of some ragdoll-like physics, but thankfully this doesn't take complete control over the gameplay (or I would go nuts). I think what I like the most is that throughout the game, there are some pretty crafty puzzles. Maybe throughout the game you'll encounter about four puzzles that might make you scratch your head for about 20 mins each, but not long enough to get you frustrated. The rest of the puzzles are easy but not made to make you feel like a fool. My rule of thumb is, if you seem to get stuck, always head backwards to find something to bypass the obstacle ahead.Limbo is the perfect title for this game as well. Story-wise it's like you're living in a nightmare. There are some things going on. 1/3 of the game is like a spider chasing you. 1/3 feels like you walked into land owned by a nasty tribe. 1/3 is like a saw mill filled with so many death traps. Death seems to be a common occurrence and theme within this game.As a kid, I never liked games where you are chased by an invincible enemy or unstoppable force. And the only direction you can travel is forward. I dunno, maybe I got traumatized as a kid when the planet Zebes blew up in Super Metroid and you had to run away from the lava. In Limbo, the unstoppable force happens to be the big♥♥♥♥♥spider! But it's not so hard and doesn't happen frequently. So that's still alright. Unfortunately just like Hotline Miami, for some reason my Steam Achievements aren't being saved. I've had the "The End - Where Credit Is Due" achievement pop up for example, but it hasn't been recorded/saved to my profile. This is more of a Steam problem I would say.All in all, I would recommend this game if you can get it on discount.

												The best way I can describe this game is "captivatingly haunting".  The stark minimalist presentation works very well given the setting. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2011
												An artistic independant game seeped in melancholy and a general aire of despair and struggle. It is displayed in a minimalistic, monochrome format, with no dialogue, music, or text; and yet it still conveys strong emotional tone that permeates the short play-length of this title. The weakness of the main character and violent depictions of his death in this uncomfortable world really lend to the atmosphereThe actual gameplay revolves around physics-based puzzles in a 2D portrayal with no introduction and a "figure it out yourself" motivation that most companies are afraid to try. No tutorial and no introduction make this a game for the clever.With no replay value to speak of, this game is one that, while definitely worth the play-through, is neatly concluded as a hypothetical story to talk about, and reflect on withouth having to experience a second or third time through.For the discounted price, at 3 hours, I've paid more for movies from which I get less.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												It is hard to find a flaw on LIMBO. It throws you in a game without any kind of tutorial or even hints at controls, but it actually makes the grim atmosphere even better, as you have to learn by trial and error. You will die, a lot.Atmosphere is perfect, dark and spooky. Story begins, and ends, without any explanation, but you are able to piece a lot together from subtle hints along the road. The ending is open for interpretation and intentionally so.LIMBO is probably my second favourite indie game and one of the few videogames I would dare call Art.Equip yourself with a bit of imagination and a bit more patience and try it out. Try it. Now.Why aren't you playing yet?(note: to dispel possible doubts, I have almost no playtime recorded, but I have beaten it twice)

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												LIMBO is everything an indie game should be. Today, games are often made simply because they will sell. Games with huge budgets, top-notch graphics, and the most advanced AI can make millions of dollars and yet only provide the player with a lifeless experience. LIMBO puts you in a world that is devoid of color, music, and narrative and yet proves to be entertaining, challenging, and able to invoke emotion in the player. LIMBO is a puzzle-platformer with very simple controls. It doesn't give you a tutorial or hold your hand. It drops you in a lonely and hostile environment and let's you figure out for yourself how to advance and how to survive. The controls are tight and the puzzles are creative and challenging without being too frustrating. You'll never be scratcing your head for too long and finding the solution to a puzzle is always satisfying. Some may complain about the trial and error process of dying and retrying. I felt that this helped to enrich the dark atmosphere with a genuine sense of peril which is very important to the game. From beginning to end, the player feels a sense of helplessness. Even though our protagnist is silent, we can sense that he is lost and confused by his hostile surroundings. This makes the need to solve puzzles all the more necessary to the player as these small victories are what drive the player to move forward and discover the secrets of this strange and beautiful black-and-white world. 10/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												An amazing game that will keep you in fear and misery throughout the whole experience. The artstyle is black & white, but the sound is rather realistic than what you could consider 'old-styled'.Sometimes, certain actions can happen out of nowhere and jump-scare you, it has happened to me quite some times, but unlike other games like Five Nights at Freddy's where the jumpscares are cheap and badly-formatted (except for the second game), in Limbo you have to take notice not to repeat that again, in order to continue.Only problem I have found on my mac is the resolution, but maybe that's because I have a 27" screen.Overall, I give this game a 9.5/10, and I definetly recommend that you should check it out. Definetly worth the 10 euros.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												LIMBO is a prime example of Indie games gone right. Fluid gameplay, dark undertones, and a varied mix of difficult puzzles will keep players at their peak interest long after the game is over. However it’s also the game’s major downfall. The game is too damn short, especially for it’s 10 dollar price range. Collectibles hidden in dark paths aren’t enough to keep players playing. However, this shouldn’t sway you from picking it up, as LIMBO will be stuck in your head for years.

												Limbo is the kind of small gem you may find in gaming. Very simple to play yet addictive, the overall feeling is great, very atmospheric and compeling. This game mix puzzle and platform, with a bit of horror in the background. The whole "greyshading" visual aspect fits very well the purpose of the game. content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Wow!  This is a great 2-D puzzle game!  The game does not take very long to complete and the puzzles are just hard enough to keep you interested but not frustrated.  I was able to beat this game in a couple of sittings and was pleased with the ability to In-Home Stream Limbo to my Ubuntu 12.04 Linux Steam system.  I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys 2-D puzzles games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												An amazing game that will keep you in fear and misery throughout the whole experience. The artstyle is black & white, but the sound is rather realistic than what you could consider 'old-styled'.Sometimes, certain actions can happen out of nowhere and jump-scare you, it has happened to me quite some times, but unlike other games like Five Nights at Freddy's where the jumpscares are cheap and badly-formatted (except for the second game), in Limbo you have to take notice not to repeat that again, in order to continue.Only problem I have found on my mac is the resolution, but maybe that's because I have a 27" screen.Overall, I give this game a 9.5/10, and I definetly recommend that you should check it out. Definetly worth the 10 euros.

												This is one of those games that has simple gameplay and controls, but it's very well done.  The graphics are fantastic with the gloomy, moody, and sometimes disturbing atmosphere. content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Who needs colors when you have atmosphere?There is no dialogue, you go in clueless.NO LOADING TIMES. It loads fully on startup. It's a continuous game; it doesn't seperate the levels.The puzzles themselves are genius. Some require you to do something ahead of time before you can do the initial thing.As all puzzle games do, this one really makes you think.There are a variety of challenges: Some physics based, some timed, and some you just get lucky on.The replay value in this game is to collect all the 'eggs' to get a secret achievement "DING" and just the achievements in general.8/10 Great looking monochrome game, and plays well too.
